column10: I wouldn't call myself a gamer: I'm a newb on almost all levels. I've played Raft and some Forest and Valheim. I'm a chill easy-going gamer, but I like building and missions. The early access felt too easy because I played with someone else and they were way more game experienced and before I knew it, we had guns and he was blasting through everything. I didn't have time to enjoy going through the enemies and building. The update I have played strictly alone. I like that it's painstaking. It's not impossible, but even on easy mode with no base attacks, I am struggling. I enjoy that I can't powerhouse through this game and I get to enjoy learning to play. The update added soooo much more. I've made it through, I think, 4 of the missions. Maybe 5. But there are still plenty of enemies to fight, underwater ruins to explore, and inventory to gather. I'm still trying to figure out the guns (I've made two so far). It doesn't feel completely explanatory for a newb, but I can also google. I'm just trying to figure it out on my own. I friggin love this game so much.
Enjoyable Fun and Relaxing like a Raft Upgrade

I highly recommend it if your looking for something different and casual.

Sunkenland is very much an early access game and it has its flaws, but the road map that the dev has for planned updates makes me hopeful for where the game will eventually end up. It has a real fun game play loop, which is, admittedly, better with friends, but the exploration, crafting, and survival mechanics are solid. You can customize your experience by adjusting enemy, survival, raid, and loot options. I've been having a blast with the game. 

The looting system definitely needs to be fixed. It is rather frustrating to be looting junk, run out of inventory space, and have all of the contents of what you were looting drop on the ground. This happens a lot when I am filling up the chests at my base, and I click on a stack to move to a container, and instead of moving only the number of items that fit in the chest... it puts what fits in the chest, and then bumps the rest of the stack on the ground. I have also been known to accidentally hit the take all button when I have a full pack, and dump the entire contents of one of my chests on the floor in front of me. ugh... that is annoying.

The combat system is rather basic, and the AI is kind of stupid. If you can get enemies into the water, they can't swim down, so you can get under them and attack up, making them incapable of attacking you or defending themselves. I think they are working on enemy AI, though.

The trader system is pretty good, once you get used to it's intricacies. You can haggle with them a bit, and play around to get the best deal possible out of them. It almost reminds me of trading good in Morrowind.

Some progression blueprints are tide to exploration, which is nice, because I have been known to neglect exploration when I get into a good survival loop. I have also found various ways to sneak into enemy bases and rob them blind without needing to engage them in combat. I like being able to find ways to complete things which the developer may not have intended. I think it makes the exploration all the more rewarding.

With all of the things the dev has planned, I am hopeful for the future of this game.

Great game! Unfortunately, right now (2/23/24) it has only around 15 amazing hours of great playtime with well made progression, and about 10 more hours worth of grinding for guns which this game makes only somewhat fun. Though it is clear this game does need more updates, I still really enjoyed it, and it reminds me of Subnautica early access days. Of course this game does have a core gameplay loop more similar to Rust. I do think that the gun crafting system and obtaining iron is extremely grindy, but as long as the devs cut down on this a bit once more content is added, I don't think it's a big deal.

   I would love to see advanced blueprints/advanced guns used in later mission islands, and make the gun scrapping system less random. Furthermore, it'd also be great to be able to actually find guns occasionally, even if they are just crappy ones. 

   My biggest complaint for this game however, is that it absolutely SUCKS to complete an island and either 1. make multiple trips back to my base to save the loot or 2. sort through and leave behind alot of loot. I had the best backpack, which definitely isn't enough, and it's not like Subnautica where you can make bases which are closer to the later game content. Instead, the islands are all spread out on the East side of the map, and unlike Subnautica's formula where late game content follows a certain path/direction, your base is guaranteed to be far away from many islands which you will need to visit.

A survival game where you must gather resources, some of which are hard to find. There are enemies to fight but if you wish you can turn off attacks on your base and flag locations you've mastered to stop enemies there re-spawning.
Clearly still under development but this game is already addictive and has so much future potential.

The game is addictive and fun to play but it does become repetitive and some things are a grind. Building bases is fun once you learn what’s possible and what’s not possible.  No pun intended but the game lacks depth. Exploration either above or below the seas is primarily for the purpose of harvesting resources. There is no mystery or surprises that entice the player to progress in terms of discovery or exploration you just dive to pickup stuff. The game is too heavily dependent upon finding blueprints to craft items and upgrades and can become frustrating when the thing you need most can’t be found. Beyond shooting at NPC’s there is no interaction in the game other than a single trading outpost with a character that has only one line of dialog and is automated rather than interactive.  Most players prefer multiplayer but that’s also where most of the bugs are. Single player has been pretty stable at least for me. The graphics are pretty good.  Basically it’s kill the NPC’s on an island and harvest resources that you can find by diving while killing an occasional shark and diving to harvest resources that you can find on an island in order to build a base and make food to stay alive.  At first it’s engaging but between finding blueprints and gathering resources it becomes an exercise of rinse and repeat.

IF you struggle to find gun parts and such..... No worries. I have found something extraordinary..... 
If you have access to a weapons rack(I am on day 252 so I have them) I accidentally discovered a bug where you can DUPLICATE your weapons infinitely and scrap them for parts for better guns. All you need to do is put the weapon you want to duplicate into your hot bar, equip it so the first person shows the gun out. Go to a container and deposit the gun you are holding into said container. note that when you exit the box your character is STILL holding said weapon but you will not see a weapon in your hot bar. Now walk to the weapon rack and place the weapon on the rack and pick it back up. Now go back to your original weapon that is in the container and grab it too. You now have 2 kinds of the same weapon. ENJOY RECYCLING!!!!!

TL;DR Below.

Let's dive into the world of Sunkenland, a survival game that takes you on an underwater journey. It's not just about staying alive; it's about thriving in an aquatic wonderland with friends. Whether you're a solo explorer or prefer a squad, Sunkenland offers a fresh take on survival gaming, blending the thrill of the unknown with the camaraderie of cooperative play.

I usually don't go for underwater games, but Sunkenland got me hooked. It has Rust vibes and Raft feels. Whether it's island domination, spelunking in underwater ruins, gathering resources, racing friends on jet ski's, or just exploring the map, Sunkenland keeps the gameplay varied and engaging.

But, no game is without its quirks. Sunkenland could really use an "Unstick Button" – because who hasn't found themselves frustratingly trapped in a game's landscape? And the game would be even better with a shared server option, allowing friends to join in even when the host is off adventuring IRL. More options for character customization would be the cherry on top, along with options to change the players point of view, and – dare I dream – underwater bases and tunnel building!

What really stands out in Sunkenland is its innovative approach to survival gaming.  I've mostly left the building to a friend – watching their joy in construction is a game in itself – but the experience of collaborating on a base is where Sunkenland truly shines.

In its current form, Sunkenland is a gem with room to grow and evolve. I'm eagerly awaiting the future updates the developers have in store.

Wishlist (as of 2/20/2024):
-An "Unstick Button" for those awkward moments.
-Shared server play, please!
-More character customization – we love options!
-Ability to plant trees outside of planters – let's add a shovel.
-Changeable point of view for a better perspective.
-Underwater bases and tunnels? Bring it on!
-To move the darn boat changing color option! I have a talent of going through 5 colors in 1 boat ride..
-The trader having a rotating selection of goodies! 
-Speaking of the trader... Can we please drag and drop the items we're selling? It's a lot of clicking..
-Splitting items from Chests/Dead Bodies/Looted area! It would help!

>> TL;DR <<
-Sunkenland: A unique, underwater survival game.
-Great for team players and solo adventurers alike.
-A few tweaks needed, but it's a sea of fun with lots of potential.
-My wishlist for the game for now is above.
-I'm excited to see where the devs take this!

Rating: 9/10

I have played about 15 hours now and I can honestly say if I had been allowed to play a demo of this, I would not have purchased this.  

The reason is this is essentially a zombie game.  There is base building.  There are underwater areas to explore.  These are challenging in their own right.  But you will be attacked every few days.  There is no relief.  

Some people like that.  I personally don't.  

Keep in mind, of course, this is an early access game.  Things will change.  But as of right now, it's really just a zombie survival game.  The graphics are excellent though.  Since I can only give a yes or no recommendation I will say no.

If it had a "meh" option, I would pick that.

EDIT after 40+ hours   - February 14, 2024

I still stand by my previous review but felt I should I add a few relevant things that might influence others to decide if they should purchase this game at this time.

The game is first person.  There is no 3rd person view at this time.  That might change in the future, but I saw  no option for 3rd person in any of the key bindings list.  I personally can't stand 3rd person and being 1st person is the main factor that led me to purchase this, but others might prefer 3rd person and to each their own.

I mentioned the base raids every few days but let me be clear about that at this time.  You can change the settings to easy, normal, or hard.  You can also turn the raids off completely if you want.  The enemies still populate their various POI's (points of interest) and will be adjusted according to your difficulty settings.

Fun with friends. Very buggy, but I've only ran into 1 or 2 harmful bugs, most are just funny/useful. Also, at the review time, the game is early access, so not surprising. Don't play this alone, however. Similar to games like Lethal Company, it's barely any fun solo.

Ahoy, fellow adventurers! 🏴‍☠️

So, I set on the digital seas of Sunkenland, and let me tell you, it was like ordering instant noodles: quick, easy, and left me craving for more flavor. 🍜

Pros:

* Seru (that’s “fun” in Bahasa Indonesia) for a while. I mean, who doesn’t enjoy a good loot hunt? 🏴‍☠️💰
* The missions? Pfft, they’re easier than finding your lost sock in the laundry. 🧦
* Blink twice, and you’ve already completed half the game. ⏱️

Cons:

* Seriously, Sunkenland, did you skip the “Challenging Mission Design 101” class? 🤨
* I finished missions faster than my grandma can knit a scarf. 🧶
* It’s like the game whispered, “Psst, wanna finish this quest? Just breathe.” 🌬️

Wishlist for Sunkenland:

* More excitement, less predictability. Maybe throw in a kraken or two? 🦑
* Slower missions, please! I want to savor my pixelated victories like a fine cheese. 🧀

So, Sunkenland devs, let’s spice things up! Add some mystery, a dash of chaos, and maybe a side quest involving pirate karaoke. 🎤🏴‍☠️

Until then, I’ll be here, waiting for Sunkenland: The Great Noodle Heist DLC. 🍜💎

Honestly, the game is cool and has a ton of potential but there are so many seriously annoying flaws and oversights on a fundamental level that it's almost too annoying to bother playing.

Like imagine swimming to a bandit raft, an entire structure made of metal and wood, with a giant sail, and a net for fishing, and walking away with a few planks of wood, leaving the sail, the rope, the literal rowboat sitting on the deck, not to mention the wood and metal itself... no, I'll harvest the chair instead and leave the rest.

The day/night cycle is super annoying too. Sure, there are mods to fix that, but you shouldn't have to. Minutes past faster than seconds. It's like someone forgot to move a decimal point or something.

So many different aspects of this game are left wanting. Fun though I guess. Not bad by any means.. If you're looking for a simple game, this is it. If you're looking for a more complex and realistic survival game, there are too many more to bother with this one.

I really really want to like this one though. They're just missing the mark to make this anything more than it is at this point.

I really like this game, there's enough content to keep us entertained on our server we've set up. As a group of friends we were delighted to discover private servers had been implemented. There's lots to do and lots to like, slightly unpolished but that doesn't bother me.

What does bother me however, in it's current state, is every time we log in something has reset, or moved, or disappeared. It's becoming an irritating chore logging in knowing that we need to destroy an item that's inexplicably not where you left it. Yes you have to destroy it because maddeningly you can't just move an item...I know! 

I'd set up hourly snapshots on a Windows server but that was for backup purposes not to trawl through looking for a copy where the stove wasn't three floors higher than where we built it half way in a wall. 

Add to that, the map keeps resetting back to question marks so it's a question of rediscovering everything.

We'll be back, and best wishes to the dev team.

{Updated Review} Came back after major update. Got my money worth out of the game I think now. A lot of things were fixed. Shotgun is still stupidly overcharged for enemies, shotguns should not have much range but still do. Enemies have been evened out and don't insta kill you anymore which is nice. Collection system for guns gets a bit tedious, takes a really long time to collect the correct blueprints to create the gun you want. They added missions which was nice. Still needs work but will give you a decent amount of playtime. 

Things that could be better would be the trader, there really isn't a point to the trader at this point, barely anything of value there and just a waste of space. The enemies you fight have guns or machetes and you rarely get the bladed weapons and only get broken guns off of people to get blueprints from, downed enemies should drop their weapons instead of them disappearing, they also rarely drop ammo. Everything shouldn't need to be crafted.

{Original Review}Game has potential but at the current state it doesn't deserve support. If they make something more of it then yes but right now it is more broken than working.

Enemies with guns rarely ever miss, doesn't matter what gun, they can snipe you with a shotgun from across the map, full auto burst from far away and you get hit with every shot. Load a game and every enemy disappears. If there are walls it doesn't matter, enemies will teleport through them just to kill you.

UPDATE: Don't waste your time. Every update deletes any progress you made, so exploring late game features is literally a whole waste of time. 

*Played on PC and Steam Deck* 

My review is centered around PC, I played for like a half hour on the deck for this review. Those comments will be at the bottom. 

What I liked about this game (and yes i understand this is early access) 
- Post Apocalyptic, 95% water based map. (There are islands, and other features that are not submerged) 
- The crafting and building 
- There is a subtle vision and path that it's evident the game will likely take. 

What I like about the potential- 
- The devs can take this world anywhere, story wise. 
- The bones of it are great, its thought out well 
- there is a lot of room for additions to tech tree, random map interactions, fishing, crafting, it all seems to be there. 

Anything that I could put in "dislike", the devs have stated they are working on, or would otherwise be foolish not to. So I dont feel there is a point in listing things out that will be changed. AI balance, AI raids, random sharks, all this will be polished out i'm sure. So i'll add this, in a meta and a lot of very particular instances, the game is *good*. 


Steam Deck Notes; 

Like other games, there is a bit of early key binding and wrangling to get non-deck optimized games playable. But I can't help but realize this game would be near perfect for the deck. 

I did notice I was unable to access my PC save on my steam deck, which was a massive bummer. But considering all the other additions and polishing in the works, I can't actually fault them for this. But I do hope to see it in the future.
Amazing resource gathering and base building game! Still needs plenty of polish but I have high hopes for whats to come in the future!

Progression feels nice too, going form my stone age to my iron age was super nice and smooth.

Rust with Islands

First I want to say:

This game should NOT be compared to Raft. 

Sunkenland lacks one crucial aspect of Raft: the ability to build a mobile, floating base.
In this game, you'll have to build your base on islands. Vehicles just provide mobility and some storage.
So the only thing they have in common is the "survival on sea" theme. Gameplay-wise it's more akin to Stranded Deep + Rust.

EDIT for 0.200:

Okay so I've played the 0.200 update for like three days with a friend now.

And I retain my thumbs down.

The most jarring problems which I absolutely can not tolerate is the frequent "disconnected from host player" error even when I AM THE HOST PLAYER.

The other problem is the game automatically and constantly adjusts (reduces) your system microphone volume EVEN WITH IN-GAME VOICE CHAT TURNED OFF.

These problems annoys me to no end. Other than that, the game's content is solid. Without those problems I would give it a thumbs up.

Sure there are bugs and glitches but the content and creativity is awesome.

I can't recommend the game at this time. The game is frustrating. It has a lot of promise, but it needs a LOT of work. I love the premise and the setting, the underwater aspect and locations are great, but the world needs a lot of work - there's not much actual content or variety just yet. Keep in mind, it's early access so presumably things will get better. Right now the game is a grind for resources, and not in a good way. One issue I have is that each update brings new things, but there really isn't any documentation for the changes. You have to try to figure out how to do things as you go along, and some of the new changes are complex and confusing. The whole project would benefit from some documentation to help people learn what to do. At least some better pop-up prompts in the game to guide us. Also, each update or "patch" breaks a lot of things. At first it seemed like the devs were quickly addressing issues as they came up, but that doesn't seem to be the case anymore. It could be that there just got to be too many problems for a small dev team to handle. Hopefully things will improve with time. It has a lot of promise, and the problems that trouble me might not be deal breakers for some.  It might be worth a look if you find it on sale.
I have thoroughly enjoyed Sunkenland! I'm looking forward to any expansions and updated in the future! I would recommend this game!

Cons

- Recent update removed ability to place player made structure on hostile ground.
- Open World but very scripted story line and progression flow.

I'm having mixed feelings about it.
It's a promising game but I'm feeling very frustrated with the current state of it.
I gave thumbs up, then changed to negative, now changed back to positive. 
Also, it's in EA which means is under constant development.

Here are the pros and cons:

Good:

- Interesting world to explore based on diving, sailing, etc.
- It's fun playing in multiplayer.
- Have a relatively beautiful world (not the buildings which are awful)
- Has a lot of potential.

Bad:

- Enemies can attack you through walls.

- Ranged enemies feels too OP. They will likely hit you whatever the scenario.

- For the player is almost impossible to hit an enemy with arrows (crossbow/bow) once they are moving, even if the target is 100% on the enemy body (Something's wrong with the hit boxes!?).

- Building system is very clunky and unpolished. You can build over anything else.

- Trying to focus on an object for interaction (e.g., chest, grill, etc.) when there is something else behind it (even having a wall between them) is very difficult. (Fix your line tracing/ray casting used to pick the focused object :P)

- I could not claim any land that I conquered because the system is broken in the current patch.

- This current patch also broke map features, like showing your teammate, discovered islands, etc.

Suggestions:

- Stop dropping the loot on the ground if the destination is full. Example, trying to store more wood in a chest that it can take, where the excess is just dropped on the ground. Why not keeping the excess in the inventory like any other game? I don't want to do math every time I interact with a recipient.

- Need more ways to defend your base against the AI's raids (e.g., turrets, NPCs, traps, etc).

Be more careful with updates making sure that what is working continues to work after the update.
Will change it to be positive once it gets improved again.

This review is taking into account the v0.150 and v0.200 updates in which we played mainly saying whats good and needs work and what has been improved on.

Pros: 

Great underwater exploration. You get a good variety of equipment like flippers, sacks, oxygen tanks and structures to explore and scavenge.

PvE combat against different enemies, both animal and human, in and out of the water.

You can choose where you want to go at anytime and explore or craft or build with a lot of potential even with the low amount of things currently in the game.

Trophies and special items like Neon signs to make hunting have a goal even at end game and set your base apart from other peoples.

The v0.200 added 45 degree structures and half walls which is really good for expanding better base designs.
 
A good base amount of things to do with Anvils, Researching, Crafting Tables etc. A good progression route you can follow from early to mid to endgame.

Gun customisation added not just 1 red dot sight.

Character creator has a good base to it.

New huge islands to fight on and explore for blueprints as of v0.200.

Big map with a lot of locations to explore and can freely build anywhere given you control the territory.

Better enemy drops not just 1 cloth or a mushroom you can get gun parts and useful things.

Cool basic use of electricity, would be even better if in future updates you could industrialize and make auto farmers and link chests up to farms or smelters so you can make things while away from base.

Can swap between beta versions so even when old worlds become obsolete due to updates you can revert back and continue to play on them.

Cons:

Hotbar isn't integrated into the inventory and as of v0.200 random items seem to get forced into it.

Can't edit a character when made and pretty limited choice of who you can create.

Despite the building requirements saying you need columns to build upper floors you can just destroy them and have floating builds, not exactly a bad thing but its a big oversight.

Trying to go faster in the start boat makes your character energy decrease which seems odd.

Decoration items can't be picked up once put down so if you misplace it then you lose it.

Some items removed like the Halloween pumpkin are still in the game but have no icon.

Audio issues especially with item pick ups, taking 1 wood makes an invidiual item pick up noise, while taking 50 makes the pick up noise 50 times in one being extremely loud. Another one is the starter boat makes an awful clunky noise that persists even when the game is paused.

Sleeping seems to not sync with actual night time meaning you either have to wait for the water to heat up in the morning or keep busy at base to kill time.

Bit of a minor issue but glass walls are randomly locked behind a discoverable blueprint which I couldn't find so I had to resort to using 45 degree walls, you should get guaranteed access to that from the beginning or on tier 1 of the research table.

The newly implemented missions don't seem to serve any purpose other than a slight guide on the order to target islands, but I'd rather just explore where I want since its an open world. Maybe make the trader give out randomised missions that you can cash in for rewards instead. And give the trader a lot more items to buy and sell that randomise and change every 5 days or so, its always almost the same thing.

Changes to chest and item sizes. A ton of things have been nerfed making looting more tedious, wood and scrap have been slightly increased which is good but the majority of things have been cut back a lot which for some things like glass as 40 was a bit too much but things like basic items needing so many resources, advanced components stack sizes, the basic boat having almost no slots etc is just a hindrance, it doesn't rebalance the game or make it challenging, just irritating when you have to make multiple long trips to cover an island instead of 1 or 2.

The combat has always been very buggy but particularly with the crossbow it just does not hit the target especially when aiming high, it seemed to work as of v0.200 so maybe v0.201 broke it? Bullets stray off especially when you strafe to dodge enemies. The enemy are either blind or insanely punishing to the point where hard is infuriating to play when enemies can shoot through walls or group together to gang up on you.

Since you have no passive health regen for having full hunger and thirst and now algae is seemingly a lot rarer and you need to research to even craft it you have no reliable way early game to heal and because of the glitchy combat and hitboxes and strange enemy AI you need to resort to use other glitches to win fights.

Flags don't seem to claim land and enemies respawned right on the island at midnight and nearly instantly killed me since I was low on health from only just taking over it.

The hitboxes are very dodgy and sometimes extend way past walls, fences so you cant shoot through them but the enemy seemingly can. I just resort to jump stabbing enemies through the floor/walls with a spear quite often since peaking gets you almost instakilled.

Invisible walls particularly on Radio Island. I'm not sure if it was an attempt to make you use the regular route but to get a tactical advantage I went round the rocks on the side and hit a huge invisible wall that seemingly just gets cut off so you can still get round it anyway.

With boats your character hitbox disappears and any raft bases slightly above water you can clip through and kill enemies as long as your boat fits underneath.

Raiding on the higher end is so often your base gets demolished extremely fast and forget about building a big base because enemies just decide to spawn inside your defences and break your stuff.

Underwater combat is essentially just repair your armour and bring herbs/antibiotics because you WILL be hit. A dodge mechanic would be nice, or some way of making shark or hammerhead fights winnable without being hit.

I appreciate this might come off as very negative and I do think the game has a lot of potential, most survival games while fun come off as very generic and this has a unique twist I don't think anything else has capitalised on, at least properly. But the v0.200 update is pretty disappointing and still very buggy. I'd recommend just reverting to v0.150 which felt more balanced and fun even without the newest additions. Since this account has under 2 hours playtime I'm gonna ask for a refund and hopefully the game will be much better in future full release and I might buy it again. If the devs by some chance read this don't get disheartened because your game is good and it has potential to be a VERY good survival type game but it just needs a bit of work before I recommend people pay for it.

Probably the most fun I've had in a long time with a game. Overall, while still an early access game, I find this to be an endless, fascinating game. While it takes awhile to get comfortable with the game, it gives creepy yet fun experience in the realm of underwater exploration. I haven't played co-op which I feel would be fun especially when trying to combat those dam sharks!!! I haven't explored even a portion of the map as I can't seem to stay warm! I'm freezing, so I need to get further into the game. Once this happens I know I'll be more drawn in, especially with new updates. The only thing that kind of sucked was that I had my woman fairly built, then the new update came and rendering my save obsolete and not working. So I started a new character. No problem, I've learned along the way to get built up fast! LOVE THIS GAME!!!!!!!

I am really enjoying the game I do not get to play much anymore due to other responsibilities but I make time for this game my own little get away from stresses of life, so thank you to the game makers. I can unfortunately only play the  single player version of the game as my connection lags badly when trying to log onto the servers, most likely as I am in South Africa. My biggest irritation is the sleep and day night cycle that keep going out of sync. Also at one point you get to clear out a abandoned outpost, it would be cool if once cleared out an advanced trader appeared there

Love the game, lots of fun, nice world...  To me it hits a nice spot between Valheim and Icarus...  I found it intuitive so not a lot of prep before start playing...  Though reading a starter guide is always a good idea.  It is early access so there are a few glitches with the new 0.2.0 but most can be worked around...  Want to see how fast the devs can clean them up (action bar highlights, flags not preventing enemy respawns are the 2 that annoy me the most).    Anyway if you want to play a fun and not overly intense survival game with a nice balance farming and fighting then it is worth a look.

Complete waste of money, every update you loose your progress then have to start again.  Until they fix this issue do not buy it.

While waiting for some other titles to launch, I decided to play the game based on reviews.  I started the game and it seemed very basic, with so/so graphics, etc.  However, and although still in development, it became quite addicting.....until they did a patch/upgrade and I lost all of my save files.  Apparently some new "upgrade" versions can't use "older save files"...like the previous days version of "older".  Nowhere do I feel I adequately warned about losing files when I hit a button to volunteer to submit development data.  I am not one to follow games sites nor other sites on them...I just play and either enjoy them or trash them.

Given I was quite few weeks into the game to say I am a little "pissed" would be an understatement.  So much so I blew out the game and wish it would disappear...forever.  "Development" would be an understatement....who makes a game whereas the upgrades/patches are not compatible with the last days saved files.....who???

I still have it in my library and may bring it out again....after it's completely out of development.....maybe!!

Sign.  Mr. Miffed
hi

Update 0.2 is in a very bad state and should not have been released. Not the same version from playtest. Very few bug fixes from 3+ months of feedback. New systems are broken and don't work right. Amateur devs release an amateur update.

[hr][/hr]
All of Rust's annoying mechanics, plus NPC raids on timers with horrible scaling. Stranded Deep environment, not Raft: there is no central raft or forced movement, it is a static world. You do feel the influence of Raft's crafting system. Building is Ark levels of abhorrent.

These are clearly not experienced devs with extensive knowledge of game design and systems. It is an amateur attempt to recreate and merge some of their favorite games. If they get some attention (read as: money) and hire some industry talent, they may be able to hold a candle to their influences. Mostly, this feels destined to die out slowly in the night while being a fun distraction made better with a group.

[hr][/hr]
Hybrid Sprint ftw! Tap to toggle, hold to...hold. It's great! Been saying for a decade that more games need this. With that said, there should still be an option to force toggle/hold. Options are always better. Hold to sprint is terrible and constantly resets, while held.

Water environments are done well. Had no anxiety or apprehension to jump right in. It is bright and welcoming during the day. The shimmer effect could use some tweaking. Starter amount of air/breath/O2 is perfectly sufficient. Death is not immediate upon running out of air (HP slowly drains), which is nice.

The basic looting loop is probably the chillest ever. However, the ridiculous "freezing at night" system means it is nearly impossible to fill your boat's chest and your inventory before you have to retreat for the day - or defend a raid.

Realism is fine, but too often results in annoying mechanics that add nothing to the game. For combat, they leaned too heavily into Rust. For interactions, they leaned too heavily into Raft. More items need a remote inventory, instead of "ingredient" slots (e.g. boats, grills, furnace, recycler).

No thought or attention has gone into inventory management, in a building/crafting game - this is inexcusable. The hotbar is ignored when looting, even when returning a grenade from your hand. For example: grenade in slot 5, pick up grenade from the ground and it goes into your inventory, you must manually drop it onto slot 5 to have a stack of 2 grenades in slot 5, hit 5 to equip a grenade and you now have one in slot 5 and one in your hand, hit another slot to unequip the grenade and it is now in your inventory, you must manually drop it back to slot 5 to re-stack it. I can't think of a more annoying inventory system.

Lots of work to go. LOTS! LOTS!! No reason for this to be in EA this early - they don't need feedback, they need to put their heads down and get to work!

[b]Issues:[/b]
[list]
    [*]Options don't do what they say (camera shake, even when paused).
    [*]HUD is terrible at keeping you informed of relevant information.
    [*]Enemy AI is atrocious. Raiding enemies make no noise and are difficult to locate. Melee combat is bottom-of-the-barrel, then throw in stamina.
    [*]Healing over time doesn't mesh well with the horde-style raids. Results in combat that feels too slow, boring, and punishing.
    [*]O2 tank system is implemented in the most player unfriendly way imaginable.
    [*]Needs tech tree, even if only visual, simply to educate the player on what relies on what.
    [*]Movement is restricted (camera doesn't point straight up/down) and sprint doesn't work with swim up/down.
    [*]Lots of jank with the boats, and terrible mounted camera movement.
    [*]Resource re-spawn system doesn't care about your builds.
    [*]Interactions don't care about your builds or terrain (loot through concrete walls).
    [*]Projectiles often don't care about your builds or terrain.
    [*]Audio is a mess. Some effects even have their L/R balance backwards.
    [*]Aside from the bad build system, costs need readjusted across the board - especially for wood.
    [*]Roof tiles are in a near broken state and should never have been presented to players.
    [*]There are multiple build menus for no reason; and, scrolling in them is annoying due to not being allowed to scroll when hovering over an ingredient, which take up over 50% of the vertical space.
    [*]When a menu is open, Tab should close the opened menu and not open the Inventory.
    [*]Deconstructing a window will remove the wall without a confirmation and leave the window floating.
    [*]"Hit-boxes" are annoying: from walking up purifiers, to axing friendly builds off screen, blocking underground builds by standing above them, and even not being able to interact with opened doors (only their frames).
    [*]Even the art assets are off: iron sights not centered, hands clip through gloves.
    [*]Some translations are missing (Black Powder) and others are wrong ("White" gloves can be red or black). Energy gains are often omitted from item descriptions. They didn't even rename most of their "store bought" clothing assets - pathetic and lazy.
    [*]They lean heavily into overly complex mechanics, like aim-based ladder climbing speed, and over used annoyance mechanics like Bleeding 4x in a single engagement.
    [*]No RNG protection mechanic - end up with tons of useless clothing with no early-game recycling.
    [*]Sleeping needs tweaked. Impossible to fix schedule by sleeping earlier/shorter, have to stay up to fix it. The semi-fixed 10 hour sleep is a bit excessive.
    [*]Fish/food has way too much inventory bloat. Cooked foods should condense to a much smaller pool of generic items. This is not an MMO with trading and specialization. It doesn't need this many items.
    [*]HP buff UI overlaps with armor display; and, it doesn't give you the increased HP - you still have to heal.
    [*]Black Powder becomes useless too fast and Chemical Substances are over-used. A starter fix would be to make ammo always use black powder.
    [*]Secondary interact UI sometimes disappears when not needed (furnace) and other times does not (stove).
    [*]Overflow from inventories when transferring gets thrown on the ground. Devs are assholes for this!
    [*]Splitting a stack is limited to within your own inventory.
    [*]Cannot put a fire out or remove unused wood/fuel.
    [*]Renaming containers should highlight and select the input box so we can start typing immediately, and Enter/Esc should act on the OK/Cancel buttons.
    [*]Destroying an empty box pops out an erroneous empty sack (the old remote inventory) that you can interact with.
    [*]Windows still reports the microphone is being used by Sunkenland when voice chat is disabled.
    [*]Halloween event really needs to end! ;) Hopefully they just want more testing of their event system and this is not an indication of their laziness to implement a loading timer.
[/list]

People are writing reviews on this like it's the full product, so for those with a life:

- It's in early access, and it looks like utter dogshit, bland, and most stuff is repeated a few times so you don't have too little things at the cost of originality, at the time of writing this it's the V0.2 update, so WAY before any 1.0 update, I'd say it gets a pass at the moment, cause they're talking about reworking it as time goes on anyway.

- It's a little buggy, but that's a given since it's early access, most bugs arent game breaking, and can often be fixed by a simple button press. It's mostly visual bugs too, from my experience. Again, typical with early access, especially THIS early.

- It looks beyond awful and like a unity project, but it's to be expected as it's early access. It's good fun though once you look past it all like a critic, and just put yourself in that mindset of how you used to play beyond awful unity games because you werent aware of Steam when you were little, if you stop comparing this game to modern triple-a titles, it can be genuinely fun. You just gotta look past the flaws, they'll be gone in the full release anyway.

While I do recommend the game, if you're one of those people that can't grasp the concept of "so bad it's good", I recommend you wait until it's fully released, rather than bombard the reviews with the obvious.

It's a fun yet terribly put together shitpost of a game best enjoyed privately with friends and I really recommend it if you're a gameplay over visuals kinda guy, even if it's barren.

great game
This is a really fun, solid game with good build mechanics, fun looting and leveling up your tech. I'm enjoying my time with it.

A great EA game with a lot of potential. The island and underwater exploration is very satisfying with a good sense of progression. It reminds me of Raft but fighting enemies and you don't have to spend countless amounts of time in the water itself you can make a conscious choice to go where you want. It's hard to make a survival game that has something different about it but this definitely has a lot of unique ideas.

The trophies you can find to put up in your base are very fun to find even after having set up a base and the building itself is very simple but effective. A wide variety of different tables for different uses.

The building almost has the structural integrity mechanic like in Valheim where you need pillars/supports to build but you can bypass it by building on your pillars and then removing them. Unsure whether this is intended or a bug, but it allows for a lot of creativity when building even though it can be a little finicky

The sunken buildings are fun to explore but it would be even better if all or more of the floors were accessible even above land as for some players who prefer combat to looting could get bored of the repetition without having varieties of structures to explore.

The combat is fun but a lot of the hitboxes on terrain is off from the actual texture meaning enemies can shoot you through walls sometimes and you can't shoot back, or you shoot through a gap in a fence but the gap is part of a wall so the bullet doesn't pass through. The AI can be a either a bit blind and predictable or a tactical trained sniper that almost instantly kills you with no inbetween.

The difficulty does need a little bit of balancing as well on the high and very high settings raiding becomes 2,3 times a day its hard to leave your base in single player to continue getting supplies while also making sure your base isn't destroyed. The way I got round this was by using steep sloped buildings where the player can jump up but not the AI but even then things built low down were broken very quickly.

Overall a really good game especially for early access with tons of nice ideas, it just needs bug fixing a little and a few tweaks but definitely recommend buying it!
a plus

[h1] Purchasing Guide [/h1]

[h3] Overview [/h3]

The idea behind this game is that you are dropped into a world covered in water and spotted with islands. These islands are occupied by clans that differ in difficulty. Your goal is to scavenge and re purpose items found in underwater cities, mansions, factories, and other POI's. With those items you need to build defences  to protect all of your belongings from attacks mounted by the clans - matching your current progress with the difficulty of these attackers. Your main way of gathering materials is under water ruins and raiding clan islands. 

[h3] The Good [/h3]
- GREAT pacing in the way in which you progress preserves the fun and adventure as you build your armory.
- Freedom of placing objects around the world or your base. This allows you to set up custom peeks and find different uses for items that fit your needs.
- Hours of fun. Once you are in and get going, you will not want to take a break for at LEAST 3ish hours.
- Amazing concept. This game is literally Rust meets The Forest meets 7 Days to Die. Although I find this game less repetitive than 7 Days to Die.
- Fun vehicles and fun to follow guided POI's
- THE SOUND OF GATHERING SCRAP IS SO SATISFYING
- Raids are a nice break from gathering materials and taking over other islands.
- Multiplayer is the most fun way to play the game but it doesn't come at the cost of singleplayer.
- Since I have bought the game there has been two updates already.
- great community.

[h3] The Bad [/h3]
- Sound design is AWFUL in many cases especially when recycling old gun parts.
- Enemy hitboxes and movement is so wacky and fast that it is sometimes hard to hit anything with the crossbow or guns.
- Guns are very up in the air - for some reason there are black powder weapons but you can just as easily get to a regular modern pistol so what is the point?
- The way the environment looks on islands is just poor. It's like someone just painted blobs all around and called it "a mountain".
- Needs more customization options for game settings - although what it has is pretty good for now.
- Needs variation in how you can play the game. Progression is linear but the trader almost always has the same stuff. This stuff is useless in the beginning, and not worth it in the end as you have to make multiple boxes to store just valuables. 
- Needs better animations (I understand it is early access and I know they will fix it. Just saying the current state of the game).
- Kind of pricey for this EARLY of early access. I mean $20 is in no way bad, but other established and finished games show this price-point when sales are on 4-6 times a year.

So its an adult Minecraft that is more like Raft than Rust.  Its a flooded world and you build stationary bases, not mobile ones. 

Explore, build, survive, forage, farm, trade, vanquish NPC enemies, and literally dumpster dive while diving.

Advance through several tiers of tech and eventually eliminate all enemies on the map. Build boats, bases, and even a helicopter. 

Both single player and coop via hosting a server are available. Seriously, this game shines when a few of your friends are all helping get stuff done.  Unlike many other team/coop games, this offers a real sense of community and achievement. 

So yes, its in early release, there are a few bugs, but none without a workaround:
1) If an enemy glitches into a rock, you can flush them dead by tossing grenades to their location.
2) If someone who connects to your server starts rubber-banding, you can save the game, close the server, re-launch it, and have everyone connect again. 
3) Building a base on water in the center of a few enemy islands is a good idea because it allows you to  access those islands easily. On your enhanced foundations, remember to put wall spikes, barbed wire, then reinforced barricades between the waterline and under your base to help keep invaders from going under and glitching through the floor.

And some tips:  
1) The server region selection does not remember your choices. The default is in Asia, Great if you are in Asia. 
2) If you;re hosting a server, password protect it with something complex. Other players will try to connect to grief.
3) Play a bit, get familiar, then start a new game, and don't build your first base on rubber duck island. 
4) Don't build advanced versions of things on top of metal foundations, build them on top of the reinforced foundations. This way you lessen the chance of having to build them twice. 

Strongly strongly recommend for a group of friends to get together and play something that offers more than just beating the snot out of the other team.

Update: Above I said to password protect your server.  Thats not the safest route.  When hosting, you should UN-check viewable to public then send your friends invitations to play from the ESC menu. Bacause if your server can be seen by the public, even if someone doesn't have the password, they can still get your IP address while trying to connect. NEVER a good thing.

If you like the mechanics of Raft and the same kind of no-hand-holding, janky graphics and combat problems as 7 days to die, then this will be up your street.

Despite both those games getting several hundred hours of playtime from me, this has lasted just 77 minutes before on easy mode with everything combat set to low, I was killed 15 times time under 5 minutes when 3 naked enemies invaded my base. As commented elsewhere, the combat and respawn mechanics leave SO much to be desired, plenty of room here for the game to grow.

Equally, without a story or tutorial or any guidance, working out what you are supposed to do, what you can do what and how things work is...challenging, and not in a way I enjoy.

Crafting mechanics and default controls not intuitive, wound up spending 15 minutes working those out and turns out on a single player world neither crafting nor controls menu actually pauses the world, hence the epic death loop.

Other people here have commented on the build mechanics, but for me, I built a foundation, chucked a bunch of stuff on top of it intending to fully base plan & segment by room later once I had enough resources aaaaaaaaaaaaaand theres no option to move or destroy placed items or buildings. I didn't find an island other than starter that I could have inhabited in my limited playtime, but explored 2 "rings" of sunken things, rafts and islands nearby. This would make moving to a secondary island where I could build a much nicer base impossible.

Final thing - Wood storage and scrap metal storage furniture is not worth building. Neither take a full stack of the item, you are better off creating a chest monster for storage unless you like the aesthetic.

This has something. The idea is still really good and I almost already want to give it another chance and see if maybe I just mucked up because it was first playthrough and I missed a bunch. Realistically, unless its combat issues are resolved, the progression is better worked out and the crafting/building mechanics are also improved a lot, this sits in the "early access games I feel I probably wasted money on" category for me. If it drastically improves on its next major update I will update this to reflect, but from Jan 24, it looks like it needs another 2-3 years of dev to get to a place where its worth playing as single player.

Plz see other reports on security issues on multiplayer stuff, deffo not one I'll be trying THAT with.

Alright my first steam review here we go (37 hours gameplay)

This game is good, and loads of fun with your buddies. One of my favorite games right now. It has great potential. Hopefully the Devs see this review as I hope they take a lot of my advice to make this game awesome and draw more players in. If they made this game great and added DLC I would give them all my monies.

Here is a list of things that needs work as of 01/20/2023

-Helicopter spawns in below constructed floors sometimes (I made a Helipad lol)
-Player spawns in below made floors and foundations sometimes (A bit annoying sometimes lol)
-Enemies need to respawn at islands, otherwise you can kill every enemy in the game and BOOM no more action
-If you take your flag down from a captured Island it needs to default to the original faction and respawn enemies again (I kept finding better islands to build a base on and noticed that even though I took the flag down, Its still my island... and if there was enemy respawn there would be a continuation of action)
-Needs an option in the menu that allows enemy raids but no structure damage (Some of us like being raided but don't want our things destroyed lol I ain't got time for dat)
-Enemy raids need to come in boats that despawn or something when you start getting raided by humans (Humans will start swimming up to your island without boats and adding the boats would just be a nice touch)
-Red dot sight needs to be attached to the gun itself rather than attached to all compatible guns (I like the red dot on my SMG but not my rifle) 
-More everything! More cosmetics, vehicles (ESPECIALLY 4 seater helicopter with 2 chests maybe a little bird wink wink), weapons, attachments (scope or ACOG please), clothes, Iron floor? (can build iron structures but the iron floor is non existent like it was forgotten lol!), Islands (please no recycling the same buildings!!), and underwater places to loot. ALSO BIOMES WOULD BE COOL why is there a random iceberg in the middle of the map lol lets have biomes in different parts of the map!!!
-BTW helicopter controls are great!! JUST NEEDS A FREE LOOK TOGGLE you are locked in just seeing in front of you and cannot look around... maybe L Shift or RMB??
-SLEEPING IS A HUGE PROBLEM... you should only be able to sleep from 20:00 to 03:00 and wake up at 5:00/06:00 EVERYDAY. Right now you can sleep whenever and you wake up 10 hours later and cannot sleep again until you've been awake for 12 hours since you slept. This is very frustrating when you try to sleep but can't because you slept at 02:00 the previous day and you sit there in the dark waiting for the option to sleep and its too dark and cold to do anything else... besides wait by your bed.... LOL
-Option in the menu to change day and night time cycles (I personally think the day goes by too fast)
-No animation when pulling out certain guns, but it makes sounds as if you racked the slide or something
-While playing the game your hands and arms are always skin no matter what you're wearing (not a big issue, but would be a nice touch)
-Option to get rid of the reticle (green dot) super annoying when trying to aim a rifle/option to get rid of green dot retcile when ADS
-Option to get rid of vehicle control menu when in a vehicle (I know how to drive the dam boat)
-You can access items like chests through walls you've built
-BUILDING needs some little work and it would be approximately 91.336% better... Floors should be able to snap to foundations (second story deck), stairs should snap together to make longer stairs, and walls should be able to snap to other walls. 
-Land animals would be the icing on the cake. Wolves, Bears, Deer, Rabbits, whatever. (Gives you hide and you can make leather from it)
-More aquatic animals Whales, killer whales (pack animal), barracuda, etc. (Right now there is only 3)
-Aquatic animals need to roam more (they roam in a small area and are predictable)
-Enemies on islands need to roam more and are usually in one spot of the island instead of spread out
-Underwater diving is very safe (the biggest threat is drowning) just feels like it needs more danger
-Solar panels bro trust me bro. Fuel is annoying to get and goes quickly. Solar panels can have a downside (Maybe they power 1 thing and are expensive to make or only power your things during the day or soak up the sun during the day and powers your things at night automatically like lights)
-Binoculars just zoom your screen in, you don't actually put the binoculars to your face and look through it
-Dismantle Bushes (Some bushes are in the way of building and show up through the floor)
-Items should not respawn if they are touching or close to a built structure like bushes, trees, barrels, dumpsters, etc
-HUGE one right here guys... Be able to build lots of things without having to put it on a foundation. Boom. Would make Building approximately 2037.81% better. I want my garden on the grass not on a metal foundation that's 3 feet above ground haha
-When looking at the spotlight while it's on you cant really tell it's on. There's not a light shining out of it, but rather the area it's looking at is lit up. This feature would just be a nice little touch and add to the realism
it's a fun game. not gonna lie I would really like to see other content creators to play this game.
at first, the game was fun but after about 3 hours some guy speaking Chinese joined and destroyed my whole world, and took all my loot
I'm (for now) disappointed. I'm a really big Raft fan and this is just.. so not what I was hoping for.

not to bad, there are still a few issues but the game seems to be coming along nicely.  
Pros: 
1) a lot of areas to explore and more are being added pretty regularly
2) a lot of variety of outfits,armor and weapons
3) crafting is reasonable, not overly tedious
4) plenty of resources (solo mode)
5) updates come regularly with fixes and additions
6) roadmap looks good and it seems they are right on track
7) I haven't experienced any performance issues, a few bugs and glitches but nothing serious
8) option to customize the game play
9) a lot of options for vehicles except for under water

Cons:
1) lacking in character customization, very few options
2) still needs some work on balance, in solo mode, you will get raided by enemies carrying guns and all you have is a sharp stick and you will be out numbered 5 to 1 (at the very least)
3)enemies (animal or human) have really high hit points, took 3 hits with a spear to kill a crab and if you happen to run into a shark while exploring, you can just expect to die, they are way faster than you are and the only underwater weapon you have is a stick with a butter knife attached to it (one bite took half my health)
4) not a lot of options for building, so all your structures will look the same, but there are a lot of decorations you can find or craft
5) there is one trade depot, 1 trader has basic stuff and another has Halloween items (seems kid of foolish to me), the basic items traders inventory never changes, its always the same items, so farther into the game the trader becomes useless.
6) underwater exploring is a great idea although the air tanks don't hold enough to last very long and you can't hold your breath for very long either, so underwater exploring is kind of a pain (it would be really cool if you could build some type of submarine)
7) hunger and thirst progresses to quickly, a normal person only needs to eat 2-3 times per day not every hour, I can understand thirst progressing quickly but not hunger
8) as with every survival game, resource storage is a problem for the amount of resources needed for crafting, it would be nice if they increased the storage capacity of storage containers

I feel like some or most of the cons will be addressed at some point in the future, so in my opinion this game is worth playing.
Like the game but they really need a TIME slider so we don't feel like this is a job. Some of us old folks like to take our time and not have to race our butts off each day.

I've played this game for 30 hrs, in offline and with friends. 
The game has a really good foundation for and early release. The gathering has a nice level of hardness that it's difficult enough to keep you busy, but easy enough that you could do it on your own. 
For combat I find a few tweaks could be made. Having a rile and being able to shoot enemies far away is nice, but if you want to shoot through something such as railing it won't let you. The shot gun for enemies is SO OP that it can be frustrating when you come across one in game. I shouldn't be one shot killed with a shotgun from across an island like a sniper rile. I think having a shorter range on the shotgun, or having a range damage control on it would be nice. The father away someone is that you shoot the less damage you do. 
Other than that all the guns feel really good, nice recoil, reload action etc.
Building can use some help. Not being able to place small items like a chest or a bed on the ground without a foundation is irritating. You are miles away from base, it becomes night, you want to build a fire to keep warm, just for the night? Nope you have top place a foundation... but you can't place that cause you don't own the island. You can claim the island, by building a flag, but in reality all you want is to build a fire to get through the night rather then going all the way back to home base. 
It would be nice when building a home base to having a snapping option. They have it for foundation and walls. If you place a painting on the wall or a chest on the floor and want to stack them it's really frustrating getting them aligned nicely. If you have OCD you will go insane in this game. So having an option to bounce between snapping and just placement would be nice as there are some things I would like to place without them snapping to random spot in the room. 
Swimming in game is really nice and smooth though swimming straight up from a dive should be faster then swimming up on a angle. 
It would be really nice to see more details added in the underwater world, which I see the developers have already started in their most recent update. The New Bi-oms look great and I can't wait to see more. I like that you can explore and 100% complete and area for treasure. The 100% slowly goes down as materials come back. This is a really nice feature as you can go back and collect materials needed again. 
Having a story or scavenger hunt for treasure would be nice. Such as finding maps in raiding Mutant or raiders bases that lead you to buried treasure or to the next part of the story line. To give the game more depth as of right now it's just survival and once you play for 10-15 hrs the game starts to die off as there is no real objective. 
Adding a whether system to the game would be amazing. Rain storms, tornadoes, hurricanes that can cause damage to plays not under cover and to the main base. During storms it could be more difficult to swim or drive the boats, use more stamina or gas etc. It would be good to have NPC or enemies affected by the storms as well such as seeking shelter or taking small amount of damage if exposed. 
Overall I really like this game. It is far enough away from Rust, Son of the Forest, 7 Days to die and Raft to really stand on it's own as a game. I can't wait to see where the developers take the game. Just because it's an early release I would give it a 7/10, with more updates and content release it could easily be a 10/10 game.

[h1]Title: A Diamond in the Rough[/h1]

[h2]Rating: 3/5[/h2]

Embarking on the journey into the Early Access realm, I delved into the promising yet perplexing world of "Sunkenland," a game that blends survival, crafting, and co-op elements. Despite its evident potential, the experience leaves players with a mixed bag of emotions, revealing a game that is still in dire need of refinement.

[h2]Graphics and World Design: 2/5[/h2]
Upon entering the sprawling open world, one cannot help but notice the glaring issues with asset implementation. It becomes apparent that many in-game elements are haphazardly copy-pasted, resulting in a lack of cohesion and immersion. The landscape often feels disjointed, with terrain and structures that seem out of place. However, the potential is there, and with some thoughtful restructuring, the game world could evolve into a visually stunning environment.

[h2]Gameplay Mechanics: 3/5[/h2]
The survival and crafting mechanics in "SurviveCraft Co-Op" form the game's core, providing a solid foundation for engaging gameplay. The cooperative aspect adds a layer of complexity and teamwork that, when executed properly, contributes to an enjoyable experience. Unfortunately, the current state of the game is plagued by clunky controls and unpolished interactions. Crafting often feels like a chore due to a lack of intuitive interfaces, and combat encounters lack the finesse needed for a truly immersive experience.

[h2]Potential and Concept: 4/5[/h2]
Beneath the surface, "SurviveCraft Co-Op" harbors a wealth of potential. The concept of an open-world survival game with a strong emphasis on cooperative play is intriguing and could set the stage for an outstanding gaming experience. If the developers invest time in refining the core mechanics, introducing unique features, and addressing the asset-related issues, the game could undoubtedly transform into a gem within the genre.

[h2]Communication and Developer Engagement: 3/5[/h2]
While the game is still in its Early Access stage, player feedback and developer engagement are crucial for improvement. The development team has shown some commitment to addressing community concerns, but there's room for improvement in terms of transparency and communication. Regular updates and a more interactive approach with the player base would go a long way in fostering a supportive community and ensuring the game's evolution in the right direction.

[h2]Conclusion:[/h2]
"SurviveCraft Co-Op" is a game with untapped potential, currently obscured by the shadows of unrefined mechanics and hastily implemented assets. The foundation for a captivating co-op survival experience is there, waiting to be unearthed through dedicated development efforts. While it may not be an instant hit in its current state, it's worth keeping an eye on as updates roll out and the game inches closer to its full potential. In the hands of a committed development team, this early access title could eventually shine as a true gem in the open-world survival genre. 

I will continue to check back on the game regularly and see what new updates / fixes that have been implemented, I look forward to seeing what the future brings but for right now I don't believe the price tag matches what is offered when you can pay the same price for a game that is more ''Polished''. Thank you to the development team for giving us all the opportunity to give feedback and hopefully all our suggestions are taken on board.

I guess that's it for now. Thanks for listening.

I'll post a  full review once I've played the game for several or more hours. At the moment I'm still finding my way around the game, so this review is more  a list of things  I've discovered so far and is  not a well written review.     

Graphics are  not  the latest, but as far as I'm concerned are decent enough to be called reasonable.  However, enemy models are  as yet sub standard, with little definition to them, however, I'm assuming the developer's will update these at some point.  

Initially,   farming for materials felt a little  tedious, however as I discovered more about the game; for example, being able to build  as many storage  boxes as  I needed,  I was able to store all the resources I found.  Once I'd built  the research  table I was then able to discover more items that I could build such as a repair station, weapons,  better  cooking stations etc,   then I was able to upgrade the  research station to level two which opened up a lot more items to research.  Once researched, and assuming  you had the materials it was  a simple matter of  accessing the item and  clicking the build button, then placing it in your camp.

Setting up a  coop server just for friends is easy, just  set a password so that it remains private.  

[b]Some do's and don't when you first start out:[/b]  

1) ... Do collect  food, wood, metal, rubber  and components.  This enables you to build your research station. 
2) ...Do build  walls and  other barriers to protect your camp. Enemies appear to attack these first before attacking   the other components of a camp  such as cooking stations etc. 
3) ... Make a basic weapon using wood.   
4) ... There are eight  slots that you can access using the  number 1 to 8 keys. These will place  whatever you choose into your hands.  
5) ... You can also  carry around 16 items in your backpack.  Any more items will be dropped as boxes that are labelled  with the component you've dropped e.g. wood planks, scrap metal etc.    
6) ... Before you build  your first research station build a fire and a stove so that you can warm yourself if you start to freeze (this will happen quickly at night, especially if you are in the water).  Freezing is indicated as  ice crystals that appear in the periphery of your vision) .
7) ... Build a cooking station  then cook  any food you  pick up.    Once cooked you can then  pick up and eat the food.
9) ... Build a bed as you can recover some health  by sleeping.  
10) ... Don't  Don't eat most food if not cooked as you may poison yourself e.g. raw mushrooms.  
11) ... Don't swim at night as you will freeze very quickly.  
12) ... Don't  visit  sites if they have  enemies on unless you have a weapon. If more than  two or three enemies, only attack when  you fist start to play the game  if you are playing cooperatively with friends.  Once you are able to create better armour and weapons it should be easier to play  solo.
13) ... Press M to access the world map.  Undiscovered sites will show as  question marks.  Once discovered  there is a percentage  discovered indication below each discovered site.
14) ... There are lots of  You Tube videos that   explain the various  things that you will need to know about the game.  Personally I prefer to discover for myself, so didn't access any of these, but I did check while writing this  initial review and found  quite a few that you may find useful before starting the game.

[b]Issues:[/b]  

When playing cooperatively with friends,  if you die; once you re-spawn, you may be invisible to your friends, but you will still be able to play cooperatively.  There are some odd glitches, for example, after attacking a island then leaving,  my friend appeared to remain on the island, but was actually sailing the dinghy we had built.    Once you've killed some enemies they still appear alive, but no longer attack you.  Eventually they do disappear.

[b]Suggestions to the developer:[/b] 

Extend the day as  the day length seemed rather short (IMO).  The storage shelves hold very little scrap compared to  the storage boxes, yet take up  at least  three or four  times the area of your camp.  Enable  the ability to move walls and other  components of the camp  more easily.

Our own Want-to-be-Water-World. A Sea of secret treasures, and loot galore, different factions of various skilled enemies to pillage and plunder, revenge killing parties, sharks, suffocation, starvation and dehydration are just a few ways to get a re-spawn. Whether it's creating your own sea shack or a massive Fortified Tower of Power, the crafting and decorating in this game will get you revisiting local POI's just to get more goodies. The feelings of dread, despair, excitement and regret will endure many many hours in this constantly updated adventure. Loving it so far and looking forward to where it's heading. Highly Recommend.

This game has great potential. If you're a fan of  7 Days to Die, you will be a fan of this game. It has a very similar feel, but not as much substance yet. I bought the game before the January 12 2024 patch and it was fun, but broken as hell. I had no issues running the game, but there were a lot of ways to dupe items, loot boxes, etc.. The latest patch fixed a lot of issues! 

PROS: 

Easy to learn. Its pretty straight forward. 
Graphically its solid and has calming music.
Melee and gun fights are surprisingly fun.
Lots of places to explore under water and on islands. 
Building system is simple and great!
Weapon crafting was pretty simple, but it appears they changed it and made it more like 7 Days to Die. Still good!


CONS:

Character creator is lacking haha. 

Inventory issues like accidentally hitting "Get All" from a loot box without enough room in your inventory, you drop everything you're carrying and collect the loot. Its really annoying. A simple warning would fix this. This was not fixed in Jan 12 patch.

Blueprints hanging on a wall (usually in enemy bases) if you look at the blueprints and accidentally click off, they disappear.

Vehicles are a little buggy. If you jump while coming out of the water while under your boat, the boat flies up in the air and sometimes disappears.

AI is trash for the most part. Just makes killing easier as it is now.

Characters don't have levels or attributes, skills, etc... this may come later.

OVERALL: I have 40+ hours in and I really enjoyed it. Devs seem responsive so this game will get better and better. It's worth early access price IMO.

This game is polarizing but I'll do my best to lay it out for any potential buyers.

tldr; Yes. Buy it. Now read below.

So first and foremost I think Sunkenland is worth it's 20$ price tag. I played with two others and got 33 hours at the time of writing this but there is little left to do other than resource hoard for future updates.
33hrs to me justifies 20$ especially because those 30 hours were not plagued with bugs or crashes like many early access titles are. 


The Good, The Bad, and the Ugly:

Sunkenland is almost like raft but more combat heavy and less cutesy on the graphics. Oh yeah and you have a stationary base/s. I enjoyed this concept more than raft. The looks of things having a heavily decay-from-water feel to it set a good tone for whatever the story may be  in the future though some of the textures were still ugly, Intentional or not.

The combat is decent. The gunplay can be fun under the right circumstances but there are a good bunch of guns with little difference between them. Shooting feels a little lifeless and unintuitive as the only attachment you are given is a "red dot" (which is pale green) has a huge circle which covers up any would-be target not to mention the ever present single dot reticle is also there but offset which obfuscates the shooting mechanic. My biggest gripe with combat besides whats mentioned above is that enemies frequently drop items of a much lower tier than they fought you with. Why are 9 dudes able to shoot with 7.62 but only drop slingshots? Enemy type and quantity is very limited and AI is bad. Running is also useless as you move slightly faster than a hobble. Maybe running shoes as an accessory/food should be added.

The map is large enough that you have a good amount to do and a bit to explore. The means of traveling is primarily handled with boats and their handling isn't too bad. The biggest problems with them are that when you upgrade from one tier of boat to the next it is a large amount of expensive materials for very little gain. +20kph and no storage upgrade. Yuck. If you do eventually find the gyrocopter, DO NOT USE IT. The controls are some of the worst i've ever seen for helicopters. This needs improved. It is worthless in its current state.

The UI is a little clunky and some things need a touch of love. Renaming a box can't be completed with [enter] and instead has to be clicked with mouse, drag and drop feature doesn't work with the merchant, frequent double clicking which messes up inventory management etc. Small things. Not game breaking. 

Buildables are not very good and like many other items have large invisible walls that extend past the item. Great for providing extra cover from fire, not so nice when you think you shot the enemy but somehow you missed even though your shot was a foot or two over their barrier. The snapping works well as does the item retrieval system.

Stability is good with no major framerate drops and only 2 disconnects during our 30hr sessions which is a strong plus. This added a lot of playability and is worth noting as optimization is usually something devs do last so kudos to Sunkenland here.

Music is boring and uninspired. There are only 2 or 3 tracks that get repetitive fast but you can turn them off.

I think there should be other things to do than just hoard resources and sandbox around. I'm thinking minigames, animals, etc. You know, those little things that distract you from the stuff you were supposed to get done. Yeah, those things.

Lastly, The merchant's barter system is okay. I don't love it but I don't hate it. It makes sense however their goods become woefully irrelevant after a few hours in. This seems to be an oversight. I'd like to see more valuable things locked behind her store's paywall. I also think the .50 should have been able to be boat mounted. That would really add some excitement. The electricity system is also very primitive. I am hoping it will be updated. Every wire run to power an appliance must be fed directly to the generator instead of using connectors or relays that can't be reconnected to. 

I hope the devs will continue to work on Sunkenland. I think they really have a good blueprint here for something special and it is in its most rough form now but it could be huge with some more love.

What is Sunkenland?  Well it's basically bits of Rust, Waterworld (yes, that Waterworld - the one with our buddy Kevin C. playing a dude with gills in their neck), Raft, and Subnautica all rolled into one.  Surprisingly good considering that it's not even at beta version 0.2 yet.  Sure, it has issues and it's rough around the edges but that's to be expected at this stage of the game.

Currently this game has base building, crafting, ships (several types), many crafting stations and storage options, base defense (even if you aren't home enemies may attack your base), underwater scavenging, fishing, farming, harvesting resources, attacking enemy strongholds, survival features including sleep (energy), food, water, and temperature based elements.

Definitely worth keeping an eye on if you like survival crafting games.

I bought this game on sale, knowing it was early access. I like the idea of the game. Diving into the ocean to salvage stuff, find treasure, craft stuff? Who wouldn't like that?
The game, as it is, does that pretty well. It's not awesome, but it's pretty good. Upon opening, the devs have placed a screen with a list of what is available in-game and what will eventually become available. That all sounds cool, but they need to take a serious look under the hood before they make more additions. 
The base game is far from polished. While it hasn't crashed yet, I've had my share of glitches. Tonight, when I relogged after a glitch, my entire base, including all the materials I'd collected, was just gone. There was an explanation on the screen, but I'm not a coder ... something about something being outside a parameter. 
Glitches like this usually make many of us rage quit, but I rebuilt again.
Then, after another hour, I kept getting a warning that my base was being attacked. But, I had 3 bases claimed, and it wouldn't tell me which base was being attacked. And, since I had half a day away from all three bases, I knew I wouldn't get back before the base was demolished. But, it kept warning me that my base was being attacked ... until I found which base was being attacked and killed the attackers. 
Stuff like that makes me wonder if any of these devs have even played their own game. If my base is being attacked, and I have more than one, PLEASE TELL ME WHICH ONE IS BEING ATTACKED.
So, then I had to rebuild everything a second time tonight.
All that being said, I only recommend the game if you get it on sale and if you can tolerate some glitches for a pretty cool concept.

This game has amazing potential and is in a playable condition. It is lacking in endgame replay value and has a long way to go in terms of development. Will definitely be playing updates as they are released, but not in between them.
