Absolutely loving this so far. I was hesitant at first because I though it was going to be similar to Raft (I like Raft somewhat but it's not something I'm crazy about). Sunkenland is Raft in someways but so so much better. A lot more action and a lot better exploration. 
To move away from other game comparison, overall Sunkenland has been a lot of fun. A lot of places to explore, just enough challenge to keep it interesting and over all while is does have some overall "crafting survival same-ness too, I find myself enjoying every time I play.

It's a new game, so there is definitely room for improvement, but overall I am loving the game play. This is what fallout 4 should have been. Incredibly impressive from such a small company. I was expecting just another basic survival game, but it has exceeded every expectation. It's challenge without being so hard I get frustrated. Items are findable, enemies are scary, but combat-able. I always find myself with a new mission or goal. Great game- I highly recommend it.

It will probably be even better once it's finished and ready to be fully released... provided Vector3 doesn't do what a lot of games are doing these days and letting the game sit in "Early Access" status for years on end.

One thing I would like to see them do is give a better explanation of what some of the items actually do. I may have overlooked it, but I didn't really see a tutorial system, which would be nice for players just getting into the game. However, for anyone that's played any other survival crafting games, it should have a reasonably low learning curve.

[i]SIDE NOTE:[/i] I had to turn the mouse look and panning rate down to 50 (was originally at 200) to make the movement and looking around a little smoother and less twitchy.

Sunkenland - A Promising Dive into the Apocalypse

Sunkenland, in its early release, offers a tantalizing glimpse into a post-apocalyptic world submerged beneath the waves, where survival demands exploration, base building, and strategic defense. While the current feature set may still be in the developmental stages, it's evident that Sunkenland is on the path to becoming an exceptional game.

Exciting Exploration:
Dive into the depths of Sunkenland's underwater world, exploring sunken skyscrapers, nuclear power plants, and mysterious subway tunnels. The game introduces a captivating diving mechanic, encouraging players to gather resources, discover lost technologies, and collect rare pre-apocalypse items. As the developers expand on this concept, the potential for immersive exploration seems boundless.

Dynamic Base Building:
Sunkenland empowers players to build their bases in diverse locations, be it a water stronghold, a repurposed ship, or an island penthouse. The modular building system allows for creative freedom in designing enclaves, which, as the game evolves, promises to add depth and personalization to the player's survival experience.

Challenging Base Defense:
Defending against pirates and mutants adds a layer of strategic complexity. The current inclusion of high walls, barbed wire, traps, surveillance systems, and artillery showcases the potential for evolving base defense mechanics, promising exciting challenges for players as they strive to protect their territories.

Crafting and Survival:
Sunkenland introduces a crafting system that allows players to build a variety of items, from tools and weapons to vehicles like jetskis and helicopters. Gathering food, hunting sharks, growing plants, and managing supplies contribute to the game's survival aspect, encouraging players to make their bases sustainable in the resource-scarce environment.

Versatile Vehicles and Combat:
The inclusion of vehicles such as sailboats, jetskis, and gyrocopters amplifies the exploration experience. The promise of vehicle upgrades hints at an evolving transportation system. The game's combat, whether against mutants, pirates, or enemy atolls, showcases a diverse range of weapons and strategies, paving the way for thrilling confrontations on both sea and land.

Innovative Trading and Cooperative Play:
Sunkenland embraces a unique trading system, relying on item exchange rather than a universal currency. The cooperative multiplayer feature allows players to team up with friends, building bases, diving, exploring, and fighting pirates together. The potential for collaborative survival in this oceanic apocalypse hints at a promising cooperative experience.

While Sunkenland's current features are in the early stages, it's clear that the game holds immense potential. As the developers continue to refine and expand upon its unique mechanics, Sunkenland has the makings of a standout title in the survival and exploration genre, offering a thrilling underwater adventure for players seeking a blend of creativity, strategy, and cooperative play.

I want to say this game has potential.  Right now it lacks in content but also doesn't have any real game breaking bugs like most games on the market.  I do find it funny you can hop off your sailboat mid movement and launch it directly in the air.  

The only tough part is getting started because the AI has aimbot.  Pitch black and they are zeroed on landing shots from 100 meters out.  Also be aware of the AI with long spears because they can shank you through the wall (however you can do the same to them by using a spear through the walls/floor)  

Multiple items don't have descriptions, some have such a long description that the text runs off and you can't even read it.  Other items have duplicated text such as the description for the sailboat is duplicated for the description for the speedboat.  

The visual of the game is beautiful, and runs smoothly.  The idea behind the game seems fun. It gives you a bit of a rust feeling but in a Waterworld aspect of things.  As long as the devs stay true to updating the game and adding content it can be a decent game to pick up.

This is my first game I've ever reviewed and it's for a good reason. I've been playing survival games a whole lot throughout my life. It's one of my most favorite genres out there. I've gone through Stranded Deep, Rust, Don't Starve, Raft and everything in between. I could go on and on about why I like these particular types of games, but I'm leaving this review for one reason.

This game has promise. Is it flawless in it's early access state? Well, no. That's obvious, but if these developers know what to do with this game, it could be big. How big determines how much they want think outside of the box. The basic premise is great. Stranded on an island, build a base, harvest resources, the same old same old, but that's where any early access games aims for.

First, the pros:
-Resource gathering not only above water, but below is really refreshing.
-Random AI attacks can break up the mundanity of building, collect, building, collect, building, collect. 
-Factions in the game, although barebonesy at the moment, are a great platform for future ideas the developers might have with it.
-Researching items feels fulfilling when you finally unlock the broken gun you found at the bottom of the ocean because you were searching for that one resource for the past 5 islands.
-Firefights are as good as you would expect from a early access game.
-Naked women neon lights you can find at the bottom of the ocean in a collapsed building. 'Nuff said. 

And, of course, the cons:
-Crashes. I've only been playing for 14 hours and got 3 of them.
-The building aspect leaves MUCH to be desired. Half the of the time your crafting benches clip through the walls and other items equally.
-Melee combat is unrefined and the enemy can get some easy cheap shots on you.
-When you die, you don't lose all your clothing/items. You spawn with all your hotbar items and clothes you died with. Not sure if this is a full con, but my Rust experience made me so confused when I found that out.
-Sharks. Fucking sharks.

In conclusion, I know I could've gone into more, but hopefully this will be good enough for you to determine if your 20 bucks will be well spent. I'm having a great time so far. Sure, I'll probably hit the wall where I have everything researched and I have all the resources I could possibly want, but for the time being, this was definitely worth my money. Also, I would feel like a dick if I didn't mention, I only played this on single player. So, to anyone courageous enough to do multiplayer, I don't have any information for you. Just...good luck.

I love it!!!! cant wait to play more, such a good game, got a couple of bugs but i like the direction its going!

Things that I like 
- building a base is fast paced, no crafting time, no weight (only limited by inventory slots)
- storage is varied, there are ammo box, fridge, food container, metal chest, wooden chest, safebox, shelf, etc, etc. So that alone works as a decor.
- storage can be put on top on other storage so we can use vertical space and organize better, it also has naming that's directly seen when facing it. 
- light source has decent range and it does not need maintenance, it's lit forever.


Things that I hate :
- time is too fast,
- not only time is too fast but it is also limiting sea exploration with cold because diving at night will catch cold, 
- the game has so many decors with many many different 3d objects and furnitures, but when an item is dropped it shows a BOX. Imo dropped items should show its original 3d model with added text for how many of it was dropped, not boxes.
- can't sleep on boat to skip night, so I have to prepare to go in the morning to get full time exploring the sea getting stuffs. 
(These 3 problems are related to the point it's annoying to go explore at random time.)
- open/close door is sometimes hard when there are other interactable items nearby such as storage.
- night time is too dark, I always hate darkness in a game if it does not have any game mechanic ties to it, ppl usually combat this with gamma or monitor brightness, WHY should players be tortured with that, just use a different style to portray night, like bluish tint or smth. No matter how a game tries to be realistic, it is still a game, we still need to see to play the game. The game has decent light source though, it gives enough illumination for the surrounding but NOT when at sea where I will spend most of the game time. I dont mind darkness as long as the game has good lighting, which the game has, but partially, dunno if later I can have light source at sea, but why not make it available early.
- sleeping 10h is too long, and the 14h delay for the next sleep sounds like it will mess up the sleep cycle. Imo we should be allowed to sleep at any time with custom duration.
- the game can be played without sleeping if I have tons of food (maybe at endgame), so maybe add penalty starting for 3days without sleep, decrease maxhp and maxstamina, add more penalty if not sleep for 7 days. That should force sleep.

Sometimes I need to do stuffs at base, cooking food, filling water, defending base, etc, then when I want to go to explore the sea, it's already noon or evening so I dont have full time for exploring the sea. Maybe :
- Remove the cold, it does nothing and blocking gameplay exploring the sea
- let me customize the day length
- add sleep on boat to skip time.

The concept of this game is extremely cool and unique, but the execution leaves a lot to be desired. My only serious complaint is the building. Its wonky, broken, and extremely frustrating. Probably the WORST building of any survival game I have ever played. You never know which way a wall is facing, because it looks the same, and seems to automatically orient itself the wrong way. Its also very difficult to remove placed items, especially early on, making construction an absolute nightmare. Also the snapping will just randomly not work, leaving you with pieces of roofing missing, since the game will not allow you to snap random pieces into place.

I wouldn't mind the building being this broken and unpleasant if it weren't such a fundamental part of Sunkenland. Construction is an extremely important part of the game, as it is necessary to survive, but it feels as if it is just a necessity to get through in order to enjoy the rest of the game. I usually enjoy building, but in this game, expanding/modifying bases is basically hell. Otherwise, it is a very interesting game, and has A LOT of potential. If they fix this crucial piece of gameplay, then this title could be a major success. It is early access, and I understand that, but I cannot give it a good review until they fix this. As soon as the building is improved, I will change my review and recommend the game.

I've played this game for 20+ hours now and it's really great. It takes elements from Rust, Raft and Stranded and puts it all together in a stranded survival type of game.

There's currently quite a few bugs, but nothing game breaking. The potential with this game is huge and I hope the developers are dedicated to fixing and improving the game.

This game has a lot of the foundations for a great game. Crafting, survival, coop, enemy raids, base building, the graphics are nice. But the issues it has currently are annoying enough to effect the QOL. 

Theres a lot of small things such as:
-Seeing different loot in an enemy storage chest than your friends, 
-Traders always have the same thing for sale every day
-Swimming faster than sharks you can run laps around them stabbing them theres no real aquatic threats. 
-When I unlocked items reliant on power, at least for me it was not very clear how to power them.

Then there are two bigger issues
Inventory Management
- Trying to bind E to "Use" instead of the default F causes you to dump everything inside a chest when you press E to close the chest because rather then close an open Chest, E is also bound to "Take everything from chest" instead of something more common like "R" or just a take all button. Me and my friend were constantly pressing E to open a chest, placing a few things into  it, then instinctively pressing E to close it and the entire contents of the chest would fill our inventory and the remainer spill onto the floor. 
- Theres a lot of storage/inventory QOL improvements to be made. I want to be able to split items inside a chest, or take only 1/2 of a stack from a chest. It would be nice to have the ability to send similar loot to a chest, or in proximity be able to send your loot to nearby chests that contain that loot like in Necesse. Its great that theres tons of different items in this game, but i often find myself placing the same thing in different chests either because the storage space is too small, or the stack size is way too small, or i didnt realize it was in another chest because I have 10 chests im  trying to keep organized. Having automatic storage sorting QOL improvements would help manage the loot. 

Enemy AI
-My biggest complaint is the Enemy AI. Oh my god if they fixed only one thing it should be the AI. They See you through everything, snap to your position and fire with precision, dont reload, say anything or try anything creative. They generally dont react to their buddies getting into fire fights. But once they do know you are there they aim at your direction pacing left and right waiting for you to pop your head out so they can shoot before you can flinch. 

Why am I going out to loot places to the goods back to my base if bringing the stuff back is a nightmare? Why raid bases, build base defenses to be raided, If enemy AI is either brain dead with fists/spears or insufferably over powered with rapid fire guns? This game is fun, I am still having fun. I dont think in its current state its worth 20 bucks.. I know its early access but I think there needs to be a good amount of focus on AI/Storage UI. The coop was good, something people don't always get right and is often buggy. So Kudos on that. I look forward to updates as the game progresses through early access and would be happy to revisit.

Bad right now. I had fun but there's a lot of things broken. There's not a lot of world there so far. There are also serious issues such as spawning in a thousand meters from your base even though you just saved there. A lot of the UI and build system is clunky. The AI is brain dead but also spawns in with guns so they can easily overpower you...but they spawn in the water and have to swim to your base so it's really more of a chore to deal with...and you'll have to deal with it because raids come in regularly and are both underwhelming and overly annoying to deal with. You don't get anything really for beating them and they destroy your base so you have to repair it---which is also a janky mechanic right now because things can get in the way of repairing what you actually want to repair. Let's see...what else...the underwater exploration to find salvage was incredibly simple and under developed. If that doesn't get an overhaul then don't buy this game. It's a game about the world being covered in water and you have less space to explore then Seven Day s and less variety somehow. Kick it up a notch

Fun Solo but mostly Co-Op title in the alpha stage currently, For what it is right now its fun, crafting, building, surviving, but in the water and on islands, diving deep down to scavenge materials for crafting and taking over islands from enemy clans.

This game could be a very good game IF the developers would address current issues. From walls that enemies can shoot through to boats being sent to outer space when exiting the driver seat. The developers seem keen on adding new content rather than fixing the existing issues at hand. 

Examples:
- Iron sights and "red dot sights" are incredibly inaccurate, you actually have to rely on a tiny green dot above your gun to aim and it is even slightly off.
- as addressed above, boats tend to glitch out and either get stuck on debris or glitch out and launch themselves.
- enemies are clueless when raiding their island until they spot you and light you up through walls that should be impossible to shoot through.
- a lot of useless research for a single item that only has one use
- extremely low oxygen when diving and requires multiple scuba tanks.
- only one generator size that can only power a battery station rather than multiple items
- hunger and dehydration when waking up and most food and water don't even hydrate or feed the player that much so you're constantly looking for food.
-healing items aren't all that easy to come by and even the trader only has 10 pill bottles that go rather quick

These are just some of the gripes I have about this game, and I love the game. I wouldn't recommend the game unless you're fine with a bugged out game that will hopefully be fixed along with eventually adding in new content. But the next update has been coming for awhile and so far it doesn't seem like the update is addressing current bug fixes.

In the hour we played, we had three different times where someone would join and grief us. One joined, grabbed a bunch of wood and built random walls around. If the game didn't allow constant griefers, it would probably be pretty fun.

Ah yes, the Unity 3 game world. Like an old version of Stranded Deep with zombies. Looting sunken buildings is fun, but combat is just frustrating "swing and hope", with red splashes in your face, then respawn and retrieve your stuff, over and over. The survival elements are a drag and unbalanced. Nobody IRL starves to death or dies of dehydration in one day, especially if you've eaten and drank that same day. You spend most of your time trying to keep your vitals topped off with little time to explore. I want to like it, but it's a slog, and the assets are laughably outdated. I'm not sure why so many would-be devs release games so early. It's always the same story. They build and build and add and add, then comes the engine update before the game is halfway thru. Just stop this early alpha nonsense, already, and don't release games until they're real and playable. And then I find myself leaving the same review comment, "I'll check back on this game in a couple years."

Sunkenland is for sure one of the mid tier early access games I've played. In order for this to be top tier the combat needs a heavy overhaul, melee and ranged both. There needs to be more sea life, majority of this game is scavenging the sea for materials and rare items. As of right now, the only sea life that you can interact with is Marlin, Sea Turtles and two different sharks. The other fish are caught with a fishing rod and/or traps.

UPDATED REVIEW after 30 hours
The game improves as you progress. Adjusting server settings to decrease the number of enemies during island battles and disabling persistent raids on your base enhances the experience. This customization allows for more exploration, leading to the discovery of additional materials like gun parts and iron. Iron becomes crucial for upgrading craft tables, armor, and weapons. Eventually, producing steel becomes a game-changer. Building a solid base and having fun is possible, but after around 30 hours, it may feel like you've exhausted most content. Although you can still collect materials and enhance your base, claiming islands with a flag seems to halt enemy respawns. In summary, the game becomes more enjoyable over time, especially when playing with friends, providing approximately 25-30 hours of gameplay.


INITIAL REVIEW AFTER 3 hours
The game shows promise initially, but after investing 6 hours, I found it to be somewhat frustrating. There's a considerable amount of grinding with minimal rewards. Upgrading the crafting station to the next level triggers relentless attacks on your bases, making it challenging since you repeatedly spawn back in the base. Sharks pose a significant threat, causing you to lose all your belongings, and they appear to navigate through walls in structures. Wood, a crucial resource, is surprisingly scarce compared to other materials. Weapons feel underpowered, and multiplayer experiences glitches, with players getting stuck within walls. While crafting has potential, the enjoyment diminishes after upgrading the crafting station, turning into a monotonous grind for minimal gains. The lack of customization options for difficulty levels, FPS settings, and character features is a downside. In conclusion, I would advise against purchasing the game at this time. It's better to wait and see if the developers address and fix these issues in the future. If not for the 6-hour gameplay limit on refund requests, I would have considered seeking a refund.

I cant in good conscience recommend this game. Its very very rough, very slow, very dull. It feels almost like the early access is the first weekend the devs worked on the game. Interesting concept but really really early in its lifecycle to release or charge for.
This game reminds me of Ark in some ways, and Raft. I like the scenery especially under the ocean.

So far, so good. I'm shocked at how good this game is with how new it is, and I've only played it for so long, but wow. If this is early access, I can't wait to see where it goes. 

The survival is pretty easy, to the point where I haven't bothered upgrading my food or water supply, and if I'm being honest, there is nothing particularly spectacular about the combat or the rest of the gameplay, and that's no fault of the game, as these days nothing is original. However, all of these elements come together to create something that's unique, and I love that. The enemy factions help you not feel so alone, and it can help put some pressure on you too, but not as much pressure as more hardcore survival games.
Even if all of that sounds too easy or too hard, you can tailor the difficulty to create a comfortably challenging experience just for you. 

The only complaint I really have is the sound design, and it's not the use of stock sounds that bothers me. It's the fact that the sound engine is just, god awful. Traders voices will overlap, an enemy on the other side of the island will sound like he's 5 feet away, you hear the same 3 splashes on a loop when sailing across the seas. I have nothing against stock sounds, but I'd appreciate a bit of variety and more effects than just the underwater effect, because the whole game sounds like it's taking place in a recording studio.

All in all, I rate this a 9/10, I can get over the sound design because the game itself is awesome and feels like a breath of fresh air.

Dear Vector3 Studios

I hope this message finds you well. I wanted to share some insights and feedback regarding the gameplay experience in your recent release. While I thoroughly enjoyed the initial days of gameplay, I've observed some areas that could benefit from improvement.

Firstly, the combat dynamics need attention. At long range, the bots exhibit inadequate combat skills, often failing to engage effectively. Conversely, at close range, there appears to be an issue with the bots using aimbot capabilities through obstacles such as trees and bushes, resulting in a lack of visibility for the player. Additionally, I've encountered instances where bots attempted to shoot through walls, undermining the overall gaming experience.

Furthermore, there is a notable absence of diverse traps within the game. As a player who enjoys constructing bases for self-defense, I believe the inclusion of more trap options would enhance the strategic aspects of the gameplay, especially in anticipation of potential player versus player (PvP) elements.

On a related note, I would like to express some concerns about the helicopter controls. The current setup seems unconventional and challenging to navigate. I suggest a more intuitive control scheme, such as assigning roll to AWSD, left and right direction control to mouse movement, and using left and right clicks for ascend and descend functions. Alternatively, providing customizable keybinds for helicopter controls would offer players the flexibility to tailor the controls to their preferences.

I appreciate your dedication to delivering an exceptional gaming experience, and I believe addressing these concerns would contribute significantly to enhancing overall player satisfaction. Thank you for your attention to these matters, and I look forward to witnessing further improvements in future updates.

Best regards, SLoPAH.

I got this game on a whim, "why not" I thought. 15€. Must be cool. Boy was I wrong.

We gamers are spoiled. We get the most awesome products for the cheapest prices. Therefor it becomes extra clear when you have a product, clearly unfinished, and clearly in a very rough playable state with no mechanics, graphics or content that warrants the current price for it. 

Thats what Sunkenland is at its current state. Rough, very buggy, unfriendly UI and dito mechanics and very little, very quickly repetitive content that warrants no further appeal to play. the gameworld, while graphics look more than okay, is bland, janky and repeats itself with assets that do not invite me to look further than I already have.

I also cannot see how the developers are going to "fix" this within a decent timeframe. This seems to be made by a team of 7, while there are plenty of other examples of smaller teams delivering a more finished product which costs a whole lot less, with loads more content and/or mechanics to enjoy. I just do not see it happening, but I do hope the devs will prove me wrong in time.

For an early access game, Sunkenland did extremely well. The gameplay loop feels rewarding, and the gameplay systems make sense. The game offers a fun survival challenge without making it tedious.

That aside, there are some flaws with the current iteration of the game:
1. the combat isn't smooth, mainly with the handling of the guns and the way the red dot sight is implemented. There are two dots on my screen when I aim down sight and only one of them is accurate, this resulted in so many missed bullets.
2. The fact that I have to spend 5 minutes after a raid going around my base repairing every piece of structure is not fun. Repairing is too tiresome and tedious as it is right now, especially when enemies seem to have infinite ammo.
3. Though this isn't strictly a flaw, the game could benefit from more AFK resource farms that could gather stuff like scrap metal, wood, cloth etc.

The game is in a good state now, and it seems that the developers are continuing to push fixes and new features. I finished my first playthrough with a friend, and look forward to coming back to the game in a few months and experience all the new features.

Fun game overall and a solid addition to my list of survival games. I'd consider it to be most similar to Stranded Deep, with less focus on overall survival mechanisms and more combat.  The coop was pretty solid with only a few minor hiccups. I use a private server to avoid unwanted guests.  The combat is decent but I'm interested to see the next release which promises some updates in that area. Guns are cool and feel solid, but the enemies will often stand around until engaged. Once engaged they will take cover and move around, so the AI is not too bad. They are also not aim-bots which is nice; just don't get surrounded. I also like the base attacks. This is missing or badly done in most games. 7 days to die is one of the few survival games with decent tower defense. This game certainly doesn't compete with 7 days in that regards but overall I like the random attacks and they add a challenge/threat without the enemy easily ripping your base to pieces. Overall crafting system is good and there's a decent amount of content. I got this on the holiday sale and it was well worth the money, but I would still have been satisfied if I'd paid full price.

Things I'd like to see (I know a big update is on the way, so maybe it will address some of these):
1) Underwater play needs some tweaks. There's isn't enough underwater threat, as there are only a few sharks and they really aren't hard to take out if you have the appropriate level spear - you can also cheese kill them from the surface.
  - I'd slow swimming speed down (maybe 30%)
  - Reduce lighting in the deeper areas
  - Increase overall oxygen slightly to compensate (maybe 20%
  - Quadruple the time a headlight lasts on a single battery; headlamp is completely useless as is - flares are way better.
  - Double or triple the time the underwater scooter lasts on a battery, although unlike the headlamp its still quite useful as is.
  - Add more aggressive marine life and more ways to defend yourself from them. Sharks are relatively easy to kill but fighting them is just trading blows as you don't appear to be able to dodge them or interrupt their attacks by timing your hit.
  - The idea is to make deep water dives dangerous and scary, but not tedious if you have the proper gear. Rewards should also be greater for deeper dives to make it worth the effort. The swim food is great and I like that it makes such a difference you want to make it and use it.

2) Storage improvements. Overall storage isn't bad and in general survival games range from tedious to unplayable at default storage settings, which is why all the top survival games support mods - so no-one has to use the developer's settings. Comparably Sunkenland is pretty good but still needs some improvements.
  - Scrap metal should be stackable to 50. You need to keep enough around to expand or move to a new base, so you can't dump it, but it takes way too much space.
  - Return half as much coal from furnaces and cooking. The stack size if fine, but you just don't need the amount returned. It's dump-able at least, but that just tedious.
  - Special decoration items should be found at 1/2 to 1/3 the rate. I have 5 of all the common decorations in a single play-through with absolutely no looting areas more than once. I sold so many items I have an entire chest of silver coins and nothing to spend them on, but at least "sell" items are stackable.
  - In general I'd say double the stack size of items like cloth, glass, ore, rubber, ...
  - Vehicles need to have upgradable storage and larger boats should have 2 storage containers. The helicopter should really have 2, as it's otherwise useless given that the time it takes to land negates any speed advantage, so why would you use it. You could also make it easier to fly, but generally I can control the helicopter even through controlling the tilt with a mouse is really not ideal.

3) Random map generation: 
  - Implement a socket system, like Stranded Deep, where there are only so many areas predefined and you simply plug them into a socketable grid. POIs would need to be flagged with a difficulty rating and underwater vs land so the socket algorithm could place them suitably, but the process is otherwise pretty straight forward. It doesn't really generate anything, but rather places POIs differently and can choose a preset amount from a list 2 or 3 times the size so the end result may have different POIs from a previous and all in different positions.

4) Floating driveable base:
  - I love games where you can build and expand a base and move it with you as you explore. This really isn't done anywhere except in Raft, but its the entire promise of the game, and Ark.
  - Obviously a big ask, but would be a great feature.

Overall I think the developers have done a great job. Developing a game is not easy, but what they have is already worthy of being on the shortlist of good survival games and I can't wait to see where it goes from here.

Pro: A great start in early access, it has a ton of potential even with a long way to go content wise. That said, what is already in the game is fun and pretty addictive, I'm really enjoying the diving & looting loop. If you like Raft and/or Valheim, you'll like this.

Con: As with many other Unity based survival games, once you build a half-decent base (i.e. with more than a few models/items) the frames per second drops a lot. It went from over 100 fps to 40-59fps very quickly on my 3080, regardless of graphic settings. It is only alpha early access though so hopefully this can be addressed in future updates but it does worry me, as so many unity games suffer the same issue.

Good game but with some issues.

First, Negative

1. I swear bots have some kind of advantage because they can shoot through trees

2. Movement underwater is so unbalanced. I made a guide that shows you how to be faster than all boats with items the game intended for you to use.

3. The Price is a little big for the state it is in now, maybe it can be cheaper while in early access?

Now, Positive

1. The Crafting/Research System, while short is very fun to grind for, except steel ingots, which are a pain with one furnace but otherwise is not that bad.

2. The combat is fun and a little broken, but the game is in early access so I give that a pass

3. Trading is pretty cool and fun.

Overall, could become i nice rust raft mix that could do great for years to come when released.

Extra Notes:
If you're wondering why I didn't mention servers, well I will here. First, as long as you aren't looking for random people to play with, you should be fine setting the max players to the amount you are planning on playing with. (Ex. I wanna play with my friend so i set it to 2 so only we play.) I've never seen hackers get in my worlds when doing this, so I'm sure you won't have any issues when doing this. Also, THIS GAME IS NOT A RIPOFF OF RAFT OR RUST IT JUST TAKES SOME FEATURES FROM THE TWO TO MAKE AN UNIQUE EXPERIENCE! Whew, sorry, I just had to let that out.

I'd recommend you play with at least 1 friend but single player is still pretty fun.
Choose wisely but I would recommend getting it if you have the money.
Have Fun!

[h2] Yet another mediocre early access survival game [/h2]

Review subject to change upon future development changes. The dev team is also small and pushed this out in a short time so I will try to not to be too harsh with this review, especially early on..

That said, here's what I got after finishing this in about 15 hours --

- Lack of any real substance after 10-15 hours of play time. Once you wipe out the islands of AI enemies there's nothing left to do but sit around and watch the ocean and just survive.

- Interesting water world concept and potential to add some really cool things in the future such as subs, naval combat, piracy, etc.

- Has good bones to build on for the future and make really awesome improvements if it doesn't get abandoned.

- UI needs work as well as sorting options to be more fleshed out with QoL adjustments such as simple things like transfer of items that match from your inventory to a container you have open.

- Too many useless items like clothes that don't do anything for your stamina or ability to not freeze.

- Map is too small and has no procedural generation to keep things fresh for future runs.

- No weather, nor seasons. No ability to warm outside of a fire, as previously mentioned the clothes are pointless beyond armor.

- Missed opportunity to take advantage of this world concept and have subs, better scuba tanks, wet suits, underwater base building or secrets under the water beyond the POI ones.

- AI is clumsy and makes firefights a complete mess. AI also raids your base in a really uninspired way, as they simply just appear on your island with nothing to make it even seem remotely realistic. 

- Guns need a lot of work for not only recoil but scopes and just better combat in general.

- Building is lackluster and needs more flexibility on build options. Though there is a good amount of cosmetic items, a lot of them are oddly just Halloween inspired, unsure why this is..

There is a lot of work to do and right now feels a lot like a side project a group of buddies put together. Hoping and optimistic in the future this changes. For now if you just want something short lived and casual then it's worth about $10-15 during a sale. The price tag currently doesn't justify my personal rule of dollars to hours spent finishing the game. If the hours spent are less than how much I bought it, it's not worth the cost.

[b] Final review score - 6/10 [/b]
If you want a short lived casual survival game then this is for you. If you want something you can sink a lot of time into and enjoy returning to this world for future adventures with friends, you will be very disappointed.

You can see that this game is still in Early Access,
But the sheer potential you can see in it is outstanding,

Graphically it is good, and the enemy AI is alright (damn slavers hiding in cover and peeking out to take potshots at me.
I really like the environment you explore, and the current variety is solid in terms of bases and underwater ruins.
Knowing that they are actually continuing with improving and expanding is great.

There are certainly several things I'd like to see in the future, such as more friendly NPCs and, the ability to build on outposts/settlements you clear and claim (not just build on platforms you create).
Expanding the building to include some form of solar/biogas creation, and the ability to 'name' beds (dying and have 4 different 'simple beds' becomes a roulette of 'guess which is a satellite base and which is your home base that is on the other side of the map from where you are)
I would LOVE to be able to improve storage on vehicles because I am a filthy hoarder who snags everything not nailed down (and sometimes tries on things that are)

What the creators have now is enjoyable, and their notes have given me much hope for what will come.
Keep up the good work guys

I wanted to NOT recommend this game. My reasons are:
1. It's an old unimaginative trope.
2. Very much a work in progress.
3. The NPCs that attack your base will always have better gear and never drop anything. 
Reason three is the reason is why I recommended this game. Normally NPCs are a joke, easily handled by the player. But Sunkenlands devs must have known this and their NPCs will always have better guns , armor, and come in large numbers. I don't consider myself a pro-gamer. I'm just a grampa that likes to play games. So I'm average in my age group, below average against younger gamers. The NPCs will destroy your base, even my reinforced metal walls didn't hold up. Maybe if I had friends to play co-op I could have made it longer. But I'm proud I made it 45 days playing solo on my first try.  The base is still there but (I think) but the evening attacks just before bed have taken a toll on me.

I'm loving this game and am really looking forward to the updates and improvements that will be coming down the pipeline. There's a lot of room for different play styles and I really like the overall feeling of the game. I'm particularly enjoying the raiding and pillaging of mutant and marauder bases. Feels kind of like Sea of Thieves meets 7D2D. I also feel like the learning curve to this game isn't as steep as some others, which is in some ways refreshing. It's a little more forgiving and you're not thrown to the wolves right off the bat.

As for bugs and other issues, this game seems to be really solid. I haven't had any crashes or issues with kicking or latency in multiplayer. The only issue that I have seen (when I'm hosting a game) is that when my friend is using a boat (sailboat in this case) he cannot exit the boat while I'm in my inventory or a chest, otherwise it will teleport him all the way back to wherever he was when I opened my inventory or the chest. Not a big issue, since he'll just check to make sure I'm not in my inventory or chest when he tries to exit the boat.

One last item I'd like to see improved in a future release would be for the cursor on the map to move in real time when you are a passenger on a boat. This would make navigation quite a bit easier when you are trying to guide your teammate to a specific location. 

TLDR: Awesome survival game that doesn't slaughter you right off the bat. Would highly recommend!

Oh boy, where do I even begin with this game? It was like sailing through a stormy sea of confusion and disappointment. I mean, seriously, who knew that arguing about space in an open-world ocean game would become such a big deal?

At first, I was thrilled to dive into this supposedly epic adventure. The promise of exploring islands, discovering hidden treasures, and sailing the vast ocean had me hooked. But alas, my dreams were shattered faster than a shipwreck hitting a coral reef.

The moment I set sail, I noticed something was off. The islands seemed to be floating in some sort of distorted space-time continuum. I mean, come on, I'm all for a little creative liberty, but this was just too much. It felt like I was navigating through a twisted Salvador Dali painting rather than a coherent game world.

And then the arguments began. The community was divided into factions, each passionately defending their theories about the spatial anomalies. It was like a never-ending debate club, but with less logic and more frustration. I found myself caught in the crossfire, trying to make sense of it all.

Eventually, the developers decided to throw in the towel and issued refunds to everyone. I guess they realized that arguing about space in an ocean game was a lost cause. But hey, at least they admitted their mistake and tried to make things right.

In the end, this game left me feeling seasick, not from the rolling waves, but from the endless arguments and disappointment. If you're looking for a smooth sailing experience, I suggest you steer clear of this one. Save your sanity and find a game where the only thing you argue about is who gets the last slice of virtual pizza.

Rating: ⭐⭐ (Two out of five stars)

If you like Subnautica, Rust, 7DTD, and Raft. This is literally the perfect game for you. Please just know that it is in early access, and for only being out a few months, It's definitely worth waiting to see what the devs have to offer. Crafting, raids, exploring, building, It's all here! I have been hooked on this game, waiting for the opportunity to actually play it for myself, as well as support the devs in doing so ;) 

A few things I would like to point out are the heap amount of bugs with the water and boats, all of them seem to love flying across the map if you jump out and end up under them, its super odd and happens very very rarely. Another thing is when you have buildings in the water, the boats (mainly sail boat) will glitch under the foundations and will never sail again :'( When it comes to exploring, the sharks do not care about physics and go right through buildings, so be careful when exploring the school because I about died in there.

Trading; I would like to see more items being offered by the trader instead of what is offered. Maybe it does that, but I have about 20 in game days passed and the trader has the same stuff and the Halloween stuff still being there I find a little lazy considering its New Years day at the time of this review.

Enemies(NPC); The movements i'd say are pretty damn good, however the shooting aspect of it, its almost as if the ones with guns have literal aimbot(even on easy mode) It's not impossible, but you need to stay constantly moving until they need to reload before pushing at them. The NPC's with crossbow's and early game pistols are easy to go against. Another thing is it seems that some of the enemies respawn after killing all of them. The mutants like to respawn on Small Rock Island and not any of the other places. I'm not sure if they are meant to respawn or not respawn at all. 

Overall the game I see has a ton of potential, and I am very eager to see what there is in store. Please, again, keep in mind it is still in early access, that doesn't mean its not a ton of fun to play, especially with friends(if you have any, I don't <3)
I am having fun in this game, holy fuck

Very much what I was looking for in a sort of Rust meets Stranded. 
The game, despite being in early access has been smooth running and rather enjoyable. The customisation and mods currently available set sight to unlimited (in a way) of imagination. 

Couple points 

- If you're loading multiplayer then make sure the host / players are on the correct server network as this impacts the ping majorly. I have noticed a few times where the server location has tried to set it to Asia over Europe though it is easily changeable. 

- Set passwords on the game servers if you do not wish other players to join. This will stop random people joining obviously.

- There is a "Friendly Fire" in the modify section and difficulty / raid intensity can be adjusted which is a very nice touch depending  on your play style or what you want to do.  

In all, I am excited to see what the new updates bring and what we can further do and explore. I haven't put hundreds of hours in but the time I have played, it's been really enjoyable to pass the time.

Still in development so there are a few bugs to work out and features to add but this is a wonderful combination of Fallout meets Stranded Deep.  Gather resources, build your base, grow crops, research tech, grow stronger and venture forth to explore a world dominated by clans that will kill you on sight. Epic gunfights where the enemy will take cover when shot at, will charge you with axes or spears and hide in wait for you to enter a room before blasting you with a shotgun. 
There are some bugs though where after a huge gunfight there will be a bot still standing watch over the ocean waiting for someone to attack metres from the gunfight, your boat may glitch when entering causing you to be thrown out and the boat respawn from the sky, when facing the front of the boat and exiting you'll be spun 180, beware where you go as you may be able to pass through a gap one way but not the other causing you to be trapped inside. But saving the game before embarking on something means it's not a big deal. The screen may appear cracked on occasion but exiting to menu and loading mostly fixes the issue (I'm on NVIDIA). You'll harvest trees and if you leave some saplings they'll grow to be full trees and seed new trees, which will sometimes grow through the floor of your buildings but it doesn't damage them so that's a positive. 
Some things that would be good to see coming:
Many clans have solar panels but you don't which is frustrating. 
Solar and battery setup would be very cool. 
Being able to craft advanced parts.
 A craft with loads of storage. 
Telescopic sights, which I saw is coming in January along with heaps of other weapon mods. Yay.

And it's already coop.
Definitely worth your purchase.
i like crafting, and building and this is a new environent that is creative,

[h1]Maybe It's Not For Me[/h1]
I wanted to have something fun to play with a few friends or solo, I was a bit disappointed by the seemingly shallow progression and repetitive gameplay loop. If you like rust maybe you'll enjoy it, but I never liked rust and I don't really enjoy this either. [b]The graphics are alright,[/b] but it didn't feel very stylized and at times I felt like they just grabbed a bunch of random assets and used them in the game. [b]Combat[/b] is pretty awful against the npcs, they don't move around much and they kinda just stand there waiting to either die to you or shoot you every 5 seconds. [b]Survival[/b] is mostly just a pain in the beginning, maintaining your hunger and thirst mostly just means going back to base for water and maybe trying to wrestle a marlin; after you get fish nets food and hunger becomes pretty meaningless and you can just wait for the nets to fill up and collect them with one button press. [i]Maybe this game isn't for me,[/i] but I felt bored pretty and often thought if this was even an original game and not an asset flip.

Take it with a grain of salt, and goodluck to whoever reads all that. I understand I haven't played for that long, and my review is biased.

I'm about 22 hours in as a trio, and this is my review of the game:

* It's still Early Access; I know the developers have some plans posted when the game loads up, but there doesn't seem to be anything about game play other than adding quests (talk more about this later). That's a little disappointing, as there is so much that can be done sooner rather than later to improve the game.

1. Enemies do not reliably respawn on islands after you've killed them. My trio has conquered a few islands (but hasn't claimed them as our own) hoping enemies would respawn for more PVP later on, but that's not the case. As there are a limited number of islands, it'll eventually just be us with no PVP save for the 'raids' every few days. Very 7-days-to-die, once the islands are gone.

2. It is not open world; it might be a bit more enjoyable if it was, or if there were more options for your server (limit of 16 players) to start different factions, build on separate islands, etc. That way, you could compete / be working against friends instead of having to be on the same team. There IS friendly fire (if you enable it), but you would all have to start on the same island as a group before taking over others to have that working-against-each-other kind of game play. That takes away all the PVP from NPC's, however.

3. Still quite a few glitches. The biggest two I've had is the boat glitching back to base, leaving you stranded in the ocean. Another is - when placing things in your base against a wall - you can access it from the other side of the wall. This means if you have storage boxes on either side of a wall, you really have to move around to find the right angle to hit the one you want. This can get frustrating.

4. Hackers are a big problem. I've tried password-protected lobbies as well as private lobbies (not shown as public) and have had hackers join both. They use God mode (unable to be killed) and spawn in insane amounts of loot we haven't even unlocked yet, then use it to try and kill us and/or demolish our base. Server hosts are able to kick people, but we don't get an alert when a hacker joins our server, so it's based on us finding them before they demolish our progress.

5. The map definitely needs to be bigger and contain more islands, as you can get through most of the game in a couple of days. This is where quests will come in handy; there is currently no point in the game other than to build a base, defend it from raids, and kill the NPC's on other islands. Again, you're left with a 7-days-to-die style game once you build a base and kill the NPC's on other islands.


Overall, I really do love the concept of the game. I love that you have to dive for loot, fight sharks, fight other factions, sail the seas to visit other islands, etc. I really hope the devs put more work into a story-line and quest-line, and that we see the devs either region-locking servers, or finding another way to keep hackers out, as this will kill the game before it even takes off.
Enjoying it so far. Excited to see what the next update drops on us!

game has so much potential its incredible that its only in alpha, some changes id like to recommend
- Make base raids more interactive and more challenging.
* Let us make traps that can kill the enemies, barbed wire to slow them down
* Improve the spawn places of the enemies in raids, when we get raided sometimes the enemies are inside rocks or a whole different place than near our base and they never come near.

- Make automation systems
* conveyors, pumps, sorting system, etc.
* Oil rigs and ore rigs that pump up ores from the bottom of the ocean

- Building
* Make it cheaper to build or let us upgrade the already built things with the hammer
* Fix the stair placement, when i try to place stairs they go everywhere except where i want them,

- Npcs/Enemies
* Let us be able to make alliances with certain factions
* Add more variety to the trading outpost, make it to where some items get swapped every 3 - 7 ingame days
* Add more underwater monsters and let us fish with spears or harpoon guns

- Productivity
* Furnaces: only letting us put one ore into a furnace at once should be criminal which is why you should either make automation systems or let us put 2 in at once or just make the time to smelt shorter.
* Grill: Make it to where the improved grill lets you grill 2 - 3 items instead of one on the simple grill.

* Additions that would be cool (maybe)
- Let us extract blood or something from mutants which we can use to change our DNA to get gills or iron body or something like that, to change our lung time and that
- Make a vehicle workshop where we can make our own custom vehicles in a simple way but expensive, this would be that there would be indicators where we can place stuff so we dont make broken stuff but we can still make things that are good.
- Schematics: Make it to where we can find base schematics so people that arent that good at building can use those to make a cool house.

Final conclusion and review:
This game being in early access is insane for the amount of content there is, there is a bright future for this game and I believe that the developers are doing the right thing listening to feedback and taking actions on the bugs and new additions. If you consider buying this  game, you will get your money worth, im only 10 hours in and im hooked to the game.

Being fairly early in early access, this game is a little rough around the edges.  The movement, controls, and inventory systems could benefit from massive improvement (the movement mechanics with the mouse made me give up and utilize a controller, and as it isn't technically controller supported, that came with a learning curve, but feels much better mechanically than mouse and keyboard now that I'm comfortable with the systems and mechanics).  It could also use an actual tutorial instead of essentially dropping you into the deep end of the ocean from the get-go.  That being said, once this game gets it's legs underneath it, I foresee it being a fantastic game.  It's got Subnautica meets Ark meets Raft vibes, and I'm absolutely here for it.  I think it's already a good purchase for the price-- my husband and I have had hours of fun derping around and fighting off mutants and sharks. I look forward to seeing how they improve and launch this game in the future.

2023 (Dec 31'st) Review 

SunkenLand is one of the most fun Open world Survival Craft games I have ever played. 
It mixes the building style of Rust (sort of) + Stranded Deep gameplay + 7 days to die inventory system 

Pros 
1. Easy to learn and get started 
2. Fun and engaging building system 
3. Interesting loot system and beautiful environments (for a Early Access game) 
4. Crafting at its finest, not too hard or grindy to get items or too fast to get to more advanced items
5. Auto save during crashes or when ALT-F4ing the game (or at least that's my experience)
6. Building system is spectacular and leaves a TON of room to customize and add modularity to your base
7. Progressing is fluid and slows down a bit in some places but overall good!
8. Progressing AI during raids! they start with nothing and evolve over time eventually carrying heavier weapons!
Cons
1. AI is a bit dumb or Esports players pixel peaking angles that dont make sense or shoot through geometry
2. Armor durability is very low and feels almost useless till you get 55+ armor (all together)
3. Animations are a bit jank in some areas as well as alot of textures tend to be muddy even on highest settings
4. Laggy (stuttering)  even on beefier systems (mine: R7 5700X / RTX 4070 / 32gb 3600mhz) avg Fps on High: 80-90 @1440p 144hz while running a server 
5. Object loading tends to make the game stutter 
6. Audio is bugged in some cases with clicks and pops happening when you break items or loading into areas.
7. AI is VERY dumb during raids and tend to stand in place or walk into a wall or straight up ignore you if you have barb wire next to you 


Overall 7/10

I was going to give this game a positive review until today. Unfortunately every time you log-in you have to "create your server," which is not an issue, except for one thing:

The game never remembers what your previous settings were, so it always defaults to creating a Public server, where anyone can join.

Turns out that someone joined our server and destroyed everything we had built within a matter of minutes, because anyone who joins has access to all your structures. There is no way around it currently, no factions, no clan that they need to join, etc. So if you ever forget to set your "server" as private, anyone can join and grief.
An immersive, in-depth crafting survival, Sunkenland delivers on these points, but it may be too grindy for some.

Here's the real issue. This game is full of security flaws.  Don't listen to reviews that state any of this is fixed by password protecting your game.

Passwords on servers can be bypassed. 
There is no banning option. 
You IP is easily exposed. Attackers can then gain access to your system via unity exploits.
Zero cheat protection. Anyone can run hacks on your server there is no way to disable this.
If you can think of it, someone has a hack for that. Instat-kill even with FF off, god mode, teleport, radar, you name it.

Enjoy this offline for now.

Another scavenging and crafting survival game like Raft, project zomboid, Rust, valheim, Ark, etc. This is wet minecraft and it still needs a bunch of work.
 You can frustratingly interact with crafting stations through walls, and other stations. A lot of things dont respect walls, like sharks. This is a key flaw in a base building/fortress game. The rules for construction are not respected by the game and you can end up with rooms with no roof because the build system wont let you. 
There is an extensive gun building system, but its lazy as you need a key ingredient for each "broken X gun". You dont craft so much as repair.
The gunplay is ok, but a little janky. There are a lot of clothes for something with minimal stats, almost like dress ups were a core feature. Its quite a tropical looking setting but you start freezing if you are outside after dark. The shaders look great. Water is stunning. It doesnt feel particularly grindy.
This looks like one persons passion project that they will get tired of before it exits beta.

The game is missing key features yet. One of the most noticeable to me is the inventory management. I find myself having to manually stack items in my inventory while diving due to the game creating multiple non maxed stacks of the same item. Moving items around needs some optimization. 
Other issues worth mentioning (I played around 3 hours only): Cumbersome trading mechanics due to lack of prices. Sound issues, specially when joining games near constructions. Buckets need to press use to fill up with water. Bleeding to death seems real, but maybe too real.
Bugs and features aside, the game is cheap, and the devs seem to be putting an effort. So I recommend getting it right now to keep the development inertia going.

Good start!

Ignoring the obvious early access typical stuff.  

Pros: Good concept and some good lighting.  Very 7 days to die feel(thought potentially a better game for sure).  Crafting system has a good start as long as they continue to develop it.  

Cons Fixable: Enemy pathing and combat awareness needs attention.  Factions don't alert friendlies to danger.  So picking them off one or two at a time is easy.  The aiming of firearms is a little off.   I can clearly see them and for fast moving bullets, should connect.   I can understand for bows and crossbows but the combat system needs a rework in this area.  Also, unless I am really unlucky with bullet spread, bullet paths should not be blocked by invisible barriers.  Chain link fences shouldn't block bullets for the most part anyways. 


Maybe fixable?:  Maybe its the game engine they are using, I don't really know enough but fps should be much more streamlined by now.  We have been playing these games for years!  Clunky FPS is not acceptable.  Also repairing base blocks can be difficult due to the requirement for the hammer to hit the block.  If another block gets in the way or the swing path isn't connecting with the intended block, repair doesn't happen.  

The underwater portion of the game seems to be the best part so that is good.  However everything above ground seems a little clunky for today's technology.   

So I am on the fence about this one.  There are some things that are easily fixable but some other things that seem to be built into the game that I don't like.  Positive review with a caution to players expecting a AAA gold standard game.

The game is still early access, so I can only review it up to this point in it's development, but so far I'm impressed.

There are many areas the game team have yet to develop further and I'm excited to see what come from that.  I'm really enjoying the open world element and building from scavenged materials, researching more advanced ones etc and the mutant attacks are a nice little element so you don't get too comfortable.

I've only tried the game single player to this point but it's still a load of fun battling with the AI players over resources.

I did get randomly jammed stuck under the lip of a roof of a building and drown at one point, but these kinds of things are expected in early access. 

Excited to see what's to come in the future for Sunkenland.

TLDR: Plays like abandonware.

Poor quality graphics, lack of content, coupled with terrible controls makes this a title to steer clear from. It's not anywhere near the fun as Raft or Rust despite the positive reviews would have you thinking otherwise. I will caveat the quality of the water is quite ok but the rest of it is trash. The controls are clunky with sensitivity a struggle to find the right amount, and it's missing simple functionality such as when building. There's no easy way to navigate the UI intuitively such as tabbing across pages or using right click to close the interface. The combat is bizarre at best, but mostly reduced to a lot of being unsure where the hitbox is and where the end of your weapon is waving around at... once you realise you are being attacked that is. The crafting and tiers are simplistic and don't make a huge amount of sense either.

I've supported Early Access games over the years since Space Engineers in 2012 and this one just is not worth more than $5 at most in it's current state, I will be asking for a refund after I write this review to warn others off.

This game has the bones to be a great open world survival game, but at its current state I have to say its too early access. I look forward to seeing how it grows and I'm sure I'll come back later and maybe change my review, but for now there are so many other games in this genre that have so much more polish and are more fun to play.

It's a bit like Rust but the world is massive especially because you have more than the overworld- you have the underwater world which reminds me of Fallout, just submerged. It's spectacular to navigate, and I love eye-candy in games when it comes to world design. It plays extremely well in offline / single-player mode and there is always the option to take your skills online in a random lobby or very shortly your own private server.

As someone who doesn't play very many games anymore, I am pleased with Sunkenland despite the needed polish the game requires to contend with  AAA studios who have hundred-million dollar budgets.

The only aspects I would change are
-improving the graphic quality because the poly count is at the same level as Bethesda
-adding third-person POV
-adding more options for resource automation so you aren't plagued with needing to travel far and wide to collect scrap metal or ores (for mass-building constructs aka your base), OR, having a slider for resource density to control how many resources get spawned
-adding dialogue to friendly NPCs to expand the lore and improving human body animations to make them a little less simplistic. Also, it would be really nice to have snippets of lore dispersed throughout the sunken world, maybe in sealed containers written by the people who lived on the surface
-improving the animations and behaviour of non-human entities like turtles, sharks, etc to have more than their current minimalist idle behaviour that will make them feel more alive than a resource

Despite these criticisms, I am enjoying the teetering balance of tension and peace the game offers and look forward to playing with friends eventually and showing them the ropes.

Sunkenland has potential to be an excellent game, but it totally needs some more time in the oven. I wouldn't recommend buying it at a full price, unless you have an unquenchable desire to play survival games. Downsides are, for instance, many tasks in this game are onerous, the performance isn't that great and, it has some bugs etc. Despite all of this I still leave a thumbs up for this game, because this, still, is a game worth your and your friends' while for a little bit of fun.

Honestly, while it's put together better than most of the other games in it's class, i just didn't find it to be any fun.  AT ALL.  The underwater exploration should have been a crowning achievement, but it doesn't feel like an adventure, it feels like a chore.  

And don't get me started on the "Base Defense".  It sounds like a neat idea, but each attack is stronger than the next, forcing you to struggle to create a larger and larger base JUST to keep up with the growing hordes of enemies (a bit Like a Rogue-lite tower defense game).  That pressure actually makes this game STRESSFUL to play.

And since the enemies can attack your base while you are away, you WILL get interrupted in the middle of a dive and be forced to sail home (however far that is) and IF you are LUCKY the dozen enemies or more will have left a few scraps of your base intact for you to "protect" by the time you arrive.

But you won't be that lucky.  You'll get back just in time to see everything you just spent hours scraping together torn to pieces.

Buy Subnautica instead.  Seriously.

I'm not into the whole builder genre usually, but they put a different twist on this. First time playing the game I was mesmerized for two whole hours. What I like about it is it's not too realistic. For instance, your initial tool, a crude, stone ax, doesn't wear down after you use it a few times. I'm not sure if this will change as the game goes on. Some of these games, where you scavenge for items to craft with, get on my nerves a little, when the things you craft breakdown after three uses. Not on this game, so far.
     Only gripe I have with it is after you build something, you can't disassemble it and put the materials to use somewhere else, if you happen to change your mind. Right along with that, you can't replace or fix something that you've built; so be extra careful when you're building to place your foundations exactly where you want them. I had to start a new game because my yet-to-be-diagnosed OCD couldn't handle one of my placements.
     Definitely worth your time and money: I'd tack an f-bomb on to my description to ensure coolness and developer prowess if I thought it would make it past the moderators. Deuces.

I would say this is more of a mid type game, it's not great but it's also not terrible. This is one of them janky but fun with a few friends type game. This game to me feels like if rust had a child with stranded deep this would be that child. Don't go into this expecting to have a content filled game because this is still in early access so even though there is enough content to keep you invested for a while it still needs more stuff added to it, but i am sure in time it will get there. As i stated above this is a janky game so you may find things like swimming in the water actually just feels like you are still running on land, But so far there has not been any seriously broken jank that i have encountered. I will say this game hits the mark pretty well for a water world type game. Graphically it's not great but it's not the worst i have seen. Performance for the most part is pretty solid, but when you get in a boat it does get slightly choppy but it's not to bad. If you have a friend or 2 to play this game with and you do not mind a janky type game then hell for 15.99$ when the game is on sale why not. Update: just a few small details i forgot to add, The map seems like it is pretty big at first glance but once you start to travel around you start to notice it is really not as big as it seems, and sadly a lot of the map feels a bit empty when it comes to wild life, there is literately only 2 types of sharks and then some marlins and crabs along with smaller fish that you can catch when fishing, i guess there is suppose to be gators too but i have not seen one at all. I noticed that the sharks and marlins also only seem to ever be in the same locations, meaning they do not actually travel out of the locations that you find them at and all they do it swim in a circle, i feel like this is a big reason why the wild life feels very limited since there is set locations that these fish stay at, they do not roam around the ocean freely. I think if this game was actually a pvp/pve multiplayer (not just co op) it would bring a lot more of an enjoyment to it, i say this because once you take out all the factions there is not really anything left to do other than to just keep farming for loot but at some point you will have so much that you wont need anymore.

Sunkenland is clearly in early development and is already a fantastic experience. It has a solid foundation for a core gameplay loop, a janky but reasonable progression, and solid objectives that keep every stage of the game fresh. It's super rough, ends really suddenly, and gets GRINDY for no apparent reason at a few distinct parts of the game, but given more development time, I'm sure Sunkenland will be a game worthy of your time. As it stands, it is fairly short and offers little depth, but my friends and I had a great time upon the high seas.

If you go into it now, it is rough. Several seemingly important mechanics are best cheesed, theres no way to get unstuck if you find yourself hovering ten feet above sea level, and progression can be unfortunately tied to scavenging drop RNG. The combat is suprisingly enjoyable given enemies aren't very smart. A couple of areas that seem like they should be full of loot are suprisingly barren. 

If you think you and your friends would enjoy a janky but solid experience, I would give Sunkenland a try. If not, I would keep an eye on this game - it has the bones of a great experience, and with just a bit more content and some polish, Sunkenland is a serious contender to be an all-time great.

Sunkeland may be a island-loot-collection game, with a lot of underwater parts of the islands, but its not Raft.
You cruise around, collect stuff, fight enemies (A.I) and get better stuff duo to better loot and blueprints you find.
This whole game loop is fun and we had about 20h until we reached the feeling, that we should wait for updates.

The most negative points you need to consider before bying now (end of 12-2023):

- Bad network implentation (some delays/mini teleports when coop)
- Clunky  controls, clunky hitboxes, its just a super clunky game
- Buggy buildings and things you craft (get stuck, wont work e.g.)
- Enemy A.I either wallhack/aimbot or braindead af.

- QoL missing things. 
  - No auto sort into chests
  - Cant move chests WITH stuff in it
  - No "simple" movement option for buildings
  - limited objects for a fun base creation (generally base build is pretty small)

The flow of the game feels really low quality. Everything  is just off. 
Nothing is finished, what can I say more than its a really bad game.

This game has potential.

But I cannot recommend it now.

I think the general progression of the game and things you can craft/get and use is OK. But the acquisition of the materials and parts is lacking. 

Getting the material / exploration part of the game is very different on land and in the sea. The exploration part is primarily in the sea. You can explore different landmarks with varying “difficulty” to get the material from, the difficulty being your lack of oxygen. I do like that some of the landmarks serve as a dungeon of some sort. Some of the landmarks have only one entry point or a long way to better loot that might make you take a risk with your remaining oxygen. I noticed some of the landmarks have a guardian shark, but they can be easily avoided. But this is for SOME of the dungeons, the others are open areas where your only annoyance is constantly getting back up for air.

The islands serve as arenas. Every island has set number of enemies that you can kill. The difficulty here is the number of enemies that can quickly overwhelm you and of course kill you with better weapons than you have. But you can cheese them with going slow, that is if you have a ranged weapon. Depending on the island the reward for clearing the arena might be a box with better loot, other than that you can get things from the enemies you defeat or from the resources of the island.

This becomes very repetitious after some time with a puff of fresh air being a new landmark with a new way you maybe need to approach it and of course new workshops and guns you can use. I cant pinpoint it, but it just lacks something.

This Game... It's is addictive and Fun, diving for resources is really fun and protecting against Mutants adds an element of tension.  I can see myself playing this for a while.  Also having the option to play with friends without having to be on a public server (those are generally so toxic as to make the game unplayable - RUST) is a great benefit.
Finished the game with some friends at the highest difficulty. I hope it gets more updates in the future and more threats on the way.

This is a SOLID game for Early Access and an Alpha build. I couldn't put it down once I hopped in. The amount of resources scattered along the ocean floor and each of the Points of Interest underwater make the exploration top-notch. I think the crafting system is okay, but I know it's going through a rework in future updates, so I'm not judging it too hard just yet. The building is where Sunkenland COULD really shine, so long as some of the nitpicky building restrictions get resolved in future updates. I think this game is a really cool blend between Raft and Rust. Solid 8/10 janky fun.

This is a game , that maybe not looks so good , but good enough.(for that price)  But  we in coop(up to 15 players) have a lot of fun.  It is a mix of Medieval Dynasty / Raft and a shooter.   Exact that makes it good.   You can build , explore , dive , cook , develop , fight ,,,,
The Diving is also fun, you always explore something new.  And you can develop better equiment and like that you can fight also against good fighter fractions (there are 5-6) 
I would buy the game again.

Still immensely fun and a solid multiplayer game. Highly recommended!

DEBUNKING NEGATIVE REVIEWS: 

1. Make your server private you silly geese, no one is coming to destroy my private world.
2. There is around 15-30 hours of solid gameplay assuming you spend time basebuilding and farming resources(which you NEED to do if you want the high level gear).
To say there is 5-10 hours of content here is crazy.

in its current state its actually a great game and with the following QoL changes I think the game would be perfect:

-dismantling buildings and especially decorations is rough, I hate that I lose materials when I put something in the right spot. let me move stuff so I don't lose mats or permanently lose decor

-clothing is basically pointless as it provides no armor and is outshined by the camo which has 3 armor, maybe let us use regular clothes on top so we can make aesthetic choices and not be forced to look like we're in the USSR  

-flags, they're nice because you can claim territory but I don't want to see every single flag I've raised nearby. Please let me opt top turn those icons off and just keep the one more homebase.

-raiding is finicky at best, spawns are really weird and the defensive structures you can build can range from OP for some enemy spawns and others will end up being completely useless until maybe the next raid

-i love that theres gunplay but holy hell the hit reg is really bad. Headshots feel really inconsistent.

-similarly, enemies seem to range from totally clueless to elite sniper gang faze clan pump shotgun gods.
I appreciate that they are formidable but sometimes it feels like there's no way to react to being shot at. The animations are wonky and it can be hard to tell when an enemy is taking aim or taking cover.
random voice lines would be cool to help locate enemies as well(dm me I make an excellent generic mercenary)

-another hotbar would be nice, sometimes at home I like to have the hammer, bucket, etc. but I don't want to take the time to remove all my weapons and other tools. 

-I don't really like when games have a sleep timer, I think it would be much nicer if we could sleep when and only when its night time and wake up in the morning, Sometimes it can be frustrating when its night but i have to wait halfway till morning to sleep.

-there should be a crab trap. its one of the few sea creatures you can't consistently farm, at least in my experience.
