I have played many survival type games in my day and I've never really been able to really get into them without a friend holding my hand all of the way. "Sunkenland" has changed that for me. I am about 20 hours into the game and not only am I surviving, but I'm doing really good. Already Have a nice base of operations built up for myself as well as defensive fortifications around my homestead. Expanded onto another island and am now working on a second base of operation on the White cliff Islands. This game is highly addictive and is really actually fun to play and not overly complex to learn. With that said, "DEVELOPERS" Please add a feature to where I can move my furniture without having to destroy and gather the materials for rebuilding it. Once you place something in your home, It's stuck there as you'll have to destroy it and rebuild it once you expand your base. I'll give this game a solid 7/10. This is really fun for an early access game. It'd be nice to see some more character customization too.

The game is early access but the developers seem committed to working on the game and the announced changes for the latest update (at the time of writing) seem to directly address many of the concerns I have about the game - better exploration/more biomes and a combat/enemy re-balance to make things more engaging, some quests to pull you through the exerience and they want to adjust the tech development journey. 

As things stand pre the above announced - I have played 30 hours over the holidays. The environments are nice and the base building is relaxing. There is a grind for resources but you work out where to find things quickly enough and there are in the current game items that you can build up to that make resource gathering easier. 

I am playing on standard difficulty and the game isnt too challenging, which suits me as I am just enjoying swimming around and building things.

The game is definitely a work in progress but I am going to vote yes and say it is one worth supporting.

However, it's falling flat with the black-powder revolver being a stronger choice than most other firearms. It lacks a scope, but if you can get the iron sights on something, it shoots laser beams. Not the most polished game, but it is a lot of fun once you get around some of the minor scuff. Definitely the bones of a good game here. Devs need to add some fixes and QoL stuff for the game to shine.

Biggest thing for replayability:

-Randomly generated map / faction power.
-Bigger map
-Better tuning of difficulties

QoL:
-In multiplayer, we have to restart the server every time someone logs off or we can't go to bed.
-Smarter inventory (Taking everything out of a box when your inventory is full should just produce a system message, not send all the inventory everywhere).
-Some things like batteries run out way too fast.
-Minor ui improvements.
-Clearer communication of game systems.

Could see this game getting really good, especially if there are more objectives added.

Okay, so I do own a lot of survival games and each one is different, and the same in it's own way. This one...there's just something about it, it's simple yet effective if that makes sense. Graphically not AMAZING but it's not ugly either. The textures work for what is there already, the animations aren't AAA but they work as well. Knowing I don't have to worry about other players killing me and it's just AI(i have server but with a password on it) it's nice. So the game can be relaxing, all the materials are within reach, it's very easy to get up and running on a basic base within your first 30 minutes. I can imagine later in game it gets harder because guns come into play but for the place I am at now in the game, I am excited to pursue this further. Frame rate, textures not bad, WE HAVE ALL PLAYED WORSE and this is nice knowing the game ....well it just freaking works! Great job especially for the price of the game. IT's my go to game to relax now. Thanks and great work so far devs.

If I could leave a neutral review for Sunkenland I would. Like many other positive\negative reviews, I found the concept of this game to be very intriguing. As a huge fan of the movie Waterworld, I like how this game's "story" is set. For me, however, everything was a little too simple and quick, and I feel like more work is needed for this game to be great.

In my hour of game play, I spent 95% of my game time diving in the water for resources. I really like the concept of breaking down objects like a fridge or washer\dryer to get metal and components or even having to chop down a wooden shelf for plants. This was okay and all, but got very boring very quick. 

For the time I was on land, there were a few things to break down, plants to gather, and trees to chop as well as birds to shoot for food; and this reminded me of most normal games of it's type (which I don't mind at all). One thing that got me though was the pick-ax. I got one made but could never figure out what to use it on. I couldn't bust rocks, you couldn't use it on objects to break them down (at least none that I could find), and I found it useless. 

The base-building concept is very neat, and I really liked that you could build a foundation in the ocean that automatically added the necessary support. There were a LOT of things you could build but there seemed to me like there were a lot of things I would consider a high tier object that I could build early on. That to me turned me away a bit because I'm not a huge fan of going from basic to advanced in a short period of time. I'm that person that turns down the experience gain on purpose to prevent burnout.

For combat, I did get to experience this with shooting down a seagull, to killing a fish, to even fighting mutants at my base. This, like several other reviews, was very clunky and I felt like I landed several hits that did absolutely nothing. It didn't matter if I was using a bow\arrow, spear, or even a hatchet. As for the mutants themselves, they need a lot of graphical work as they looked very blah as their eyes looked like pyramids after I did eventually get them killed.

As for the overall experience, scenery, and ambiance; it was very pleasant and enjoyable. This is one of those games where I would simply login just to listen to environment (I do this in Ark: Survival Evolved\Ascended in the Redwood Forest). I did enjoy diving in the water to see all of the buildings, bridges, etc. that were underwater. It helped to relive that scene in Waterworld where Kevin Costner's character does a dive underwater. As for my vitals, I only had to worry about my food\water meters a few times but nothing that screamed "I NEED TO EAT OR DRINK EVERY 5 MINUTES" which allowed me more time to play and explore.

I think that once it's improved, I'll happily purchase this one again. I couldn't give this game a negative review though b/c it is in a playable state and there are probably a lot of players that are looking for something that's not so heavily involved like other survival games. I look forward to seeing how this one progresses.

Prepare yourselves for a blistering diatribe against the abomination known as Sunkenland – a game so profoundly infuriating that I can barely contain my seething rage. This digital atrocity stands as a testament to the depths of incompetence and disregard for players, a festering wound that mocks the very essence of gaming.

Let's embark on the torturous journey through the game's user interface – a labyrinth of despair concocted by what I can only assume were sadistic developers hell-bent on making players suffer. Navigating through this convoluted mess is like attempting to unravel a Gordian knot with blunt scissors. Sunkenland, your UI design is not just bad; it's a slap in the face to anyone who believed they were investing in a playable experience.

The graphics, or lack thereof, are an assault on the senses. Did the developers unearth a dusty old relic from the annals of gaming history and decide it was adequate for release? The visuals are so outdated that I've seen more cutting-edge graphics on my grandmother's flip phone. Sunkenland, you're not just behind the times; you're a disgrace to the art of visual storytelling in gaming.

And now, let's delve into the labyrinth of bugs infesting this digital nightmare. Quests are more broken than a mirror in a house of horrors, and the frequency of crashes rivals a demolition derby. It's as if the developers unleashed an army of glitches upon unsuspecting players, gleefully watching as their gaming experience crumbled like a house of cards. Sunkenland, your bug-ridden existence is a stain on the very concept of playable software.

Updates? Don't make me laugh. The last time this game saw a meaningful update, dinosaurs still roamed the Earth. It's apparent that the developers have washed their hands of this catastrophe, leaving players to wallow in the mire of their own regret. Sunkenland, your neglectful approach to maintaining a playable game is a slap in the face to everyone who believed in your potential.

The in-game economy is an insult to the dedication of players who hoped for a rewarding experience. Grinding feels like a Sisyphean task, with rewards so paltry that even a scavenger would turn up its nose. Sunkenland, your economic model is not just unbalanced; it's a mockery of the time and effort players invest.

In conclusion, Sunkenland is not just a game; it's a betrayal of trust, a heinous crime against the very community it purports to serve. The developers should hang their heads in shame and issue a public apology for subjecting players to this digital purgatory. Sunkenland, you're not just a blight on gaming; you're a disgrace to the entire industry, and I wouldn't wish the agony of playing you on my worst enemy.

So first of all it's pretty obvious that the devs here took the same engine or formula that 7 Days to Die used and kind of just redid it. Which isn't bad.
 
It's actually done very very well but you can tell everything is using it down to the movements and animations and crafting systems. I'm just saying if you liked 7 days you will probably love this given how similar it is. And it has a whole whole lot more content than 7 days does. The guns the upgrades, the whole systems is just more than that game but the gameplay itself is basically the same except it's just in the water. 

Every so often a group of mutants or whatever will attack your base so you gotta put defenses up. Kinda the same gameplay loop as 7 days. 

Will it get boring? I dunno yet I haven't explored everything. My only real negative is the map size seems kinda unrealistically cramped for ocean water based exploring. You should feel like your in an endless sea and you don't. Everything is pretty close together. Now the game is actually still pretty challenging and the systems all work together given this still. 

The AI is pretty stupid but groups of them will still challenge you. 

 The crafting systems has a ton of stuff. Like a metric ton of just upgradable things and tons of things to work towards. 

The trading system is one Ive always wanted in an apocalyptic game where there isn't some stupid type of currency but it's just a trading system where you give me this for that or that many things for this I absolutely love it and I wish more games like this would do it that way. 

Overall Ive always wanted an open world waterworld game because the movie is prime for a good one and this one has a solid right direction.

This is horrible in so many ways, that I am surprised that more than 100 people even bought this.
Actually, the imagery is wonderfully alluring, as is the idea of the game, but this does not even remotely reach any level of quality that would be expected of a game that has earned likely much more than a million bucks. I am waiting on my refund to process as I am writing this.

First, it is an early access game, but using an unfitting font(looks like unity standard font), horrible UI (everywhere), arrows that ricochet off of everything(including hit targets), etc. is totally unacceptable, as is the whole state of the game.
There is 0% polished applied in any aspect. Building does not work as expected. Crafting is boring. Fighting and farming are already unrewarding. Loot tables are bad. Calling the AI any for of intenlligence is an insult to anything intelligent. Combat is therefore bleh. And game pacing is already not doing quite so well. And maybe spawn players on an actual island, not mid air above water. And for gods sake, please at some sort of tutorials, newer PC gamers will be stuck quickly otherwise.

For the developers, I suggest you hire some indie developer that polished up their UI and menus well. Literally most people in the scene will have done it better than you. The idea is nice, but put more time into actually developing your game, than you do styling up the steam store page to trick people into buying something completely different than they expect.
And maybe adjust the standard settings for controlls and sensitivities, so that most people can play without going into settings and tweaking stuff. Or just do it as a form of tutorial during boot up.

Keep on learning how to make games, and hopefully whatever this is supposed to be, comes true in a couple years. See ya maybe 2026.

Pretty game with some of the worst combat I've ever experienced. I hate that games can look this good and still have such bad mechanics. The character models look good but the uncanny valley is strong here. NPCs feel like mannequins. No movement, no life. There are games like this that feel better to play. More rewarding. 

Pressing 'F' to salvage things or cut trees down needs to feel like more than pressing F. You only have an arm when you're wielding an item. You have no legs. You are just a disembodied restless soul roaming around pressing 'F' to salvage entire sunken cars. 

Speaking of using items, why can I only wield one item at a time? Did my character lose one of his arms when he spawned into the world? I tried to equip my ax in one hand and the torch in another and it was not happening. If you can, it is not readily available. Seeing as you don't need sleep and the "Simple Bed" costs more materials than i ever had on me I just found myself waiting in the dark until the sun came back up so I could jump back in the water and dig around in trash. 

As for survival mechanics, You get hungry and thirsty and will die if you run out of air. You don't need to sleep as far as I could tell though I never actually slept, I just played for several in-game days straight. Hopefully it passes time or at the very least restores your health bar but I can't say it does either of those. When you're injured you can make bandages for immediate use but the cost in cloth is too expensive. You got a stamina bar. It works as intended. 

Cooking is fine. Nothing to it, just throw the food on the grill and forget about it. It doesn't burn and once its done it becomes lootable. Not rewarding. 

Researching things requires specific materials, once you have them you can immediately research a new item. Doesn't feel rewarding. 

Base building has the basic snapping square grid system seen in other games like this. The exception is that you cannot flatten the land to build, their attempt at working around this was to create foundations that work fine but again, this is done better in other games. Most rewarding aspect. 

I requested a refund after I farmed up materials to make a row boat thing. I get on it and start rowing and this giant ugly interface pops up as an overlay and shows me the controls for operation. Suddenly, my screen is cluttered just to tell me to press 'WSAD' to move directions. It doesn't go away its just there and to make matters worse, the sound effects used to row are grating. In a game about being a survivor in Waterworld you would think the boat driving mechanics would feel responsive. Valheim does this far better. 

So, I row my boat up to the little trader lady's floating shop and make a few trades in their pleasing trading and bartering system. I buy what I need and sell some trash and I'm ready to bounce back to the cribbo. I hustle back to my parked rowboat and hop back in. I parked it facing the trader's shop but far enough away to just turn around...or so I thought. 

However, as I turned left and began to row the boat was suddenly caught by the undertow riptide of a glitch that pulled me and my rowboat under the shop and permanently stuck looking at the trader's massive mommy milker's upside down through the clipped floor she was standing on. That's when I checked the time on how long I had been playing and it read 99 minutes. 

I really like that there are vendors and NPCs and enemies. But it all feels so skeletal. Like 25% of a great idea realized. It's a shame too because it has a lot of great ideas.  The boat tends to do odd things now and then, like disappearing and reappearing, as well as flipping over randomly when you disembark or enter it, though more of the former.

 Enemy raids while on solo play and you're away from base should NOT be a thing. It's like coming home to find your house robbed and burned down after a long days work. Not fun lol

Other than those few ideas, the game is absolutely awesome for how long it's been out, and I look forward to continuing the adventure!

Very early access game, at this time I wouldn't recommend it.

Pros: 
Good theme for the overall game. Plenty to explore, build, enemies to conquer, collecting, you name it. Graphics are decent though not ground breaking. Seems like 7 Days to Die plus Raft games. 

Cons: 
There is no plot. Other than two paragraph blurb that says you have no memory, better make the best of it. Clipping is an issue in many places. Your character will pop up or through buildings, floors, walls, etc. Your base will randomly get attacked, this can happen at any point. Including when you're on the other side of the map. Having a strong defenses is a must to buy you time to drop everything and rush back to defend your home. At times you won't make it back quick enough, and find large chunks of your bases wiped out, crafting tables destroyed, and so on. NPC's have a bad habit of finding a very slight gap in a building's floor or wall to shoot through. Somehow being able to hit you, and collisions prevent you from exploiting the same gap. Big pet peeve of mine is when confronting a group of NPC's all equipped with handguns, shotguns, and rifles, you defeat them and get... a strawberry, or 4 gun parts, a piece of cloth, a can of soda. If I take down a group of NPC's all armed to the teeth I expect to be able to at least get something they were using. Last issue at least for me. The NPC's programing knows when you're aiming at them. They will be standing still, doing nothing but enjoying the great water view. Put your cross hairs on them from afar and watch them run around like it's been one hour after eating at Taco Bell.
Also what's up with the Halloween Theme at the only trader, at the time of this review its mid December.

In conclusion: Unless you have a group of friends that wants to waste a weekend, don't buy this game yet.

The entire game feels clunky. There is nothing to do other than building bases, which you don't even need since the enemy AI is very basic and does not work often. The game often crashed on my friends' computers. The enemy islands don't respawn so after raiding every island (if you cant be bothered since its basically the same thing over and over) there is literally nothing else to do. There is no point doing it over because the map will be the exact same. Sound design is pretty bad.

I feel like this game may have some potential. But it is simply not worth the amount it is listed for, not even close. The game is far from complete, even for an early access title. You may have some fun when you play it with friends, but this would apply to almost every other game. Even with friends, there is nothing to do.

Base building is also very bland, buggy and unbalanced. There is no stability mechanic, so you can just have a floating base and no enemy will ever reach you (they won't reach you half of the time regardless).

Overall, I do not recommend this game, not even if there is a 50% sale.

This game is fun.  The underwater scrounging is great and the submerged city has a very cool vibe to it.  All the mechanics around swimming in the early game are smooth which is cool because in most games, swimming is the most annoying part.  You can reasonably hold your breath but then you get your first set of flippers and an oxygen tank and now you're the freaking boss.  

You start out on this little castaway island with POI's tantalizingly visible in the distance.  You start by scrounging around the island (in and out of water) to get a basic base up and running.  Before long there is a sense of urgency because it seems some of these POI's are sending raiders over to see what you're up to.  They're pretty dumb at first but can do a lot of damage if they catch you unprepared.

I built my first paddleboat pretty quick and marveled at the rusty sound of the pedals as I frantically accelerated to 60kpmh (wtf?).  This boat had an onboard chest and now I could head out and pay my neighbors back in kind, hauling their loot back to my base.  Also, I fought Jaws with a spear and survived to tell the tale... achievement unlocked.

All that said, this game is a bit jank in a very lovable way.  Some might say it lacks polish.  Here is a short list of dumb things that probably won't get fixed until long after I'm finished with the game :)

1) Stack size is hilariously stingy (scrap metal 15, ore 5, wood 20, etc. etc.)  Doesn't take long for serious "chest-spam" to occur
2) Cooking/Smelting - I was literally laughing out loud when I realized you could only cook 1 food item and 1 ore at a time.  I mean, I could build 10 smelters and 10 grills but should I really have to?
3) You can access stuff through walls.  Doesn't sound annoying?  Try drinking your water accidentally instead of opening the front door
4) Speaking of doors, one of the most annoying things is the hitbox for closing your door.  Its not the door itself, its the open space where the door should be

These and other minor quality of life issues don't prevent me from having fun.  My character name is "Mrs. Costner."  Hoping to grow some gills soon!  See you out there!

- Sunkenland promises a buffet of survival and crafting but serves up more of a snack. 45 hours in, and I'm still waiting for the main course or even some bread.

-Building bases feels like assembling furniture with missing instructions. The potential is there, but I'm left with extra pieces and a wobbly structure.

-Defending against pirates and mutants should be thrilling, but their AI is about as sharp as a bag of wet mice. They're more of an annoyance than a challenge.

-The crafting system makes me feel like I'm constantly on a fetch quest. Just when I think I've gathered enough, it's back to square one. It's a repetitive loop that tests my patience more than my survival skills.

-The day-night cycle is so brief it feels like I'm living in a world where the sun has commitment issues. It's hard to get anything done when night falls faster than my last date bailing on dinner plans.

Playing with friends could've been the game's saving grace, but it's more like solo play with extra steps. We're together, but everyone's on their own survival soap opera.

The lack of substantial updates makes me feel like I'm on a deserted island sending SOS signals. We need more content, better AI, and fixes that go beyond cosmetic touch-ups.

Im really impressed by the amount of quality, QOL and features this game has to offer that early after release. Thats actually a very rare, very good state that the game is in already so props for that.

Pros:
-Nice visuals especially underwater, overall really interesting and unique setting
-Good performance even on outdated hardware
-Movement, combat and looting feels great and satisfying
-Ranged combat with guns has a satisfying weight to it
-As for now a solid pool of stuff and progression, but has to be built onto
-Cool base building which is easily done without much hassle
-Many amazing work stations, storing options and alike
-Clear menues that are easy to understand and navigate around 
-Good sounds and tracks alike, very fitting and creating a relaxed atmosphere
-Coop is easily setup and works flawless and bugfree overall 
-Interesting POIs with different enemy factions and a decent map layout


Cons:
-Horde attacks on bases are mind bogglingly annoying and you have to disable it to enjoy the game
-Looting cars and scrap piles with your bear hands (doesnt really annoy me or anything its just so unrealistic)
-All the pois are so close to each other and if you imagine the water away it wouldnt make much sense landscape wise
 (But i guess its beneficial for gameplay purposes especially for slower starter boats)
-Building onto already existing POI bases can be very difficult and sometimes annoying
-Total lack of base character customization
-A very stupid enemie ai that also walks through walls sometimes
-Definitely need bigger item stacks for some stuff (Ore for example), just in general 
-Enemy respawn on island outpost is ABSOLUTELY frustrasting
-Attacking outposts in the night is super annoying as well because you cant see sht but the enemy ai has perfect aimbot

Let me start by saying I only have 19 hours in this game so far and I can't stop playing. I have ALOT of early access games and this one has to be one the most functional and fun games I've played in a while. There are some bugs and some features that are lacking. For instance when trading, there is no "sale" price, you just have to keep adding items until its a deal. I logged in on 10/7/23 and my sailboat's nose was pointed at the dirt. Hmmmm...Looked like I would have to restart but I pushed the boat further into the water and it righted itself. Problem solved??? Battle is a wee bit clunky but tolerable. Plenty to do in this game and I can't wait to see what the story line will be. I'm sure the devs will come up with a jolly good tale. In all it's a great game despite it being EA.

It's still in EA, while I'm writing this, so there isn't much by way of story yet. But there is a lot of landscape to explore and it's beautiful. The basic survival mechanisms for cooking food and distilling drinking water are pretty good, if a bit complicated. I mean, who builds a grill and a distiller right off the bat? Generally you'd start with a campfire and a tarp. But I've been having fun. 

My biggest complaint are the zombies. Why zombies? EVERYBODY has zombies, these days. And every time I look at one, I just wonder how they could logically exist, especially when there isn't enough muscle left to actually function. They really bug me. I jumped on this game with both feet, within about a week of being released.  Currently I have 711 hours played with 6 saved servers.  Other than the occasional flying raft or the shark swimming through the 2nd floor walls in the Mansion, I have nothing negative to state. I hate the long swim back to retrieve the belongings from my carcass when the bad guys shoot me through a wall or floor but that too will change with time.  The beginning is a bit of a slow grind to obtain a set of BDUs and a couple good weapons but the game is a great addition to my collection of water based survival titles.  It's tough to wait and see what this next major update brings but I'm anxious to find out what is being changed / added.
I recommend this game for solo play and coop.  I do hope the helicopter flight gets smoothed out.  Enjoy!
fun

Steam being what it is and only allowing a thumbs up or down doesn't do the gaming industry justice nor does it allow for honest reviews of games in early access due to that same short-sighted system.

In the current state of the game, I can't recommend it.  While the base game isn't bad for what it is, it feels rather empty.  Multiple areas in the game feel like the base layout was slapped down and the fleshing out process was started but never revisited after that first pass.  Ore nodes are sometimes under the ground or stacked 2-3 deep on one another.  Exiting the boats randomly launches you into the air.  While swapping seats seems to fix this, it shouldn't be necessary.

A patch is supposed to drop in early '24 to address some of the above issues.  While I can see this as a game that I may play from time to time, I don't feel that draw that makes me want to make a new character or start new world as it currently lacks any real reason to play the game past collecting all of the blueprints and completing all the research.  It's like playing Rust in the ocean but with less toxicity, substantially less items, and substantially smaller terrain.

Overall i recommend this game. The drawbacks though are glaring and many, primarily when it comes to combat and enemy ai. Enemies, once they have found you, always know where you are. Their friends know where you are. And their main tactic when it comes to fighting you is to find cover, run into cover until their gun clips through cover, and shoot you in the face with laser like accuracy from across the island with a shotgun. Also, this game very much has the feel of a game that is meant to be multiplayer focused, but playable single player. Meaning, not a single battle feels winnable with just 1 person, but rather that you and your friends are supposed to raiding places. This is a severe hindrance to the experience for me. I'm interested to see where this goes. The premise is good. The world is interesting, if a bit cramped. I'm uninstalling and will try back in a year or so with hopefully more balanced gameplay.

This game has some serious potential, as well as a great start. 

PROS - -
- Simple hud.
- Easy to figure out the dynamics of things.
- Can change the game difficulty to your preference.
- Can change enemy difficulty to your preference. 
- Can turn off raids of your land by AI.
- Very smooth gameplay.
- Easy to navigate.
- [Multiplayer] It seems very well sync'd, seamlessly easy to join and invite friends. Very smooth gameplay.
- Game has enough in it as of this moment to keep you occupied for a while [I hope there is more features soon]

CONS - -
- There are a small amount of bugs, scattered here and there. But NOTHING i have personally seen that is game-breaking. 
- [Multiplayer] While driving a boat, whether the host is passenger or driver. If they use the map, the boat/vehicle stops for everyone else until the host exits the map. I would like to see that fixed, so the vehicle stays in motion.
- [Personal preference] No real story, as far as I have seen, i would personally like to see some form of backstory/history, as i am one that likes to know how a survival/apocalyptic event happened in movies & games that lead to the current situation ["why did everything flood?" type of questions].

SUMMERY - -
The game is very enjoyable, quite peaceful depending on your play-style. I loot when needed, I conquer land when in desperate need. You can take your time with almost everything, besides food and water. But thats normal, you're playing on the games time frame, maintain your needs at ALL times. I have not crafted or discovered everything yet, so this recommendation may be slightly lacking on full information. 

I would fully recommend this game to anyone who loves the survival aspect of games.

For context: Having played video games for some 40+ years I am no stranger to early alpha games and my opinion is on only 100hrs in this game.
This one has potential. Does it have glitches, quirks and WTF moments, of course! It's early alpha!
Much will depend on how the team addresses current quirks and streamlines game play.
Single player I feel I'll get my money's worth. 
Co-op it is NOT ready, go into it knowing that. The game breaker for us is that after some playing time folks who join the game can no longer access containers, doors etc. Also items the placed in containers don't show. Exiting steam and restarting/changing servers occasionally helps but the interval between it happening again becomes shorter with each occurrence. 
Just my thoughts, hope it helps, Enjoy!

So i don't really know where this game is going, i thought if i gave it a few days to mull over i could suggest a path but i still have nothing beyond a few suggestions. The main issue with the game is it's very finite. I've collected nearly all the blueprints and stacks of needed resources in about 15 hours. There's not much else to do now other then collect stuff i neither want or need to "100%" each location. there is no fail state and the cost of death is you need to go back to pickup your backpack (everything worn/on your hotbar stays with you), progression is item based so you when you start at your island you're suppose to spiral away with the further islands/sunken area giving better items. i feel the game could use larger underwater exploration sections with options to refill your air. i liked how easy it was to keep your head above water to get air, i didn't like that scuba tanks worked passively which meant you had to take them off if you were just quickly dipping down to grab something so you don't end up daining it before you need them, if they reversed the use that you drain your breath followed by the scuba, it'd be much better. also the weapons feel bad and there's very little you know about it before crafting, so firerate, capacity, and recoil are only found out after crafting and most are known only by feel. there's only a reddot as an attachment, and it's worse then some iron sights.

T.L.D.R. 15ish hours of casual fun, more if you're a completion-ist

Pro's

Good future potential 
Lots of clothing options
Nice music
Co-op 
Build a base nearly anywhere

Con's

Poor building options
Unbalanced enemies
Bugs everywhere
Potential gamebreaking bugs
Limited playability right now
Sea diving is limited right now
Lacking many QOL options
Day progresses too fast, needs options to slow time down
No mouse scrolling for hotbar
Current gameplay loop is very repetitive 
Poor inventory system that keeps dropping items when a stack is full

Make no mistake, this review will be most likely change to a positive at a future date because the clear sign is that eventually Sunkenland will be a great immersive survival crafting game, it just isn't remotely close yet but so close within early accesss are you surprised?   Right now,  anyone potentially interested in jumping into the game, beware that the game is very buggy, unbalanced and lacks a significant amount of content with a repetitive game loop.

The problems with Sunkenland right now are extensive,  once you have reached stage 4 in crafting there really isn't much else to do except raid islands, rinse and repeat.   Combat is buggy, sharks can attack through walls, enemies can shoot through walls and the damage they do is unbalanced and 9 out of 10 times  you'll be facing enemies with firearms, and naturally they have unlimited ammo and reload exceptionally fast and without decent armor, you'll get shredded fast.

The average gameplay loop is raid island or swim underwater for loot, find a POI and raid it for its unique blueprints whilst trying not to die,  slowly upgrade gear find a new island to raid rinse and repeat.   Underwater aspect is a neat idea, the issue is that you can never stay underwater for very long even with basic scuba gear - and once you've explored some of the areas it becomes more lucrative to raid islands, which makes you run into balance issues especially with highly accurate, fast shooting/fast reloading enemies. 

Tons of bugs all across the board from building roofs which will either not slot together at all, or simply very limited options.   Character options is limited, although plenty of clothing options are available..the issue is 99% of them suck,  this game values armor level above everything and most clothing options have an AC value of 1, soon as you find some military fatigues which usually have a value of 3 you'll never use any of the other clothing options.   

Crafting better weapons/armor is a chore because it requires you to find a broken item as a crafting resource, and soon as you craft some half decent items that game starts to become much easier...far too fast.    Swimming for resources also becomes redundant pretty quickly as raiding islands becomes a better option,   and having some options like raids enabled quickly become more annoying than fun especially on single player as it becomes fairly unbalanced.   Crafting better and faster boats makes it easier but still the scope right now is limited - needs more of everything and I'm sure with time, it will grow. 

Right now,  for survival crafting fans I'd keep an eye on developments for this game.  Once many of the bugs are fixed,  much more content is added and balanced then this game will definitely start to rival some of the other classics in this genre,  it just isn't anywhere close at the moment and naturally - this will be years in the making for a small indie team,  keep an eye on this title as I do expect big things eventually - right now, I'd hesitantly say its not for everyone, but it will keep growing with time.

So far this game has been fun and stable. Some things to work through with adding a story line, but the graphics are pretty and game play is fun. I'd say this game falls squarely in the group of games like Raft, Subsistence, Survival: Fountain of Youth, Forever Skies, etc. A little bit of crafting, a little bit of survival, and a little bit of gun fighting. 
I could do without the daily raids on my base, they get annoying. They're predictable and annoying (similar to Subsistence). It ends up being a big nuisance fixing your base back up after every raid. I'd like to see the food menu increased to add different perks based on the recipe. A story line that drives us to explore all of the islands for a reason other than resource gathering. Inventory management is a pain also...my base is totally full of barrels and crates of inventory. I wish we could sell the clothes or resources to buy things of value that are hard to come by. As it is, it's very easy to find furniture and blueprints everywhere.

Such a fun and engaging game for still being in Early Access. Highly recommend. I've spent hours diving and scavenging already, and I haven't gotten bored yet. Base building is fun, and I love the research table too. I have only played by myself, but I'm sure this would be fun with friends too. Looking forward to what the future holds for this game.

Ive enjoyed my time playing this game. It is fun right now, and has improved each update. The frequency of fixes and content has been impressive for an indie co. it gives me some Borderlands meets Rust meets 7days vibes and scratches that itch that survival gamers get.

That said, theres only two other words of importance: Procedural generation. It should be moved up to top priority. This game will live or die based on whether they can create unique maps for each playthrough and server.

Other features may make the first playthrough better, but it won't matter if nobody plays it more than once and the game cannot reach critical mass.

I write this review after "finishing" the game on insane difficulty AI setting and highest difficulty raid frequency and garrison amount.

1.) Replayability. The enemies in island outposts don't respawn, once you clear it that's it, you can only ever come back for scrap piles and lootboxes, I would like them to respawn together with the loot for the replayability factor.



2.) Questionale stacks sizes. You can stack 20 pieces of large planks but only 5 pieces of iron ore, my chests start overflowing with stuff such as charcoal and components in the mid-game and I have no way to use them.

3.) Common bugs i found. When i leave my boat it makes a dolphin trick-flip and sometimes sends me flying meters away. Im a big enjoyer of grenades but when I use throwables they teleport into my inventory. 

4.) Lack of traders. There is only one trader and while I love the barter economy, it would be nice if there were more traders you have to unlock by liberating captured trading outposts or something, that would sell better exclusive loot appropriate to difficulty of the outpost.

5.) Raiders. I would make the raiders more of a challenge as they are incredibly primitive and do not pose a threat in any stage of the game, for an experienced player of shooter games and survival games in general they are a piece of cake.

Edit: PS: I love the strip club neon decorations, I want a way to buy more of them.

Let me start by saying this:  This game is in EARLY ACCESS!  Are there bugs? Yes.  BUT, the devs are addressing them exceedingly quickly.  I helped play test one of the last updates that addressed a few issues and devs were making changes and uploading them as fast as we were reporting them well into the night.  That said, here is my review:

With 75 hours into the game (a modest amount as I am balancing a ton of things and gametime is a rarity for me) I whole heartily would recommend this game to everyone.  Especially if you have an itch that survival/crafting games scratch, but need a little something extra or slightly different.

Pros:
Its freaking waterworld meets a ton of other things
Looting is divided between underwater and on land
Enemies hold not only land locations, but periodic raids on your base
Graphics are nice.  Crisp and clean with correct ragdoll physics.
Slight struggle for resources in the beginning, but evens out in the mid-late game.
Lots of upgrades for not only firepower, but also transportation and underwater exploration.

Cons:
Enemy raids ramp in difficulty quickly, can be overwhelming right now (WIP)
You will be staring at butts when you kill enemies in the water
Character models a little gangly, but not horribly so, and should smooth out as time goes by

This is definitely a worthwhile investment in the age of early access, and make sure to join the devs discord where there is a very active and helpful community.

Edit:  There have been a few updates since I wrote this and the devs are hammering out the bugs quickly.  This is shaping up to be not only a unique experience in the genre but a great game overall.

First of all, I wanna say good work from the 7 devs this game has (facepunch crying rn) and the amount of content availible so far. As I described to a friend of mine, it is like Rust for cosplayers and people who dont want constant pvp. Game has amazing graphics for being early access and love the underwater potential of the game. 

However, this brings me to my first point: diving
Diving speed in this game is ridiculous. Especially when you have diving fins and fish stew, you are faster than most boats in the game which does not make much sense. Furthermore, a lot of diving sites are just too deep for normal diving and after you run out of oxygen tanks the diving is way too slow as you have to spend most of your time diving down or rushing back up for air. The holes (such as windows and cracks) are not big/small enough to determine whether you can fit through or not, wasting your precious air underwater)

Second point: PVE
The AI in the game is pretty good when clearing outposts of enemies, however as soon as you get your hands on gunpowder weapons, you can clear almost all outposts of enemies, even though your gear does not fit the difficulty of the outpost, so more difficulty differences would be greatly appreciated

Last point: Raids

I understand the game is for newcomers just as seasoned veterans, but in my opinion waiting 25 days until first properly armed raiders appear is just too long. In my gameplay I have walled in pretty much the entire island and left space just for docks. Raiders which damage the walls have to stand right outside of the walls in order to damage them, making you get ourside of your compound to kill them. To fix this, raiders on boats and some sort of a raiding tool (such as rocket launcher, granade launcher etc.) would be welcomed to make the raids more challenging as the time goes by.

Despite all my reservations the game is awesome and instantly drew me in (i play both raft and rust, which this game is a combination of) and enjoy playing it. I am aware of the game being in open beta and the devs are tirelessly working on improving this game but there are some QOL changes which bother me a little bit (such as me not being able to switch items in hotbar with mouse wheel). Other than that I strongly recommend this game and if the devs keep up the good work, this game has the potential to become one of the greats.

Apologies for the long review but I hope the devs read this and hopefully implement changes I have suggested in this review. I know I have written a lot of negative stuff about the game but I just want to improve it and make it more enjoyable.

This is a tentative recommend. At the moment this game is in a late alpha stage, with some issues and jank that would definitely tip this into a no, if this was fully released. Fortunately the developers update and make improvements regularly. This is more of an overview for Early Access, I'll be updating the review in the future.

This game basically plays like Fallout 4 (without the storyline aspects or radiation mechanics), there's co-op and some light survival elements. Definitely some inspiration from Rust and Raft, as well as other survival games, the concept is pretty cool. But there's not really anything new here to set it apart from any other game in this genre. There's nothing inherently wrong with that! Iteration and improvements on a proven formula can result in an amazing game, but there's a lot of work to be done here before it gets to that stage.
With the TLDR out of the way, let's get into the nitty gritty.

GRAPHICS:
I would say Sunkenland's strength with graphics mainly lies in it's concept. It feels very reminiscent of Waterworld, art direction can often rescue games that would otherwise look pretty bad or dated and make them timeless. Unfortunately Sunkenland looks pretty pedestrian, most of the textures and models look fine, but they don't look great. It reminds me of very early days Rust, or 7 Days to Die. Everything in the game is basically a point of interest and even boats are static locations. There's no boats floating around or patrolling and the game can feel a bit empty im-between islands.

GAMEPLAY & PROGRESSION:
Sunkenland's core gameplay loop is; go gather things to progress into better tools and better weaponry, so that you can tackle bigger challenges and gather resources more efficiently. You can build buildings (Think Rust, or Fallout 4 style building). You generally achieve this goal by swimming underwater to explore abandoned ruins and cars. There's various different ores that you can gather with a pickaxe. The problems I have with progressing in this game is that things can be very tedious. You have to build a research table to learn new recipes, which require you to spend resources that you also will use to build the thing. Quite often this means you simply get bottlenecked on specific resources like rubber, forcing you to explore multiple POIs to get enough for a single furnace. I personally really enjoy this part of the gameplay loop, but there's no unique items that I could see hidden away or alternative reasons to explore. Blueprints occasionally pop up in chests or lootable containers (You don't have to pay resources to learn these recipes, phew!). Once you've progressed a little bit, you can make a crossbow and take on the hostile POIs, which leads me to the next section...

GUNPLAY:
I'm not gonna sugar coat this, combat in this game is currently very janky. You have a wide array of weaponry at your disposal to craft and find, but the vast majority of them early on are so bad, that you basically just cheese the horrible AI with crossbows, until you unlock something that doesn't suck.

This game has ballistics, so projectiles over a longer range will drop slowly, you will have to adjust your aim. This isn't really a bad thing, the problem comes when you try to aim down sights. Very often the iron sights for weapons do not line up correctly with the crosshair marker in the middle of the screen, so aiming feels really janky and weird for a lot of weapons. Another example of this is when you have the red dot sight. You get a red dot from the model, a big ugly green dot that appears when you ADS and the green crosshair marker. It's just confusing and messy, this is something that will be obviously worked on, but as it is right now, gunplay is pretty bad and doesn't feel satisfying.

The other issue I have is gun balance. There's not really good progression, you are often given a lot of bad choices for weapons to craft and the odd good one. An example of this is the bow and crossbow. The bow is so rubbish you are better off trying to melee, but it should in reality be pretty competitive with the crossbow. Both should be good options for different things. There's a lot of work to be done here for guns, but there's another huge issue.

AI:
Some people have said the AI is really good in this game, via some of the other reviews. I disagree. It only seems to function if the enemy can figure out how to pathfind to you, or otherwise is able to shoot you (in which you need to be within a certain distance). They don't appear to be able to react to other entities being attacked nearby. You can have two dudebros chilling out in a room and blast one in the face with a bolt action rifle. His buddy won't react 90% of the time, unless you are really close and they arbitrarily notice you. When the AI decides to stop sniffing glue and actually do something, melee enemies will simply charge you, POIs aren't really designed well enough that the AI can realistically flank you, or otherwise reach you most of the time, you can simply jump onto a higher ledge and the AI will often start running around randomly in front of you, not really knowing what to do. Enemies with guns and crossbows fare a little bit better, but often they will attempt to shoot at you through walls, which they are unable to pierce and will only attempt to shoot if you are close enough, it's very easy to outrange enemies and if you aren't in range for them to shoot, they start running around randomly. A good way to see this in action is to just rock up to a POI in a boat and start sniping at enemies from far away. There's no taking cover or running away if they can't attack you, they just start doing a weird patrol, there's just no real situational awareness... These sort of strategies work way too well. The AI is probably the worst thing about this game.

On a side note, occasionally mutants or raiders will attack your base, they seem... kind of competent at breaking your stuff. Definitely keep your things protected. If they break things, you won't be refunded the crafting materials, so keep furnaces and stuff locked up! These enemies will just spawn at your base island while you're out doing your thing.

VEHICLES:
The vehicles in this game are solid, there's tons of different tiered boats and a gyrocopter. The progression for vehicles seems solid so far, they all have storage and get you and some friends to where you need to go. There's no submarines though... Hopefully in a future update. Also hopefully NPCs will use boats in the future.

BUILDING:
It's pretty good, there's the usual options like in Rust, where you have tiered building materials. You can fortify your walls with traps and barbed wire fences to keep out invaders, there's some weird implementation for storage where you have progressively more expensive options that... have the exact same storage space.
There's also a lot of nice decorations, you can definitely make yourself a pretty cool base. There's a lot of different tables for crafting as well, so you will need a decent sized shack, or it's gonna get cluttered.

There's also electricity, generators and several tools that require the use of such, you can get pretty cool neon lights and lots of other cool things.

Probably my biggest nitpick is that you aren't given many options to choose for example, the height of your foundations.

OVERALL:
Sunkenland currently sits in the same category as 7 Days to Die (Or any similar alpha game), a ton of potential, promise and bugs, it's just not there yet. Maybe with a few more years, it'll be compared favourably to a feature rich game like Rust, but it's a long road ahead. There's definitely fun to be had here.
Tentative recommend, if this game was abandoned tomorrow or fully released, it would be not a recommendation at all.

I wasn't sure about Sunkenland at first glance... It seemed like just another in the large pool of survival games, and felt very familiar (I was a fan of Stranded Deep, but that game just never seemed to mature). Once I started playing Sunkenland, however, I was able to find the familiar gameplay aspects were done well, and could see the game was evolving and going in a good direction. Then I got the chance to do some multi-player co-op, and I realized it has the potential to be a real winner.

It's not a big AAA title with massive maps and content, but that's OK with me. Sunkenland keeps things tight, a decent sized area to explore (both above and under the water), and the announced coming content is only adding to my excitement in seeing what the game turns out to be at the end of Early Access. So far, Vector3 is showing that they understand what the game should be, and are putting out a steadily improving product that consistently makes the experience better, so I have high hopes!

Pros:

This game has really good bones. Strong survival elements without it being super tedious, progression research system that makes you feel like you improved as you finish it. The Faction system is cool and the PvE raids really keep you on your toes so you don't get complacent. Diving for scavenging feels like you are in a whole new world every time you go down, it's honestly a beautiful site even if it is a drowned civilization you're spotting. Those are all the pros. 

Cons:
Now for the cons of the game because an honest review should always have them. Combat with enemies feels a little imbalanced. They are able to see and shot you point blank from nearly any position once they notice you. The block system is a little clunky, diving takes a long time to get to the point where you don't feel like you are panicking to the surface all the time. Some of the research feels a little bit out of place. For instance, you can research things that need a generator but you can't unlock the generator until the next phase of research which makes it feel like it's not worth it to invest in them but you also feel like you need those things. Last but certainly not least the time between day and night feels off and sleeping progresses you the same amount of time no matter when you sleep but sometimes you get raided and can't sleep so you're forced to stay awake for day but you can't dive because freezing water isn't safe at least at the point where I am in the game.

I saw this game on a content creators YouTube channel and, after wanting a little bit of a change from Rust, I decided to give it a go. 

It's an early access game and it shows, but, that's reflected fairly in the price. 

Early gathering of resources is simple and not overly explained, none of the tutorial style hints are in your face and any sort of progression block. IE; you don't have to "Get 6 Wood" before you can jump in the Ocean and have a look around.

The build mechanics are similar to Rust, but without to build wheel, once you've selected what piece you want to build you can build as many of those pieces as you want. Then just pop into the craft menu and change the next relevant piece, rinse, repeat. One thing I have noticed is that the hit box for opening doors requires a certain amount of accuracy and items behind the door can be opened through a door if you don't hit the right spot. 

Playing solo survival was really fun. Exploring the Ocean first, then onto the various different islands around, the game doesn't hold up in showing you "there's more to do here". 

Progressions with weapons, allowing further progression through the islands can be set at a relative pace by adjusting your settings. 

Survival doesn't take up the whole of your daytime hours in game. I've played a couple of survival games where the only opportunity to gather food/water takes up the majority of your daylight hours. Sunkenland has a really nice way of balancing that with deployable's or general exploration.

Trading outpost gives you something to aim for if you don't want to start hitting up the NPC enemy islands too soon.

I would recommend getting some progress under your belt, get some weapons, get used to those, then restart on a slightly harder bunch of settings. It's worth it.

The game looks great. It needs work, but that's the point of an early access release, to get feedback from people and make adjustments. 

If the game goes the same way as Rust in terms or quality and updates, it's worth getting the game now before the price inevitably goes up.

Foundations can't be adjusted in height... (if they can, it's not explained), which makes it difficult to build from top to bottom. But the engine can do that... the programmer can't...

You can't attach traps to some foundations (not on all sides)
Ores that have been placed twice on top of each other.

I could go on and on with this list.

The errors in thinking are manifold and rather show a programmer who is not a player himself.

This is a fun survival game with a unique premise. The graphics and game play are solid, and the interface is pretty easy. I would like to have a better option of moving things around, however. As is, if you build a structure (wall, floor, etc.) or crafting station, you have to completely demolish it and build another from scratch--which costs valuable resources. Likewise, it would be nice to have a one-click option of moving inventory and items instead of having to craft a moving box, place the item in the box, then place it in a quick-access box, and THEN move it. Speaking of, one last suggestion would be to label the quick-inventory boxes with numbers 1 through 8 so players know which item is in which box. As it is, when you try to quickly equip an item, you have to count boxes or just make a guess--which is very inconvenient in the middle of combat. Pulling out a bandage,  drink of water, or a fishing pole during a melee round instead  of a weapon is quite frustrating--and almost laughable. Overall, however, I am really enjoying this game and will recommend it.

For an early access game, the base core concept has been laid down in Sunkenland in this early beta. It is very playable and addictive as it is now. Sunkenland has all the hallmarks of 7D2D in its early years, and it is evident that there is a talented crew behind the game, which makes it exciting to see where this game will go over the next few years.

Some small buggy things need attention, but this is to be expected at this early stage and should not deter you from buying the game at all.
1) Opening and closing doors - this needs to be a lot easier and not take specific/careful targeting to get the prompt on the screen.
2) Wall heath: NPC raids hit the walls, and there is seemingly no way to see the current health of the wall after a raid. I upgraded the walls with Armored panels and the NPC's broke in the very next raid - wtf?
3) The current trader loot is just ok. There is nothing consistently exciting here to get the player farming/engaged.
4) Raiding a nearby mutant base in (offline) PVE and clearing them out should hold off the frequency of attacks as they regroup.
5) Some of the item descriptions are lacking informative information.
6) If the player is crafting an item that takes another lower crafted item, say rope, then the crafting system should auto-craft lower their items. (See Empyrion as an example)
7) ** The action bar needs to allow scrolling with the mouse wheel ** URGENT The number of times I consumed food or drink after fat-fingering the keyboard.
8) Indicated full buckets placed in a chest are no longer full after a save and reload. Even though they indicate, they are full.

Game Suggestions:
1) There needs to be more NPC danger in looting key areas underwater further into the game. A player searching around needs to have a more significant risk vs reward the further away from their base. Any underwater NPCs need to drop more key loot. Even key/s to a nearby locked door or loot chest. A dropped key can open a nearby and/or another POI for solid rewards. The NPC could be a mini-boss.
2) Raiding NPC need to drop damaged gear. It should be suitable for a quick upgrade but has limited repairability due to its hand-me-down past. These drops should have a tiny chance of dropping limited repair/durability high-tier gear/snorkelling gear. This gear could allow access at a deeper diving depth, not ordinarily accessible with crafted gear (Mutant Accidental Technology?) This could be a location for rare blueprints and not craftable gear.
3) Have upgrade slots in the boats, improved sail trim, improved wind indicator, or improved gas usage. Build protections/defence and offences on boats as upgrades. Each slot is a rare find or craftable blueprint.
4) Incorporate a talent tree (see vanilla World of Warcraft)
5) Upgrading something like the Spear should yield better drop outcomes, more so with food kills.
6) Auto stack picked up items.
7) There needs to be a Destroy option on the inventory interface. Or have items despawn if they have been dropped.

It's a pretty interesting game. It's kind of like Raft and Stranded Deep. I guess it's a bit like Rust, as well. I didn't play Rust. Although, I did purchase it. I don't like PVP games. I like the survival, and building aspects of games.  It's easy to build your base in this game. So, if you like that. This is a good game. Ironically, if you have arachnophobia, don't get this game. I know what you're thinking. There can't be any giant spiders in a game about diving, islands, and nothing but water. Well, you should be right. But there's a trading post. I decided to revisit this game after Thanksgiving. But apparently, there was a Halloween event. No, my single-player games, don't generally have events, but this one did. And the developers thought it would be great to hang an ENORMOUS bigger than the player spider from the wall. Nothing says Happy Thanksgiving/Merry Christmas like a giant black spider hanging from the wall behind the cashier. I guess they brought it in with the last update. When is the next update? Who knows? Potentially in a couple of months. I wish there was a way to turn off the events. Other than that, it's a decent game. Do I recommend it? No. I don't like giant surprise spiders in my water world games. When they remove the giant spider, I'll change it to a recommendation, if I can. But with my luck, they'll stick it in a Santa or Elf suit and keep it. Or maybe they'll teach it to swim with the mutants who raid our islands.

Overall, I ABSOLUTELY LOVE this game! It has so much potential! And I'm well aware that the wonderful developers are working around the clock to make sure things are getting taken care of so that they can make the best game possible for those of us that are enjoying it and will continue to recommend it to people.

The game has it's flaws, like any game in development does. But what needs to be kept in mind is that it is a survival game. You're going to grind. You're going to do the same kinds of things over and over again. That's what basic survival games do. You grid, build, grind, get better stuff, build more, grind again, etc... Just remember that as you progress further, the game does get a little more difficult. Want more of a challenge? Take up the survival difficulty in the opening menu. 

Now, as for the things that could be fixed or that I would like to see come in the future, not just as a player but as a streamer.

-Weather. Fighting against the elements takes up survival interest.
-Wild life? I understand that this game is water based, but there is a point where you pick up a roasted pig. Where did they get that? I've never seen a pig running around.
-More crops/Better farming. It would be nice to be able to have more than just the 4 crops I've come across thus far. As well as being able to possibly expand on how farming works.
-Better/bigger air tanks. Having to carry so many air tanks because you have to dive so deep gets a little tiring because of having to take up inventory space and having to switch out so frequently.
-Another trader. The possibility of a better trader further out would be nice. One that might have those better air tanks even.
-Boat fixes. I've come across an issue with my boats, regardless of the game I'm in. I'm not sure what has caused this, but the only way I can seem to get out of a boat is by getting into the passenger seat and then getting out. Otherwise the boat will flip, for whatever unknown reason.

I'm sure there are more things that I could add to this, but as of right now this is all that comes to mind. I, personally, will continue to play and stream this game. I love it!

The framework for the game is there but it suffers a lot of issues most other survival games do. It's just too similar to something much better. Are you here for the water exploration and combat? Play subnautica. Are you here for chill vibes on the water and island looting? Play raft. Are you here for in depth combat versus various clans and enemies? Well, 90% of other survival games do it better as of now.

This game will definitely be on my radar but it's simply not in a state you'd play it over something cheaper and more fun with far more content. That being said, I hope the devs keep working hard and make this game stand out among all the already amazing survival games that have come out within the past years.

I nominated Sunkenland as game of the year because i enjoyed the different areas to search and the 1st person shooter style. the building and scavenging was extremely fun.

(Game of the year Nomination Update)
To be short and quick with a review, I did decide to nominate Sunkenland to game of the year, for how much fun we had playing it. How often I check to see updates, and how the beautiful concept of exploring the land and the old barren buildings of our past. From the immense amount of potential I see in this game, to loads of fun it currently stands as is, as well. 

(Previous Review)
Sunkenland is a gripping and addicting game. You are constantly in motion to loot, build and invade enemy territory. I have had immense amount of fun playing this game in co-op. Sure, this isn't perfect, it is in early access, but this is 100% worth trying where it stands currently. There is a few glitches, that can be slightly annoying but nothing to ruin your fun. Sunkenland is all about exploring. From the water to the land, collecting blueprints, decorations, scavenging for recourses and building a strong and fortified base to withstand raids. I always find myself about to log off. When I realize there is more I need to do, and a crap ton of charcoal in my inventory that I can exchange for that oh so precious chemical substance that I can never seen to find enough of. I am more than excited to see where this game continues to go, and hope for the very best success for Sunkenland.

Sunkenland is a cool concept world with inspiration from the setting in the movie Waterworld. If you love that movie, then give this game a try.

 This is a survival game that allows you to create worlds or join existing worlds. You can create a solo world, or public world.

 I will focus on the solo mode in this short review:

  The server settings allow you to decide enemy presence, and other factors which will change the game experience for the world.

  In world, You must eat food to fight hunger, and drink water to fight thirst, you must also keep your energy up, when that runs out you lose consciousness, you can sleep to regain energy. You also have a health meter to keep up, food and medicines will refill health.

  You need to find or craft clothing if you wish to wear any outfit or armor(you start in your undies)

  You can craft boats for long sea travels, there are motor boats as well as sail boats, and even peddle boats.

  You can explore sunken cities while deep sea diving.

  Crafting and upgrading, scales up as you progress in the game - as an example you can upgrade your main crafting table to unlock other specific crafting options as you progress. Another form of upgrade is: forged iron bars can be refined into steel, and wood planks can be milled into refined wood, allowing the crafting of special items. 

  This game has far more content than what appears on the surface, as should be evident in the title of the game, I have mentioned very little.

Over all, I love this game for what it is, regardless of what it isn't. If you like survival and base building, I say give it a try. It is still being actively developed, so expect to see it grow and change. As it is now, I consider it a masterpiece. 

I have not played public servers so I offer no information or opinion on multiplayer/co-op.

Visuals     8/10
Audio       8/10
gameplay    8/10 
World       10/10
Exploration 10/10
Survival    9/10

Over all 9/10

Personally i feel this game is a good canidate for labor of love for the steam awards. Why? Well let me tell you it is well thought of.
You can place Chests UNDER Crafting stations! It is something minor still not many early access games have it after years of development! It has a lot of utility and it feels like someone thought about that. The building system is nice with the snapping aspect. The decoration system is just rad! Not to mention the signs you can place is has a lot of humor in it and i love it. 


Combat is intense and it feels like the enemy is looking for cover and flanking. Also headshots feel rewarding with a nice feedback and the enemy is not so bullet spongy same as you with the armor.

All and all i can hearthly recommand this game and i hope this gets famous as other survival games, it has a lot of potential!

+ Scratches the diving and looting itch quite nicely.
+ It feels good to play and I even find myself relaxed at it - the sharks can get bent though lmao.
+ Seemingly “bad” AI is just helping my enjoyment of the game. 
+ The vibe of the game’s great, love the color palette and the distance of the islands and everything, it just feels right.
+ Building system & decorations are fun and enjoyable.
+ Your base can float in the sky! Yay!
+ Fun vehicles you can get into, and you can stack 2 fins on your feet to swim fast, it’s great.
- The duration of the diving tanks is a little bit too low, would appreciate more options or longer breath.
- Some of my vehiccles teleported back to the base sometimes, I’m not sure why but it doesn’t happen frequently so it’s fine.
Highly recommended !!!

Overall a good well polished early release. No real technical issue apart from my helicopter re spawning into the middle of a building on game load when i parked it on my base on the roof... gunna be hard to get that one back :(

The Good:
Loved the start, so tranquil doing the entire explore thing underwater, nice soothing sound track. Pretty easy to find stuff you need and food. build a base, lots of fun

The not so good:
Very quickly started turning into a bandit shooter. once i started to wage war on the bandits, i no longer needed to explore underwater as i got all the loot, guns and ammo i needed to raid more bandits from the previous lot of bandits. 

I think the balance between tranquil exploring the serene underwater landscape is out of balance with the bandit side of the game and it was a bit of a let down (for me).
BUT if you like murdering helpless bandits just going about their daily plundering with a bit of adventuring on the side, then this game is for you

I've been playing this solidly for few weeks now, and despite being in development the game is quite well fleshed out already. There is some mild jank here and there which is to be expected, and entirely forgiveable at this stage. Initially it feels a lot like Stranded Deep but then later you get elements of Mad Max, the Forest and even Fallout 4. You start with next to nothing on your island, nearby are many others with various factions who will attack you from time to time. Already there are a ton of things in the game that you can build, including an extensive base, a whole fleet of boats and even a helicopter, an impressive arsenal of craftable weapons and many types of armour and clothing. I've still got a few islands left which I look forward to conquering and looting. Obviously at this early stage there are still improvements to be made so it's unfair to expect a lot of polish and finish, but what there is so far is great.

I put 60+ hours in to this game. tldr; It's as fun for a bit, but not ready for early access.

Eventually it just becomes "craft boats, craft weapons, kill dudes"; so I hope to return in the future to a version that has a stronger identity. I felt the same about Raft so my compliments - I had almost as much fun with this as I had with Raft. I also liked the AI, it's pretty good. The base defense is fun at first.

I want to be positive so I'll focus on what I'd like instead of complaining:

I'd love to see:
- more wildlife beyond the basic sharks.
- deeper dives that you can't even do until... *spoilers*
- more dive gear blueprints/etc.
- Much clearer building mechanics; specifically:
-- less penalty for taking down scrap metal. (it's scrap!)
-- rotation, better placement, etc.
-- More pieces, especially roof.
-- set depth when placing things like paintings so they don't end up half in a wall.
-- destructable decorations; that way you are protecting the fancy vase you found.
- The machines must take more than one piece. It's such a grind to cook one piece of meat at a time on a 3D rendered grill that could clearly take more. Maybe early game you just get a little yakitori grill that takes 1 piece and the nicer grill could take more...
- A reason to take specific islands/factions.
- More neutral / friendly NPCs.
- Reworked menus where item descriptions are whole and you get important storage info for containers.
- instead of requiring rubber for wiring, construct wire from rubber/copper.
- Barge / Move the larger floatillas / Towing?
- If you can't own an build on a conquered base - fine. Then let me destroy it all.

I look forward to switching this to a 'recommend'; but right now you'll run into broken descriptions, grindy game loops (food, ingots), and a too fast spiral from fun survival base defense exploration into a basic shooter.

I hope the devs keep at it; so much promise here!

I was hoping for something......"Congratz on becoming king of the seas!" or something like that.  Still have a few blueprints to unlock.  It's fun with friends to build and expand out.  With 3 people attacking an island or base it's quick.  Sometimes the AI bad guys are super good, and others are super dumb.  I found the most annoying thing was food supply, and bag space.  I need a tugboat with 4x the storage when it's just me playing, or at least more slot capacity.  This is a fun game and I recommend it.  It does need some work though.  It's NOT, like RUST.  The PVP is not there at all.  No servers to play on that are not password protected so you have to make your own which is super easy to do. - There is no global target? What is your goal? Just PVE?

A fun little game that you will end up really enjoying for the first 30 or 40 hours.  It doesn't try to do anything new with the exception of the setting, but that isn't a bad thing.  For a standard Survival Craft game it does that very well.  The cost of the recipes scale well and do not feel grindy at all.  The current highest-tier ingredient, Advanced Components, are the most difficult to get and even those are fairly findable since they always spawn in red tool chests.

Pros:
- Excellent Base building
- Variety of weapons
- Relatively unique setting
- Multiplayer
- Variety of POIs

Cons:
- No Dedicated servers
- Bugs, a lot of bugs
- Plenty of weapons, but you'll only use 3 of them. (Or at least I do)
- The usual painful inventory management.
- Lack of useful base defenses
- Terrible gun aiming and sighting (Or I'm just getting old)
- No random resources, everything is POI based, no point in exploring the deep blue water.

Neutral/Suggestions:
- Game offers an alarm as a late game warning for when raiders approach, but you don't need it because the music changes when raiders are within X range.  The music is your radar.
- Would be cool if raiders came on boats instead of always swimming.

So much fun, can't wait for future updates. The building is great, the material gathering as well. There's a large amount of tools, weapons & decorative items (etc) already implemented which is amazing.
