I recently had the opportunity to play Sunkenland, and I must say it's a truly exceptional game that left me thoroughly impressed. From the moment I started playing, I was captivated by its immersive world and engaging gameplay. Here are some of the reasons why I would give Sunkenland a positive review:

Stunning Graphics and Artwork: Sunkenland boasts breathtaking visuals and artwork. The attention to detail in the game's design, from the lush landscapes to the intricately crafted characters, is simply outstanding. It creates a visually immersive experience that draws you into the game's world.

Immersive Storyline: The game's storyline is both intriguing and captivating. It offers a unique and imaginative narrative that kept me hooked throughout my playtime. The lore and backstory of Sunkenland are rich and well-developed, making me feel like I was part of an epic adventure.

Diverse Gameplay: Sunkenland offers a variety of gameplay elements that keep things fresh and exciting. From exploration and puzzle-solving to intense battles and strategic decision-making, there's always something new to discover. The game's mechanics are well-balanced and intuitive, making it accessible to both casual and hardcore gamers.

Character Development: The characters in Sunkenland are well-crafted with distinct personalities and motivations. As you progress through the game, you'll become emotionally invested in their stories and relationships, adding an extra layer of depth to the overall experience.

Spectacular Soundtrack: The game's soundtrack is a masterpiece in itself. The music perfectly complements the atmosphere and enhances the emotional impact of the game. It's evident that a lot of care went into selecting the right music for each scene.

Innovative World-building: Sunkenland introduces players to a world that is both familiar and uniquely different. The concept of a sunken land inhabited by diverse civilizations is both fascinating and thought-provoking. Exploring this world and uncovering its secrets was a true pleasure.

Community Engagement: The developers of Sunkenland have shown a commitment to engaging with their player community. They actively listen to feedback and release regular updates and patches to improve the game. This dedication to the player base enhances the overall experience.

Replayability: Sunkenland offers multiple paths, choices, and outcomes, which encourages replayability. It's exciting to see how different decisions can lead to varied consequences, making each playthrough a unique adventure.

In conclusion, Sunkenland is a must-play game for anyone who appreciates top-notch storytelling, stunning visuals, and immersive gameplay. It's evident that the developers poured their hearts and souls into creating this masterpiece, and the result is a gaming experience that stands out in the industry. I can't wait to see what the future holds for Sunkenland and eagerly anticipate any expansions or sequels that may come our way. Bravo to the team behind this exceptional game!

(Update: 3 - 4 hours in) Second thoughts, until the developer allows players to control their saves this game is a no-go.  All saves are overwritten and you cannot create separate saves.  What this means effectively is that you cannot save your game and "experiment" to see if something works.  There are no tutorials and many aspects of the game are not intuitive... so you end up wasting a lot of time and resources.  Base building is especially frustrating in this regard.   ---> ...after reading some other comments, this game is meant to be co-op, so single players beware.

First thoughts, just under two hours... I have not run into any game ending bugs yet.

The game seems to run well enough, and I'm looking forward to experiencing more of what the game has to offer.  If the developers continue to improve the game, I'm sure I'll be able to sink many hours into the game.  There are a lot of superficial changes that need to be implemented (for example, the way one creates a new game or loads into an existing one is not clear, quite confusing actually.)  The development path and base construction is not explained, so if you're like me you will want to "explore" the mechanics a bit before creating a new, "serious" play through. 

Overall, I'd say it's well worth the price based on my experience so far.  If the game continues to develop and expand, I'm sure it will be a fan favorite.  After I have a decent grasp on the game play arc, I'll update my review.

SAVED GAME NOTE: I purposefully exited and re-entered (save testing) a couple different games, because the "negative" reviews thus far seemed to indicate a problem with losing items/loot.  Initially, I attempted to use the two, loot-able containers at the spawn point.  I lost a number of items (I think it was mainly "special/rare" items and not basic construction materials) upon reentering the game after I save/exited.  I retried this process on a new game (different specific items looted) and this time built my storage and allowed the two, loot-able containers to destruct by taking all items out of them.  The items seem to have been saved when placed in a player constructed storage container.

I really like the game, and even this early iteration, there is a lot to do, a large crafting tree, and everything seems to just 'work.' The map is HUGE with a lot of varied locations. I very much enjoy raiding and taking over those locations, then finding different ways to take advantage of the existing base / location to build my own base. 

Hey, this game is FUN! The building mechanics are great, and you can get a base going very quickly. I like how the enemies will raid on occasion, and that they get tougher to defeat as you build your base up and play longer. 

The crafting tree is very deep, with a good variety of building materials, parts, weapons, armor, food, appliances, workbenches, etc. 

Only issue I have had is respawning under my bed a couple times. I had to either wait to starve and die or break the structure that the bed was placed on. 

Some areas where there is room for improvement - though keep in mind, this game is in early access: 

- Enemies can seem a bit repetitive
- I do think enemies should either drop full weapons OR have them stored in a safe after you clear a base/island
- I am looking forward to the addition of missions / tasks other than kill / loot only 
- I would love to see magnified scopes for the rifles at some point :) 

Overall, this game has a LOT of potential and is really fun. I am exciting to see where the devs take it and how it develops over time. Give it a try!

A great exploration survival game that is fun in its current state, but has several areas that need improvement.

Needs Improvement:
-- Enemy AI!!!! This is probably the most broken part of the game currently. With enemies set to Hard difficulty, I have experienced enemies phasing through walls to deliver a shotgun blast to the face or gain super-speed out of nowhere.
ALSO: Enemies are way too deaf when it comes to gunshots. Please add more enemy awareness when shots are being fired around them.

-- Hitboxes: There are hitboxes all over the map that are completely, infuriatingly screwed up. There seem to be random, invisible hitboxes all over enemy islands/fortresses that intercept my bullets which should have hit the enemy square in the head. To add to the frustration, the enemies seem to be aware of where these invisible walls are, giving them a distinct advantage.

-- Add another trader with better stuff on the outskirts of the map PLEASE

-- Cross-hair alignment on some guns is very wonky

-- Allow more than one piece of ore to be put into a furnace at once

The good:
-- A decent amount of progression is available to unlock higher tier workbenches, allowing better items and weapons to be crafted. Raiding islands on the outskirts of the map is essential for getting end-game tier loot.

-- Enemy AI actually has a few positives: 1) Taking cover when you are sniping them from a distance and forcing you to push them. 2) Rotating positions after killing you so you have no idea where the same enemies are going to be hiding

-- High tier weapons feel very rewarding when you are able to craft them

-- The map is interesting and fun to explore and the raid-able islands/rafts have a ton of variety

-- Lots of options of craft-able boats for traveling long distances with extra storage

Dive into Sunkenland,ann Oceanic Adventure Like No Other!

In a world where the seas have reclaimed the land, and adventure beckons beneath the waves, Sunkenland emerges as a thrilling, watery wonderland that will leave you breathless – in the best possible way. With 11 hours of immersive gameplay under my belt, I can confidently declare that Sunkenland is a triumph in aquatic gaming, and here's why!

🌊 The Oceanic Odyssey Begins: From the very moment you plunge into the depths of Sunkenland, you'll find yourself captivated by the underwater world. The developers have  crafted an expansive, post-apocalyptic seascape that feels like a real-life Waterworld adventure. 

🌟 A Deep Dive into Gameplay: Sunkenland offers a captivating blend of exploration, strategy, and survival. Whether you're salvaging valuable resources from sunken cities, battling sharkes, or navigating treacherous currents, every moment feels like a heart-pounding race against time. The game's intuitive controls make it easy to adapt to this submerged realm, ensuring that you remain immersed in the action.

🏝️ Base Building Bliss: Establishing your  base is not just a necessity; it's an art form. Constructing your haven , customizing it with advanced technology, and watching it thrive in the heart of the ocean is a uniquely satisfying experience. Sunkenland encourages creativity and innovation, allowing you to craft your aquatic paradise.

🤩 A Watery Adventure Like No Other

This game is equal parts invigorating and infuriating at the same time. 
Pros: 
[*]The customizing is excellent.  Having the ability to rotate, overlay, and all the different decorative and useful items keeps the possibilities very open regarding making your fort feel like your own.  
[*]I've been playing for 11 hours and haven't broken a single tool so that's seriously helpful considering how much materials everything eats up
[*]The graphics and sound are really realistic right up to the rocking of your boat and the stomping of your feet on metal or wood
[*]I don't lose my tools when I die either, sure my crap I'm carrying gets dropped but it's in a nice neat baggie waiting for me to come get it even if I turn tail and run for a couple hours, but my tools never abandon me and that's very comforting
[*] The hunger / thirst bars don't feel very time consuming or draining and are easy to fill back up when my character is finally starving to death
[*] Claiming islands so I know where it's safe to tree farm
[*] Freaking adorable decorations
[*]Being able to play alone; always a huge positive in any game I play

Cons: 
[*] Sometimes my swing action and my jump action don't work.  I have to close out of the tool I'm trying to use and re-grab it again for the swinging to work again.  The jumping is random I just keep hitting the space bar until my character decides to jump again
[*] Sharks being able to swim through walls/ceilings/floors and bite my ass..not cool
[*] The villains with the guns are pretty sweaty and kill me in two shots.  I'm patient though and will keep coming back until I've beaten them into a pulp 
[*] There's no way to just move things without breaking them.  I just want to move the rubber duck..I don't want to break him I just want him in my tool room.

Pro/Con? 
[*] Being able to get loot through walls, super helpful and makes me feel sneaky
[*] Random Respawn, I get it's random but do I really have to be chucked 10 miles from where I was?  Sometimes helpful mostly time consuming
[*]The stupid lady at the Trading Floating Island..Trading Island is awesome, Trading Lady is super greedy.  I'm pretty sure my diamond ring is worth more then your paint blueprint MARTHA!

All in all I highly recommend especially if you enjoy games like Subnautica and Rust

So at the time of this writing it just celebrated a month after release into ea.  I got this for $15 (usd).  I think the concept is great and it has amazing potential.  It is VERY rough right now.  It has things to build that the ingredients do not actually exist in the game. I fully expect that to change because the developers appear to be  really working and addressing the problems that come up.  It does needs an incredible amount of polish and development.  And to be honest I do not think at this point it is worth more than the $15 I paid.  However if they keep up with the potential this game has I think it would be worth a lot more. (I could see it at $45 + one day).  On the other side I have seen lots of games end up in ea development hell so the commitment by the makers is going to be the deciding factor.  I think that I own almost all of the survival/craft games that Steam offers and I think this has some of the best potential of them all.  Right now it's so rough that it could go ether way.  Best of luck and happy gaming

this game is right on the line between good and bad, but as it stands now id say no.  combat is one of the issues, the tougher mobs are almost godlike to kill, even after hitting them multiple times, the mutants are ok, but the other mobs are too uber.  bag space is really crappy even after you upgrade the bags.  for a game on the water, you'd think they would allow you to upgrade your lone breathing tank, but im on next to the last research tree and nothing, and the lone tube you can make is crap, gives you like a min. of extra air, then you gotta go back to base and refill it, which is crap.  when the pirates come and attack your base they just rip it to shreds, even with my perimeter defenses setup, they just rolled over it, then you gotta go around and rebuild and repair crap which takes far too long to do.  the mobs are shooting me with guns, but they never actually drop their gun when dead, you might get some ammo, but that's it.  game still needs a lot of work, too much to be early access really.  and im not a fan of having to dive up and down so much, let us stay underwater longer to allow us to farm mats more.  hold off on buying the game until the devs, can fix the many, many problems.

I'll be honest I bought this game yesterday, put almost 5 hours into it and I already love this game. People like to draw comparisons but I struggle to find any fitting. Take what you will from the following and (P.s. The game is 1 month old at this time).

- The underwater play is good, tho the combat is a bit rough
- The exploration feels good and rewarding
- Land side combat is rewarding and fun with a little bit of difficulty if you don't prepare
- Weapons feel rewarding and user friendly
- Tools feel a bit clunky (on land better tools are faster but underwater they feel pointless because its based on the #of hits)
- Sailing is good, boat physics can get a bit goofy
- Raid mechanic (after 30 days) is still good
- Building is enjoyable, would like more raw shapes (for combat themed bases)

I must say I am quite pleased with this game so far, sure it is not perfect, but it has a decent amount of content for the current price and I am enjoying it.

Pro`s:
-Decent amount of content
-Appears to be a decent amount of blueprints to learn
-Combat is simple but fun
-Good base building 
-Small boats to bigger faster boats in game to learn and craft
-Good variety of weapons
-Attacking neighbouring islands is fun and sometimes challenging (yet rewarding).
-Graphics are pretty decent (remind me of rust)
-Good focus on PVE

Cons:
-Mobs randomly spawn on your island around your base (it would be better if they could be seen swimming/boating across to you)
-AI is a bit dumb (gunners will move around to make for harder targets, but not smartly)
-Melee combat is a bit clunky
-Bed time is confusing, I really can not work out how the game determines when you can go to bed (often says not bedtime even when your character is exhausted)
-You kill decent armed enemy's but rarely get weapons from them even though you can see them (should be in their inventory even if broken)
-Map size seems limited (my guess not proceduraly generated)
-Enemy's can cause a lot more damage to you than you do to them (even with scrap armour on)
-I would love to see sea combat

The game runs well on my gaming latop with RTX 3080, Ryzen 5900HS, 32GB Ram at 1440p, even for long periods into the hours. Considering its an initial release into Early Access, they have gotten off to a strong start, more work to be done regarding content, balancing and some graphic tweaking, but well done so far.

I look forward to further updates and will update my review accordingly. Right now I give it a thumbs up. Also there are always people who jump into any survival game then immediately jump on the make it PVP wagon, personally I don't do online or PVP, so I would prefer them to focus more on PVE and add PVP when they are fleshed out on content.

Sunkenland is very rough, but boy is it's progression good. It's very natural, only shows you what's just ahead, and naturally forces you through only the amount of hoops necessary for what you want to achieve.

It feels like it has a very bright future, although it might need a bigger map, or a raft style building mechanic, because once you've looted the land dry, there isnt much more to see.

Still, very excited to see how this game progresses, it's decent value at $20 AUD

If you like to explore and base build this game is for you. When starting this game you load into the world where you have to start collecting resources to be able to build yourself even a basic base. You will have to solve hunger issues, dehydration problems and as you get further into the game these become easier to achieve. There is a workbench with levels you have to unlock to be able to build better stuff, but those things require resources. Know where to find resources? You have to deep dive under water and into the beautiful cities, homes and seascapes designed by the game makers, to find some of the items. Others you must explore the many islands around your starting point where you will have to face enemies and figure out ways of taking them out so you can collect what they have to offer on their many islands. 

Multiplayer is amazing in this game. My husband and I can log on and each just play and do what we want to do, sometimes thats work together, others its separate. You can choose to work through the game as a group or individually. 

This game is in early access and I have personally seen that their team is listening to what they players want to see and have been extremely active in pushing out bug fixes and updates. I can't wait to see what the future holds for this game and I have recommended it to everyone I know who plays games. This game was totally worth every penny I spent on buying copies for both my husband and I.
It's ok, bit buggy, needs more content. Grab it on sale.

Sunkenland has great potential as an extremely fun to play game for those of you who are into sandbox-like games with scavenging, crafting and exploring. However in its current state the game is rather raw. The key points that from my perspective should be developed, fine-tuned or completely overhauled are:

1. Game progression and difficulty. Once you get your hands on a decent ammo gun (Deagle in my case), which happens quite early and easily, you can just steamroll through whatever content this game has to offer. You just exploit poor enemy AI and underworked level designs to acquire best gear and blueprints. So as it happens rather soon, there is no actual point in grinding further (unless you want to wipe clean every monument)

2. Rock climbing supreme. Right now you can literally climb up vertical surfaces with no issues or penalties. In some cases its fine, but in other it kills the joy. For example, it seems that the Twin Rock monument was designed to slowly climb up the structures, killing enemies from disadvantageous positions to acquire best gear at the very top. In reality you just dock your boat from either side and hit spacebar 3-5 times to reach the very peak.

3. As developers chose this particular scavenging/engineering context, there should be way more encounters and events that make this aspect fun and engaging. On the one hand, partial loot respawn at the monuments is great. On the other hand, there should be way more things to do in this context. Rust or Mechagon Island@World of Warcraft could be used as a reference in some way. Dynamic sea fights, NPC raids on player's base are only a tiny morsel of what could be introduced.

4. Level and map logistics. So far the Sunkenland world feels quite small. Even the Tier 1 sailboat can bring you to the opposite side of the map in a matter of minutes, not to mention faster upgrades. For a sea-themed game it is a disadvantage as you don't get to engage in combatting acts of nature or simply encounter so many things that could happen to player in the open water. The current content could amount for maybe 1/16 of potential that the game carriers. One solution could be to introduce procedural generation which immensely enriches gameplay, but this agains gravitates towards Rustlike-context. Another solution is to introduce new and more mechanics inside monuments (long diving session inside a pipe @ Unknown Ruins is both exciting, challenging (at early stage) and rewarding as it gives you top-tier components). Additionally, it might be advisable to go for partial procedural generation of sea bottom that, depending on game session could uncover or hide different parts of the same monument. It would reward returning players with new experiences and loot in the same setting.

5. A lil bit of everything.
- At certain points object animation reminds of the Sims 1 (water level @ advanced water purifier, every lever, oxygen level indicator, water scooter screen, recycler, timber workshop etc etc)
- Shooting is fine and fun (works well for me)
- Crafting is great, but it needs more tuning in terms of blueprint progression (etc you might want to introduce add-on upgrades for weapons, armor, utility objects), quantity of useful BPs (not decorative ones) and it maybe should be more aligned with game progression (I found it hard to upgrade to T4 as it required gears which I haven't encountered while being able to upgrade to T3 with no problem)
- Enemy AI is somewhere in mid-2000s
- Electricity is rudimentary
- Recycling could be more useful than in its current state. Why not allow recycling decorative items, for instance?
- Building needs upgrade options in case you want to finally strengthen your wooden foundation. Additionally, various building blocks should automatically match each other just as foundations do. If you ever tried to attach a half of stairway to the wall, you know how disappointing it feels.
- Replayability. I played 20ish hours in a single world, so am not sure about this, but random spawn on a random entry-level island could help the game with replayability. Starting off at the same place, only to commute to the same handful of monuments of the same design in the same vicinity won't help to retain players.

Anyway, I'm thrilled to see how Sunkenland develops further. Developers surely put their hearts in what they do, and that's priceless. Best of luck!

so i started playing at the one month anniversary. I love the game. i haven't even explored 60% of the map and I've got all research learned and a pretty good weapon/armor setup. I will now give my issues with game, but keeping in mind what they plan to do. For now it is crafting heavy, not a ton of fighting. But as I said I've explored not even half. But from what I've seen mobs don't respawn so once gone , they're gone. aside from the ones that occasionally attack your base. I would like to see a mob respawn. I've had headset issues using Bluetooth, when i use corded USB I have had no issues. No underwater exploration after dark or you freeze. Smelting ore only allows 1 at time, while it is quick still takes time out of exploration to get amount of ingots you'll need for everything. I currently use 3 "smelters" but that saps wood. This is a harvest / crafting heavy game at least for now. Which I don't mind at all. I just want to say that. I cannot comment on community as up until now I've only played on solo worlds. All that said if you like these types of games this is a great one with loads of potential. As long as developers can deliver what I feel like they want to. OVERALL 8/10. Have turned a few people on to it. Tips craft a large base with many chests and pick up everything. Have fun. will revise soon when i try open world.
Fun to play with Friends.

I would recommend this game to all gamers. It's a fantastic game where you have to survive in a world mostly under water. You have to scavange for resources to build things. There is lots of diving to be done searching inside the underwater buildings. You can fish, you can explore in the numerous vehicles provided and you can construct bases. However, beware the rival factions who each occupy several islands and bases. If you visit the factions and raid them eventually they will perform raids on your bases. It's a chill game and the environments are beautifully made. Going underwater is my favourite using my diving gear. Watch out for sharks! This is a new game but the developers are highly active and in time the game will be even better with more choices of weapons, vehicles locations and other mechanics. I'm addicted to this game and so are my gamer friends so be prepared to pull several all nighters!

Amazing game with heaps of potential. Hard to put a number on it as it is still quite new. At the time of me writing this review I have cleared out all enemy territories and have acquired all the best loot in the game (25.6 hours). I hope the devs come up with an amazing endgame to help keep the play through last longer. Multiplayer is fun and solo raiding islands isn't too difficult.

Here's some idea's to improve the game:
- Make enemies more aware and challenging 
- Create an endgame that is repayable
- Allow the enemies to retake their islands over time
- More items in general
- Increase enemy difficulty scaled to how many players are on the server
- Fix the bullet drop off and bullet registration on modern guns (I shoot directly where the sight is aimed but shots miss at close to medium range)
- More ways to create bio fuel instead of only using chemicals (maybe let us use plants too)
- Reduce grenade damage (grenades are extremely OP and allowed me to clear whole islands effortlessly)

Overall outstanding game and definitely worth giving a shot if you're into survival games.
An excellent game from competent developers.

What I'd love to see in the future and I'm sure they'll implement is a story line, more guns, more vehicles, more tribes, more islands and underwater loot areas, more craftables such as a bigger fish net that maybe holds six instead of 3, the ability to upgrade your boats storage/colour/speed, I'd love to see more weapon attachments like scopes, laser sites, maybe a grip for added stability, it would be cool if there were animals other than fish and birds, maybe bigger planters that can grow a massive tree instead of the tiny ones, the ability to customize your controller layout without destroying the controller layout, underwater bases would be sweet but I don't know if they'd be possible because I don't think enemies would be able to attack it. As is I give the game a sliver off five stars just because you gotta leave a little room for error but at the games full release this game will be out of this world! I couldn't recommend it anymore. You like survival games? Check. You like open world games? Check. You like a challenge and good fun? Check and Check! Whoever's making this game I want you to know you are doing an incredible job and I can't wait to see what you have in store for the future!

Long story short: 17 hours in CO-OP game (2 people, i guess 60-70% game progress) and i love it 10/10, money well spent.

I write this review at:
- explored 60% of map
- thanks to little exploit we have 100% of tech progress (in real we would be in +- 50% i explain later)

My rating:
- 10/10 overall feeling, joy and fun 
- 8/10 with bugs (its in develpoment, keep in mind)
- 7/10 with imbalance (its in develpoment, keep in mind)


For compare i would rate simmilar games
- RAFT -> 10/10
- Green Hell -> 9/10
- Rust -> 7/10 

About game:
A) graphics -> I love it but this is very personal, better check some screens / videos
B) game mechanics -> overall very good
C) game breaking bugs-> I found none, just some minor problems
D) minibugs -> its 1 month old game, in active develpoment so, yes there are many minor bugs, but nothing serious.
E) Discord community: Mostly mature and friendly, you can ask in game-questions chat and you will get answer in matter of seconds. 
F) game is mix of raft and rust and multiple other games, in a good way.

Some problems:
1. Lot of items are useless
2. Lot of items are overpowered
3. Graphic glitches, invisible walls non and destroyable objects marked as destroyable
4. Grind Lock tech progress. Advanced gears are needed for last tech progress and for best boats. However its very rare loot and i had feeling that till i will have enough materials it will be end of the game exploration, which i do not like :D Therfore there is a current known exploit, where you can open loot box and pick all but 1 item and than save server and run it again all items in not fully looted boxes will respawn. (Prolly work on coop only). Its basicaly single player so you will cheat only yourself.

Advice to begining:
A. Go for coop server and use password so you can play solo and enjoy some nice exploits :D
B. Go for hard enemies and put population on high too, no point go for easy.
C. Disable raids till you understand basics. Many bad reviews are because of something you can diasble on begining, you can enable it later when you are ready.

Sunkenland, even in its early access version, is by far one of the best games I recently played and I highly recommend it! Looking forward to see how it grows from here.
The game runs smoothly and I had no major issue with it. The only possible bug I found was that the rubber duck (and possibly other items) I found in the castaway island got lost after I dropped it to save inventory space for another quick dive into the ocean (maybe it clipped?). Also, even thought I did not change any key mapping, the game instructs me to press the "F" key to add wood in the bonfire when the correct key is actually "C".
At this stage, it is noticeable that the game is still struggling to balance the multiplayer and single player experiences - as a single player gamer, I found the starting menu confusing at times (it is odd that I have to press "create game" when resuming a saved game) and see no point in having a re-spawn timer when I am the only player.
This said, the remaining comments are written strictly from a single player perspective.
I know that the developers are now working on expanding the in-game lore, which would greatly improve immersion into this world. However, some other things might also help in this respect. I personally found the map to be densely packed. Given that this seems to be a post-apocalyptic world, it is odd to see so many islands, outposts, boats, rafts, etc, just by scanning the horizon. I know that in a game of this nature it is hard to find the right balance between a lived world (that the players could explore) and a desolate scenario (with the risk that the player feels bored); but at this stage, I would welcome a little bit more of the latter: maybe by spacing the islands and surface points of interest a bit more and having more sunken structures in-between (keeping those parts of the ruins that rise above water - those are great and really effective in enticing the player).
One other thing that would greatly improve immersion would be to let players explore the map by themselves, without providing from the beginning any clues as to where things are - currently, we are given a map with all the points of interest already marked, which makes the exploration part less enjoyable and something more akin to having a checklist of to-do stuff. Having a compass (even if it is something we must find, like the binoculars) would also add to the exploration side of the game.
In terms of interaction with the world, I would love to feel more diverse threats. Currently, and apart from the occasional mutant raids and the sharks, the world offers little challenges - it would be cool to have random weather events (rain, fog, storms, etc) and maybe some aquatic monsters here and there (like morays, whales and giant squids and/or even some new species which evolved/mutated in this water world).
Finally, I would appreciate some options for having some kind of mobile bases - for example, slightly bigger boats with space for customisation (building small structures and assets like simple grills and storage boxes).

Great survival-crafting game, set in a seemingly post-apocalyptic water-world.

Sunkenland is all about combat (and not just with sharks and crabs). Maps are populated by several enemy factions, each of which control several islands with resources you will need to progress, and who will occasionally raid your base (assuming you leave raids enabled in the settings). Very quickly you will progress from melee weapons to crossbows, to single-shot black powder firearms, and then fairly quickly onto modern firearms.

Multiplayer is (to me) very important for this game, as most of the boats (and the helicopter) are meant for more than one person, and having one or more gunners to fire at enemies as you maneuver around an island or outpost is a *massive* advantage.

Sunkenland is not light on the survival elements, but it is also not fighting you like some other games in this genre are *cough* Stranded Deep *cough* (which, to be clear, is also an amazing game). The game wants you to live... long enough for some mutated remnant of a person to kill you with a club. You can't just *ignore* food and water needs, but you won't be eating a 10-pound salmon every 5 minutes just to break even with hunger loss like many over-the-top survival games have you doing.

All in all, an excellent and unique addition to the genre!

pros:
Good graphics. Not boring - lots of underwater variety. 
I wish Subnautica had as many as 1% of these weapons. must kill!
Surprisingly good loot tables.
AI players are not too overpowered and one-shotting you like some games.
Sharks, but not too many.
combination between loot and craftable items seems well thought-out.
Food and water needs have good balance.
death poses when enemies die in water are funny.
each region shows a % on the map to show how much has been looted.

cons:
-Wish there were a minimap so you can see your friends and enemies on bottom-right mini map.
-hitboxes and swinging feedback don't seem finished yet - ie.) you swing and aren't sure if it's a hit.
It's definitely not a deal breaker, but probably something still being worked on.
-i kinda wish you got 100% of your resources back when you break structures down, but it's a typical mechanic. There might be an option later on for reducing  when starting a map.

6 hours in on a multiplayer map.
Up to crossbows so far.
Have not found a trader yet.
On level 2 out of 4 research progression.

My husband and I stumbled across this game right as it released. We as always are very skeptical on our games and normally have a hard time finding one that we both like and can stand together. While this game is still early access and not finished, we both rather enjoy our time playing. I am deathly afraid of the water and yet still find myself wanting nothing more than to venture the sunken houses and sail the vast open ocean looting. I'm sure there are many ideas and plans for this game and I can't wait to watch it unfold. I hope to see more of a raft house in the future if possible or the bigger boats in game to have mass storage as that is the only problem we face right now. I think having a small raft house would be ideal especially as the game mostly revolves around looting the sunken houses and monuments. I would also love to have more items added to the house for looting. They have decent loot for a solo player, but I feel that with as open and  spaced out everything is we could use a tad loot increase or items in the house to loot... overall I am very pleased with this game even for what little is out, I can see this game hopefully taking off the more its added onto!

ps. please dont update the game to the point it's a 338GB download like ARK is because thats a commitment one must make and sacrifice all their space in order to do so!

This is for version 0.1.40, currently the latest version.

Obviously, this is a very early alpha. There's a lot to be added and even more to be refined. But what's there already has entertained me for ~30 hours so it's already excellent value for money.  I expect to be playing it for ~20 more hours and then putting it aside to wait for updates. Maybe fiddling with my base or my garden sometimes between updates.

Sunkenland is a PvE survival and base building game with some AI enemies in some POIs and an optional tower defence component. It's a bit rough so far, especially in base building. Base building is functional, but relatively limited in building pieces and a bit cumbersome in some aspects. But it works and it's better than might be expected from a very early alpha. There's farming, fishing, decorating, cooking...the usual stuff. A bit rough so far, but it is a very early alpha. There isn't any lore or story yet. It's a very early alpha. I can't stress that enough. 

What sets it apart from other games of the same genre that I've played is the aquatic element. There's been catastrophic flooding in the gameworld and the remaining land is small islands that used to be hilltops. So a large proportion of scavenging involves diving and swimming. That part is implemented very well. That part is pretty much in a release state despite the game as a whole being a very early alpha. It makes scavving distinctly different to most games of this genre. There's a well made sense of buoyancy and freedom of movement in 3 dimensions and it adds in the factor of air supply. Initially you're limited to freediving. As you progress you can make crude SCUBA gear and an air tank refilling station, so you can dive deeper and for longer.

The core's there and the game is definitely very playable despite being such an early alpha. The dev is currently very active, focusing on bugfixes but also adding some stuff. The intention is to increase the pace of adding new stuff as bugs are ironed out. 

Overall, I'd recommend the game even though it's currently very early alpha, v0.1.40. Just be aware that it is a very early alpha. Many things are incomplete or don't yet exist at all. Things will change. There will be bugs (particularly in multiplayer).  Performance is not what it could be. But the core is there and it's in a playable state already and it has some novel aspects that distinguish it from other games in the genre. I think it's already worth the low price.

Great game, well worth the value... A survival game that looks like a cross between a variety of games. You could describe it as an underwater Fallout variant, not quite as deep; with hints of Subnautica and Salt. Graph

I play this in single player mode and its enjoyable. Plenty to explore, do things at your own pace. Combat is a bit tricky at first, particuarly in singleplayer as normally any bases you attack you are on your own; and more difficult when yours is attacked. You have to get very creative in how you build your base to stop being looted.

There isn't a story as yet that I can see, its more about survival, exploring, upgrading and basically having fun. Its not too challenging a game but quite addictive. 

Shootouts/combat can be quite difficult, particularly if you are attacking from a boat and your enemy is constantly moving. 

Its in a very playable condition now, so be interesting to see what happens in the future. If they decide to improve on some of the graphics, that would be good.

But for me, its a good 8 out of 10. Well worth the money and will keep you entertained. The developers post a lot on how they are going to change it so one for the future.

I rarely write revievs, but for this game, I simply have to. It is a positive example for an early access title. More content, story, lore and missions are already announced to be added to the game by the devs. After starting, the game greets you with an overview of the roadmap. Which looks promising and realistic to achieve. If you like survival games with a heavy fighting factor (your base gets raided over and over again, enemies get stronger over time, and you can attack hostile factions on their islands/bases and claim them), if you like base building / base defense, if you like exploring (and you really need to get off from your starting island and gather resources from distant POIs), and if you like a waterworld themed scenario, then give this a try.
I normally don't buy into Early Access but this is a great game that is really fun both with & without friends that has devs that care & listen to their community.

Sunkenland had huge potential. having spent hundreds of hours in games such as Subnautica, Ark, Icurus and other similar survival games. Sunkenland has the potential to stand out and do something different and unique. Im 45 hours in and have completed and unlocked almost everything the current early access version has to offer. 

This list below is a mix of suggestions, bugs and items from my time so far playing.

- The concept of NPC raids is fun and a good idea that needs a lot of expanding upon. Its very basic and can be "cheesed" with clever base building at the moment. Maybe adding inter tribe raids not just NPC raids against the players. It would be fun to stumble upon 2 factions having a huge island battle against each other. NPC using boats? 
- Once you kill all the NPCs the game suddenly becomes empty, yet you can keep re-looting with no risk. 
- There is minimal incentive to go underwater unless its absolutely necessary. Maybe adding some kind of story elements to discover as well as maybe adding some extra crafting materials that can only come from underwater for high end items. 
- Theme the under water zones with unique animals/fish for a better scale of zone difficulty. Right now you can just swim everywhere at any time and a knife will defeat anything that even sniffs you.
- Deeper and more floral diverse under water zones, 
- If you drop a currently equipped bag with gear in it, it vanishes and along everything that was in it.
- Better NPC item threat prioritising. Right now you can cheese them into shooting a wall and ignoring more critical player items.
- NPC's stealing player boats? (for the lols)
- Better food, water and oxygen balancing. Right now it feels a little too fast at depleting even if you are standing still.
- Character clothing/armour be shown on select screen. Currently you are just in underwear. (My wife gave me a concerned look)
- Larger crop planters. 
- Weather. Icurus levels of weather would make this game insane! Thunderstorms, rain and dynamic sea conditions etc.

Had fun with this game with some friends in the first couple of weeks after release. It has been good to see the devs taking on board all the bug reports and feedback of the players right from the start. There has been so many improvements just in the last few weeks. This will definitely be a game I go back to when it has it's full release.

So at the moment I would not recommend this game to anyone unless you are a die hard survival game person. There are just so many better options out there even in early access.
Firstly I have never seen a survival game reward a player's time so little. I have seen many people say they don't want the game balance to be too easy to gather resources, but there also needs to be a better economy for resources to move up to the next tech level. From what I have seen the devs appear to be working on hopefully adding respawnable loot which would definitely help, but a good example of a current issue is cotton which is supposed to be a way to farm and craft cloth. However, the seeds are apparently either extremely rare and/or unable to be gained from farming it on the farm plots which defeats the purpose of farming and having a renewable source of cloth on/in your base like wood and food.

Hopefully new music gets added to the game because hearing the same 2 music tracks for hours on end gets understandably old. I assume this is a product of early access and will be updated in time, but for now it is annoying.

Enemies balancing and ai really needs to be looked at. Maybe I've just stepped a little too far outside of where I should be difficulty-wise, but enemies with guns are way too strong for such bad ai. The enemies can see through walls and no with pinpoint accuracy where you are, so, even with armor, you get destroyed in seconds. Plus it seems like every hit causes bleeding which needs a bandage to fix which, in turn, requires cloth to craft leading to the cloth problem I mentioned earlier. Enemies that use guns either need limited ammo or they need some sort of miss chance mechanic. Otherwise, players essentially have to zerg-rush the base over and over to clear it if they happen to be running solo. It's just not a fun experience. 

To summarize, I think there are some definite balance issues that need to be ironed out before I would recommend this to any prospective players. If you want a better experience just play 7 days to die or another survival game as this one needs more time in the oven. Maybe I am just bad at the game currently, so if I somehow find the magic skills, loot, or gear then I may update this later.

Edit 1: As of the latest update, the devs added in cotton seeds dropping from farmed cotton plants which addresses the issue I had with it. However, one addition I wouldn't mind seeing is either a higher drop rate of seeds from the applicable farmable plants or a skill/system that allows the player the ability to up the drop rate of seeds from farms. I also would add that the building system is interesting, but also frustrating at times. Roofs in particular are annoying since I could not figure out how to rotate them to match the other roof tiles I had already placed even with on-screen prompts. I would still say that you should give this game more time to develop before committing to it. It has potential, but it definitely needs more time.

It's EA but already it's a fantastic game. I loved Raft and this has taken that idea and really expanded it. I can now pack up my equipment and move base if I wish. I think something I'd like is for there to be some indication of what level each island is. I've turned off the raiding as I leveled up too quickly and I'm getting smashed with some high level raids. No raids is also less stressful. 

I've cleared all the lower levels (I believe) and would like to go up a tier. I decided to make my base at the trading post as it seems to be the central point. But I'm also making mini bases in different places. 
Someone else said that they had people/mutants take back a post but I haven't seen that happen yet. 

Because I've built my base on the Trading Post, the foundations aren't the same level as the trading post which made things a bit challenging. 

I've also restarted this game several times because I had a better idea and wanted to start from scratch instead of redesigning my entire current setup. Which is why I have 112 hours in but still haven't hit the higher level islands. I'm also playing solo so that has it's own challenges but I prefer playing solo. 

I liked Raft where we went to each island and had to figure out puzzles (all except the last one. Utopia was a pain in the neck and not worth it imo.) 

Sunkenland is more like you're a pirate and need to take over islands and settlements. 

I think the only thing that bugs me about Sunkenland is the daylight/nighttime designation. I want my character to get up early and go to bed early but I still end up sleeping until mid morning in the game and waste daylight. And you can't raid or scavenge at night as your character will freeze to death. And because the day cycles are so short, it's hard to get in a decent amount of scavenging since I have to travel some distance. 
It's a small gripe and there is a work around (scattering mini bases around)

I highly recommend this game. It has so many facets to it.

This game is fun for what it is, even more so with a friend. A ton of islands that you can explore with deep oceans. A couple bugs here and there, some are funny, some are game breaking, some are annoying. 

Some of the bugs we have run into within the last 13 hours:

• Duplicating Batteries, one player cannot pick it up because the host and player are not sync'd; the game thinks there is a battery in the charger when the visiting player takes it, duping a battery. We started with 4 batteries, and now have 17.
• Boats like to fly, sometimes, they don't like when you stand on them.
• If a host and visiting player, open a chest at a POI, the loot is different and both players get different loot (maybe intentional?) as long as no one breaks the chest, until all players have looted it.
• Repairing is FREE, F F F F, full armor.
• Red dot / cross hair / iron sights like to bug out, they don't really conform to each other all the time.
• In my opinion, I feel like some weapons are too expensive, 5 iron ingots makes a steel ingot, you need 6 steel ingots to make an ak47.
• Helicopter is worth it and fun, I wish the controls were a little more responsive or sensitive on mouse control. 
• Hive mind AI sucks, the ability to stealth more would be interesting. 
• Items in hot-bar are reserved on death, I abuse this, my friend abuses it. If you die, your gun and ammo are in your inventory, respawn close and go at it again.
• Going completely invisible to visiting players
• Some islands being completely gone for visiting players while being there for me
• You can place most items through walls or through/in other items. (my bed and grill are hanging outside the wall, but I like having my anvil under my work bench)
• "Enemy Took 32 Damage EHH" on the top left of screen for hours

Suggestions I have:

Change AI so it's not Hive Mind
• Fix Boats / Helicopter passenger laggy view
• Repairing should come at a cost
• Bosses / Boss Fights to give the GOOD armor a reason
• Fix Red Dot/Iron Sight/Crosshair alignment 
• Less Recoil maybe? 
• More frequent / more challenging raiding from enemies when you're at your base 
• Fix certain keybinds not working (example Light toggle)
• Allow seeds like strawberry, trees, lemon, and cotton to be planted on ground instead of in a planter
• Add support for different sensitives in vehicles, helicopter, boat, scooter
• I WANT A ZIPLINE <3
• A wider variety of aquatic life / More sharks, instead of 3 sharks at a couple of POI's
• Have the trader cycle their shop items / maybe more than 1 trader in the future? (AND LET ME SHOOT HER)
• More uses for charcoal?
• Player name viability through walls or at a distance without looking at map 
• Quests? :o
• Underwater cave systems (I saw something like that in the trailer but have not witnessed first hand)
• Change the way that doors prompt you to close, having to stand in the middle of them close up is annoying but not the end of the world
• Increase grenade throwing distance, they throw like wimps

I do enjoy the game, as does my friend. If more is added I can 100% see myself playing this again after completing it. There is a limit to how much you can explore, how many enemies you can kill, territories you can claim etc, it would be nice to have the world randomly generate for you. 

I understand the game is in early access, I look forward to seeing what comes in the future, do not feel pressured by the community and take your time. My suggestions are merely a 5:00 AM brainstorm spree :)
Multiplayer blast. Needs a little more fine tuning/ content, but overall great playing experience. I can't fly the helicopter :(

Loads of potential here. I'm glad I've given it a chance.
Balance needs work, resource economy could use some balancing, a few minor bugs with object placement and, as regularly mentioned, placed objects need to be repositionable.
Combat is, functional, but currently lacks any weight or oomph, AI is still very basic, incoming damage is a little too high for comfort, but this early on, still working on finding the right balance is expected, and likely won't be settled till after most equipment has been largely implemented.
The few world option settings are basic, but cover the most impact-full and essential aspects.
The gameplay rotation feels unique for reasons I can't quite put my finger on. Obviously it has to do with the emphases on diving, yet it feels more, pleasant, then in, say, Subnautica or Raft for reasons I can't put my finger on.

It's in a very good place for an early alpha. Here's hoping it stays on track.

I'm uninstalling because I'm not interested in playing the buggy, basic creation that it is right now. I love where the developer's heads are at, but my god this game needs expanded and polished. It has a lot of potential and very much looks like the kind of world I want to explore, but right now it just needs more than I can give it. That said, oh yeah, I see the appeal, and I can't wait to play however many hundreds of hours once it's built up.
I wanted this game to be like Subnautica, because Subnautica is one of my absolute favourite games, but this game is not Subnautica. That's fine, neither was Planet Crafter and it turned out great despite the handicap.
That said, from what I understand Subnautica also started out as a buggy, broken mess with very little to do but build and harvest, and that I found it after it had been out for years, had all the rough edges worked off by thousands of gamers just grinding away. This game is not there yet, but it will be at some point, especially if people more interested in grinding then me play. I would love to come back in like 5 years and play a single-player campaign with an interesting story, set in an open world filled with secrets, history, beautiful and terrifying sights, and all ran on a polished game engine with useful mechanics. Please, PLEASE let there be submarines. 
Hopefully that, but I'd also be interested in some kind of Mount & Blade style geopolitical/grand-warfare/logistics-is-what-wins-wars shit, but in Waterworld. Start out as a survivor, figure out how to keep your character fed, get some guns and a boat, start building bases and fleets, and by the end of the game going into battle on a jetski, moving around the battlefield and assigning targets for my Balloon Bombers and fire support Heavy Gunboats, waiting to see if the Demolition Jetboat makes it to the front gate so I know what to with that first squadron of Heavy Jetski Riders. That would be awesome, I would love to play that too.

TL,DR - Add it to your wishlist, wait until it's 20% off, if you don't like it get a refund.

My friend and I played for a few hours one night, and I decided to dive in solo, pun intended. I've only played for a few hours, but so far, I genuinely enjoy what this game has to offer. Something about it, to me, gives a fresh breath of survival gaming. It has the typical survival elements as most, but I do enjoy the easy grabs underwater, and the challenging loot being on enemy territories. I really enjoy the models used for weapons (I fancy the standard bow using the nail as the sight), items, vehicles, etc. They are super neat in my opinion. The crafting system challenges you to always be exploring into enemy territory to try to find better loot, and more loot than you'd find only small amounts of underwater. Of course, underwater can only give you so much, but there are also some resources you can only find underwater, as well. I love the lore implications of the sunken locations, and can't wait to find out what actually happened in this Sunkenland. 

I don't want to spoil, or make someone feel as if I'm giving tips or tricks, because that's not the case, this is just my personal overview thus far, and I'm far from a pro, or anywhere close to being a good gamer...

 There's obviously some funky jams, being a newer game, i.e sometimes the packing box indicator that lights up when you highlight an item to pack stays on until you relog; or, when you use a flare, another goes into your inventory (or drops if it's full), and it disappears when you put it back on the hotbar;the total number corrects itself when you use the next, but places a 'nonexistent' one back in the inventory. That's no big deal though. I enjoy the enemy AI's tendency to take cover, being constantly moving, and they can pack a punch if you aren't prepared enough. Gotta make those crafting tables to make armor. Although, they can be a little...dumb, for lack of better term, as they tend to focus on the last general area their attention was placed it seems (if they're far away enough), allowing you to move around and get a counter in, barring you don't have others waiting in the shadows to surprise you while doing so. The musical cues are a nice touch, as you aren't always in danger, but the music lets you know you are close to an enemy and may be. I also believe some can respawn, or maybe another takes it's place, if you move far enough away, until an area is 'cleared'. Not a huge fan of their ability to sometimes seemingly be able to see/shoot through objects that you cannot, but that's a small gripe. Although some terrain hit boxes are a little wild, some moments have flustered me as my arrows/bullets are hitting/bouncing off a road piece that I feel like I'm aiming feet above. Again, small gripe. I will continue playing this game as I am having a great time, and I can't wait to see what comes next. The only thing I wish to see, are more threats underwater. Sharks are dangerous, if you let them be. They are easy to deal with, and there's a specific cheese I like to do that allows me to get the shark skin without ever taking a hit, and they could care less. Just kite them out of aggro range, and as they swim back to their patrol location, swim up and bing bang boom, they don't care, and they're dead. Maybe I haven't gotten far enough for sharks to be a problem, but so far, I miss the danger. 

All in all, I love the game so far, and I'm excited to see where it goes from here. I'm sure there are things I've missed, or haven't encountered, but, great game so far.

Edit: I failed to mention the base raids and enemies themselves. I enjoy the ever increasing difficulty of the raids on your base. On top of enemy threats during exploration, having random raids gives you a heightened sense of danger. Do the raids happen whilst your away, or only when you're nearby? Who knows! As the raid enemies can destroy your buildings, this leaves a constant hint of dread, as you traverse the waters. Although most enemies in this game seem to share similar models, from what I've really looked at (being either irradiated beyond repair, or burnt to a crisp from being stuck on open water all the time), it's hard to tell who's who besides seeing the indicator of the location you're raiding yourself. As for the ones that raid your camp, who knows what or why they do it...possibly for the same reason you, yourself, are raiding theirs. It's neat, and I like it a lot.

Also, the trader is a selfish person and I'm not a fan of their attitude when I bring them multiple valuables and they only want to give me 4 electronics...but that's just me being selfish in return :P

The game is in early access and so it has bugs, although the developers are acting as quickly as possible to remove them. The one thing I can say is that this game is going places. In it's current state, it's ok but as development progresses I think this could be a very well thought out game.

If you enjoy subnautica and want to see what it would be like if it was based on earth, try this game. I understand the hesitation of buying an early access game with a duck ton of bugs and so if you aren't sure if you want it now just wait. You will be wanting it soon.

Well, after surviving my first raid, I figured it was time for a preliminary review of this post-apocalyptic setting.
1) I will acknowledge this is Early Access and it has promise.
2) I had no idea until the first raid that I was also dealing with another Zombie Apocalypse trope. *sigh* I was thinking it was more like "Waterworld", getting raided by bands of "Smokers". Please reconsider the plot and raid mechanics. One Apocalypse is bad enough. It doesn't have to be a Roland Emmerich "kitchen sink" disaster movie. *eyeroll*
3) More back story to your Sunkenland would be helpful.
4) There are definitely some clipping graphics issues. Like the quite apparent hole in the sea floor near the starting island where you can swim under the sea bed without any trouble. LOL
5) Please fix sleeping to circadian sleep system with a day/night cycle.
6) I can't put my finger on it, but the building / crafting system seems a little clunky in comparison to other survival games. Something about the two different build menu's.
7) Only 6 Action Keys? Really? Not sure why other survival games limit to 8 when there are 10 number keys, but 6 is definitely not enough.
8) Speaking of Action Keys, what about Key Bindings / Hotkeys? Like the ability to bind F to E instead.

That's all for now. Good luck!

I've put 13 hours into this game so far and for $20 - you're getting a lot.

[b]Pro's[/b]
* Good sense of weapon progression similar to rust. You start off with just a handaxe and spear then move up into a crossbow then early primitive firearms until you unlock modern military weapons. The crossbow can still kill even late game enemies, but using a bolt action rifle, and getting headshots is satisfying.
* The gunplay is good. The weapon sounds, hit registration, etc. all feel on point. You have to play tactical because you can't take a lot of hits.
* The tech progression is good, especially from T1-T3. You start off with a small inventory size and limited underwater breathing capacity, but later upgrades allow you to stay underwater longer. Also, each tier of tech adds something new and interesting to the gameplay.
* Exploring the world feels interesting and rewarding. Many of the endgame weapon pieces, crafting components, and blueprints randomly drop across the map. Also, there's a good change in variety between areas so you're never feeling like you're just repeating the same content.
* Base building is good and there's a ton of customizations and decorations you can find in the world or craft yourself. You can really RP out your base.
* Raids are interesting and fun. I have it set to mid difficulty and I get raided pretty infrequently.
* I ran into 0 bugs or crashes.

[b]Con's[/b]
* Building a base can be incredibly time consuming due to how expensive in materials everything is. You can collect a full inventory of wood and scrap and burn through it all just building half your base. It just requires a massive amount of resources to build a small-to-mid sized base.
* Gameplay loop just involves grinding scrap and components that basically gate your endgame progression. To unlock  T4 workbench requires gearing advanced gears and you only get 1-2 of them out of each of the harder areas. The entire endgame is just grinding out advanced gears to finish the rest of your tech.
* AI is primitive, but they said in the roadmap they're working on it.
* I made a female character and I'm getting corsets, high heels, and undergarment drops. That seems so out of place for a survival sim with mutants in a water flooded world.

This game saved my life.

I am 31.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.
After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

Hello!

I will start with that it is really annoying that people still put up bad reviews for this game just because THEY STILL THINK YOU CAN'T SAVE THE GAME. Instead of wasting time crying here about not saving they just needed to try CLICK "CREATE GAME", if they would do that they would see that your saved server-game is still there even if in lobby your character looks naked. Last time i played on 4th september and already then this worked. In some way this is understandable because somehow developers still didn't fix that after you save a game and log in after that your character displayed naked and you see button "create game", i would just rename it to "load game" or something like that. Don't get me wrong i know the feel when you can't continue progress on next day, i had similar feeling when i didn't find button "load game" on next day, but as my character anyway looked naked i tried to click "create game" and it worked.

Unfortunately i played game not that much, because right now i don't really have time to play because of IRL. But i think i made ingame far enough to have some opinion:

After spending a lot of hours at Escape from Tarkov half a year ago, combat in this game feels very primitive, but i don't say it is bad thing, because game is focusing on dynamic fights, looting, exploring, crafting, using vehicles, co-op fights. Though i felt ingame that developers made some stoppage on weapons for a reload, which feels close to real life, also i think some recoil exists too. Melee fight experience was pretty bad and felt like in any other cheap surival game, enemy were dropping through the ground, their movement and hits felt little clumsy, but some of AI is there as enemy try to get to you if you are on a higher ground etc. But as game progress is pretty fast, then once you get to ranged weapons you don't really need melee weapons as even in combat you can run away from enemy strafing and start again fighting with ranged weapons.

OVERALL ABOUT GAME: So it in some way is similar to Valheim. Server for up to 10 players. You can play with friends too as co-op against AI or just against each other. You start at one of the islands where you can make your first homebase. There is not so much grind as in other games, so you progress pretty fast. From the start you already can dive around your island or swim further to other islands or underwater locations. Map in the server is pretty big, so it would be probably fun to play co-op 2v2, 5v5 and similar or FFA. Before creating a map (server) you can use options to set enemy bot difficulty, garrisons, raiding frequency on your base, you can even set that enemy don't raid your base. I don't remember what kind of frequency i did set but enemy raids were every ~3rd day so i had to defend my base. Also enemy quantity was more and more with each raid and also they became stronger and better geared, i think it has something to do with your research table tier upgrades. Worst thing about enemy raid is that they can come at night and if your base don't have good lighting then you have to fight in the dark. I might add that  first time zombie-like enemies came to my base at night, at that point i didn't know that enemies can raid your base. I was doing regular stuff in my "house" and i heard strange zombie angry men noises from outside, so i went to check it, it was very dark and i couldn't see a thing because my base at that point had no lighting built. So when i walked out and at some point i noticed silhoutte in front of me it didn't look friendly because it was swinging at me. I almost shit my pants at that point because before this i was chill for 3 days farming around base, thinking i am safe because i am on ISLAND! And now someone is here trying to kill me, the music turned from chill to scary, so as i notice my hp gets lower i run away from him to understand against how many i am dealing, i run to a cliff and watch from above i spotted they are 3 bad guys hitting my house, trying to destroy everything i have built. So i decided to go and kill them. I was crafting a lot for base so i didn't really have any gear, just weapon and high-heel woman boots (that's all i found till then). With all my fear and rage i took in a hand torch to see where is my closest enemy then i switch to melee weapon and kill him, then i took another zombie out, and on last one i remembered that i have campfire next to my base i run to fill it with planks so there's some light,then i finished him off and music turned back to chill. Loot from them was full garbage. Also it is not cool that you don't see health of your base structure items like: walls, doors, building base etc, unless you hold in your hand building hammer. So after the raid you go with it and look on every wall with hamer to see if something needs repair. I think it would be much cooler if you could see HP of wall etc just pointing with your crosshair at it. As soon as you understand how underwater looting works you can pretty fast grind for your first boat or catamaran both of which don't need any gas or fuel. So you can swim around faster to new locations and loot there underwater. Building feels easy but sometimes you have no idea where to farm some of the items, but if you keep exploring and looting eventually you can find it. 
Underwater experience and looting feels amazing, combined with the ingame music. It feels pretty real and ofcourse you need to follow how much oxygen you have left before you swim up to breathe. Expect that you can stuck in the buildings windows underwater and never get free and die when your oxygen is out. 

Compared to other surival games it feels more dynamic as there is not so much hard grind, easier to farm for specific items, easier to build, therefor you can faster start searching for your enemy and start a fights. Not so much thinking about eating and drinking. +there are a lot of items (bottle to drink) to buff yourself like swim longer underwater for a period of time, and also slots for items that buff your character like foot flippers to add permanent speed under water and other similar items.

It still feels a little empty not finished game, but i am sure if you have some friends who can play together for 3-5 hours you can get much fun playing it together co-op vs AI or just against each other.

Fresh and fun survival game that has some decent fps action and a flexible building to it. The survival aspect is not very hard, mostly the challenge is staying alive from some brutal enemy raids. Not tried the multiplayer side yet but that looks good as well. Devs are constantly updating and bug fixing, got a good ear in the community. The graphics, and sound is quite immersive. Would be nice to see a few changes coming along, such as:
More interactive npcs (one trader currently). A way to pit enemy factions against each other, recruit or band together would be great. Also some kind of gameplay story woven into the loot they have or tied to an improvement in loot respawn, for more replayability.
Seasons or new weather effects as a challenge for survivability.
Ability to name beds please, I often use these as a chosen respawn.
Signs or markers on storage containers, to help with inventory management.
Some cost penalty to doing structure repairs, maybe needs a battery and fuel.
Upgrades to wood tools, potentially a chainsaw with low dps in combat too.
More ocean mobs and ability for enemies to make use of boats or vehicles.
More intelligent pathfinding and AIs from enemies, they don't react as a group when raiding their island.

Very strong early access game though otherwise.

The game doesn't have any real innovations - apart from the fact that a large part of the gameplay takes place underwater. Could also be a DLC from Rust.

If you want to run around and explore things with no real goal you might enjoy it. The game has no progression walls to stop you from immediately running to the furthest areas of the game and collecting end game items. I cleared the hardest enemy locations with a spear and only died once. I did eventually unlock the last tier of the research table but there was literally no point for me to attempt to craft any of it.

Combat just isn't there. You can fight sharks just by spearing them from the side and you will never get hit. For enemies, just run behind the melee ones and stab them, they can't hit you. For ranged ones, get them to shoot at you and then hide behind a rock. They will run right up to you so you can kill them too. You move faster than every enemy in this game so just side step everything and yawn from boredom.

Hey there, let me tell you about my experience with Sunkenland, a game that had me diving deep into a submerged world, and how it stacks up against "7 Days to Die" with a watery twist. So, in Sunkenland, you're not scavenging on dry land, but underwater, which is a really unique take on survival gaming. You've got to swim around to gather your resources, which is both cool and challenging.

Now, the game has these island factions, and each one has different kinds of enemies, ranging from weak to pretty darn strong. That faction system adds a layer of strategy that's pretty interesting. You've got to think about how to tackle each faction and what resources you need to take them down.

Unfortunately Sunkenland really drops the ball when it comes to explaining stuff. The item descriptions sometimes just cut off, leaving you clueless about what you're making until it's done.

And then there's the whole issue with your base getting attacked. Sunkenland warns you when an attack is coming, but here's the twist – those warnings aren't always reliable. It's happened to me and my buddies several times. We'd get these messages about our base being under attack, but when we rushed back, there was nothing happening.

What saved us, though, was the game's music. When your base is truly under siege, the music shifts, giving you a real heads-up. But honestly, it's not the most intuitive way to communicate an attack.

Now, here's the part that really got to me and my friends. We were all confident that the base attack notifications were just bugs, because it had happened before. So, we ignored them and carried on with our underwater adventures. But when we returned, all of our hard work was gone – our base had been wiped out. One of my buddies even got shot and killed, and get this, he wasn't anywhere near the enemies. He was on a completely different island that had no enemies whatsoever. That's when we decided to take a break from Sunkenland.

So, yeah, Sunkenland is a game with a lot of potential, and the underwater survival concept is awesome. If they iron out these issues, it could be a fantastic game, but for now, it's a bit of a mixed dive.
Its a great game, worth p[laying for hours at a time

Yet another one of those titles that I keep trying my earnest to enjoy but it needs a TON of work. Combat is horrible and nigh on insufferable in its current state, even on easy it turns into a vicious slog where enemies will kill you in two impeccably placed shots whereas it takes roughly two whole magazines of yours to drop one or two of them. 

Be prepared from early game onward to be killed dozens of times and constantly respawned out in the middle of the water after dropping all of your gear in the enemy base and then trying to reclaim your kit that will also undoubtedly end up in you being killed dozens of times moreover. 

Enemy accuracy is absurd and just like any other game, they NEVER run out of ammunition, so be prepared for that.. Only weapons any enemies will EVER drop is an occasional melee weapon OR a BROKEN firearm that CANNOT be used until you've obtained a means of reassembled/repairing it. 

Look, I get it, its an early access title that is undergoing constant work but I absolutely CANNOT recommend buying it or playing it at this time. Good luck finding a server of other players who will allow you to join their game without getting immediately kicked thanks to everyone being paranoid about hackers. 

I like the general concept, the Rust meets Waterworld kind of aesthetic scratches a certain type of itch but at this stage, I'd suggest you avoid this title. The frustration factor here is just too high at the moment. 

I will be sure to change my review as the project improves or grows. Until then, buy at your own risk.
