tl;dr The game's pretty janky at places but if you're a fan of looky-looty-buildy-shooty games, there's fun to be found here, for about 10-15 hrs. I've personally clocked 27 hrs. Whenever it's worth 20 bucks, it's your call.

Review as of 4 Sept 2023, game version 0.1.20.

It's time to overanalise yet another early access survival game!

I've seen this game being described as a middleground between Raft and Rust, which is somewhat true. Graphically the game looks nice, not jaw dropping but nice. UI/HUD isn't the nicest looking to say the least, but it mostly works. The game runs okay-ish, but it's missing a lot of graphical settings (including an FOV slider).

Exploration:
- Underwater locations may initially seem very tempting and intriguing, but as the time goes on you'll be mostly looking at the same assets, looting the same items from the same containters. Then again, it's a small indie team, don't expect dog knows what.
- Non-flooded parts of the map consist mostly of what remains of cities and makeshift structures made out of thin metal.
- Most of exploration is done via boat to quickly move around the waters and "on foot" by diving to get the loot.
- Aforementioned above water level outposts are controlled by factions. Factions mostly serve a function of a gear check. The further down you go on the list, the better equipped the NPCs are and require better gear to take them out. Other than that, despite having some lore attached to them, they're just dudes with weapons. There's no karma system where if you fight faction X, faction Y likes you more and/or faction Z likes you less. Not right now at least.
- The world map that you have access to right from the start marks unexplored points of interest with question marks. Every visited POI will show your scavenging progress, in %. The game doesn't tell you what counts towards this precentage, so enjoy finding that on your own.
- There's also a trader (only one on the entire map, kinda weird but okay) that you actually have to trade with. Majority of items don't have a set value, so keep adding items to the trade menu until the Trader lady is satisfied with the offer.
- There are lootable blueprints that unlock unique vehicles, weapons or decor items.
- There's no compass.
- Once you visit an enemy outpost, the game displays on the HUD who owns that outpost, but the map doesn't keep track of that. This is rather important as progression is tied to who you can raid with your current gear.
- POIs have no visible borders on the map, so if you wanna clear something in 100%, you may end up wondering where do you even have to look.

Surviving:
- There's hunger, thirst and energy meters. Compared to other games in the genre they seem to deplete at a reasonable pace. Food sources are plentiful and as long as you keep visiting new places, it's very hard to run out of food.
- Energy can be replenished by sleeping, eating or overdosing on energy drinks.
- You can start growing/farming your own food and water rather quickly.
- Food doesn't spoil and stacks.
- There's also an oxygen bar. As you progress through the game you'll craft fins that increase swimming speed and an oxygen tank of questionable usefulness (once you drain it, you have to manually refill it via a dedicated refilling station.
- Cooked dishes offer various bonuses.

Crafting/base building:
- Crafting recipes are simple. There's very few items that you make just to use them in a different crafting recipe. Most recipes use 2-3 items in varying quantities. Later in the game item requirements can get a bit grindy.
- To progress down (or up?) the tech tree, you're gonna need items that might be rare and can't be crafted from simple resources.
- For some reason all buidable containers (wooden chests, metal chests, barrels, etc.) can store the same amount of items despite having more complex crafting recipes. The only reason you'd build something else than a wood chest is to make sure they don't pop too soon when raiders start stripping your base down, or because you like how this particular container looks.
- As others mentioned before, base building aspect is missing some rather obvious pieces, like stairs or ramps. To go up or down, you'll need ladders.
- Food and ore related crafting stations only take one item at a time, so if you have a stack of fish to cook or a stack of ores to smelt, you'll have to babysit these crafting stations. I'd really like to see devs either rethink these stations or add in-between tier alternatives that let you cook/smelt more items at a time or add more items to a "queue".
- All buildables can be repaired for free with a hammer.
- Tearing down already built base pieces will give you 50% of the items back. Crafting stations and other buildables can be "packed up" using a cheap item, so you can place them somewhere else or just move your entire base.
- There's a big focus on decorating your base, so you'll find decor items very often. In large quantities. The problem here is that these decor items take inventory space. I'd like to see these items turned into blueprints that you can later build with simple resources. Have a separate tab in the building menu for them, why not?

Combat:
- Weapons range from crude axes, bows, primite pistols to modern-day military grade rifles and armors.
- There's 3 types of enemies: humans with melee, humans with guns/ranged weapons and sharks.
- If you're good at getting consistent headshots, don't bother with anything else than the deagle and the bolt action rifle. Both seem to have the highest headshot damage multipliers and will either one headshot kill or heavily damage most NPCs, until you hit the late late game.
- More powerful weapons cannot be crafted without finding a "broken" version of them beforehand, so keep exploring and raiding NPC outposts.
- As I've mentioned before, NPCs of all factions will raid your base as the time goes on. The difficulty of raids seems to depend on how many in-game days have passed and not on how well equipped you are. You may find yourself in a situation where you're overrun by NPCs that use primitive guns while you're still mostly swinging axes or bats like a caveman. This is one of the areas of the game that developers are actively adjusting as the game gets patched.
- There's barely any warning before a raid takes place. You can be chilling at your base, crafting or doing whatever, suddenly the combat music stars playing and you hear screams and gunshots. This is something that devs definitely should change and give players some prep time to prepare for the fight. If you're near your base, you'll get a notification that your stuff is under attack, but again, zero prep time.
- Gun wielding NPCs are very, very aimboty and have no issues tracking you through walls, during night time or when they're being fully covered by foliage. This makes gunfights mostly boil down to sniping enemies from a safe distance to avoid cheap deaths. Especially since if you're facing equal tech level enemies, you're not gonna be tanking too many shots.
- Humanoid enemies don't respawn, so once you clear an outpost, you can use it as a base or something.

Other jank/bugs/quirks:
- If your inventory/container is full and you try adding more stuff to it, instead of the game not letting you do that, you'll just drop it on the ground. It's especially annoying if you accidentally press "loot all" button on the inventory UI.
- AI can sometimes shoot through solid objects or swim in the ground.
- There's bits of invisible walls here and there, sometimes you can swim through windows, other times you can't. Wonders of early access I suppose.
- Some generator powered machines have broken audio and make noises somewhere else, not where they're actually located.
- Containers that aren't fully looted will be restocked once you reload the game :^) (this one will be fixed at some point I'm sure)

What part of Early Access do people not get?!?! The game isn't complete... so of course there is going to be a few bugs and glitches. When you buy an Early Access Game you expect that, and you know it will eventually be all nice and shiny. 

My husband and I have really enjoyed the game, there is a ton of stuff to do, the ocean is fun to explore. The PVE aspect of the game make's it fun and challenging. The game feels like if Atlas and Rust had a baby, you would get Sunkenland. I would recommend this game only to people who are frequent players to Early Access games, and like games like Atlas, Ark Rust, Small Land, and can have a sense of humor with some of these glitches.

I do believe they plan to keep the game PVE, but you can host a server and turn friendly fire on, and get the feel for PVP. Although you can open it up for up to 15 people I here it's not a good idea at this time, 5 or 6 people is good. The way the game is set up is so it doesn't become toxic like so many other games like this have become, which is why they probably wont be opening up server's for large amounts of people. 
I recommend joining the discord, it is very informative, answers a ton of questions and the tutorial videos are piling up.

You know, this isn't a bad game. They're bugs in it sure. I can't rotate my building pieces with the "rotate" button for example. All the wall pieces face out instead of in. I can't rotate the roof/ceiling pieces at all, I used floors for a ceiling. Is it annoying, sure. Is is game breaking, no. 

The exploration of the underwater world to me is just magic. I love the sunken cities and freeways. It's eerily beautiful. The water is nicely done,  I love the random decorations, especially neon kitty <3.

The controls work fine, no issues once i set the mouse sensitivity to max and set my mouse to max dpi as well. 

Maybe I don't see it, but I do wish items could be destroyed instead of just dropped. They don't seem to despawn ever. It would be nice to use charcoal as well as wood in forges or grills maybe. The metal walls I think could use a retexture maybe, they seem to look a bit like thin tissue paper with holes, so I went with wood.

I love that you can turn raids off or on. Since I'm playing single player and just wanted to explore, build, and fight what I ran across vs having to stop and run back to base to stop a raid, I'm allowed to do that.

Overall good game and I don't feel bad recommending it.

I've been an avid survival game player for years. Loved Ark and Raft. This game initially felt like a good mix. There is so many neat aspects of this game. I really wanted to keep playing. BUT the server settings did not save so we were unaware that it was open to people. So some jerk logged on, and wiped our base, destroyed both our boats and left us stranded across the map. There was no fail safes to help us. There was no notification to let us know someone was in the server. It just really sucks. This game has potential but it's LACKING SO MUCH.

Pros:
crafting
exploration
new places
new things to find
surprisingly large amount of blue prints to find

cons
glitchy
hit boxes are really only for you. the NPCs can hit you thru a wall from a mile away.
zero server safety
only notification are for npcs attacking your base ( not randos)
no way to lock homes to non clan members. (like ark)

Tried reaching out to devs/admins via discord and were basically told "that sucks"
so, it's not worth the grind.

(I DON'T LIKE SP GAMES)..so i really hope they tone down A LOT of the resource/crafting grinding aspects because too much of that just makes the game BORING!!! to where I've lost interest & left dissatisfied in 20 hours LET US HAVE FUN!!!.so hopefully they'll get better servers where no matter what server players choose to play on all of the hard work & progression will follow them ...(hint) like DAYZ servers. so my verdict is mixed i love the idea and different concept but HATE THE DELIVERY!.....please developers stop using the same darn blueprint for survival games your turning good games into RESOURCE MANAGEMENT SIMULATOR'S!!!

I've played just over 16hrs and I'm really enjoying this game. I turned off the setting to not get attacked for now so I can focus on building.  Scavenging the water world is fun. It reminds me a little like dayz without losing all your stuff and starting over again. I don't think any real players are on the same server as me, at least I've only seen ai mutants. I would like to see some more side missions or other looting opportunities. I also like that when I die I can go straight to the marker for my dead body and get my stuff back.

So far this game has been amazing for being early access. It reminds me of the good old days when Rust first came out but the world is flooded. Its been a while since I've been able to set down and play a game for hours with out getting tired of it. It runs great, It looks great, and so far i haven't really found any game breaking issues.

Try it, it is good times if you're into survival games. It is pretty casual friendly imho. The dev team is very active and ambitious and the new roadmap is impressive, but also realistic.

Might want to disable the ai raids at the beginning if they are too disruptive. You can turn them on later once you learned the ropes.
most impressive 20$ beta i have played.

This game is 7 Days to Die aesthetics with mechanics of Raft + Stranded Deep in the universe of "Waterworld" (that one movie with Kevin Costner, you should watch it)

Your typical survival crafting game with horde and raiding elements. Pretty easy to figure out, nothing really complicated. Extensive building and crafting recipes. As its early access you can expect a bit of jankieness and some bugs but they're not too bothersome. Hunger and thirst are easy to manage. Finding lots of wood is hard after you've picked your island clean, because now you have to venture off to other islands with overpowered enemies. You can scavenge wood from bellow the water but its simply not enough.

My biggest complaint is the combat: Enemies are wayy too overpowered, swinging weapons much faster that you can, sometimes they have aim-bot, killing you way too easily. Your character is slow and sluggish. The combat seriously needs to be balanced better! Its a very good thing it doesn't take too long to respawn and you don't permanently loose everything upon death, unless you truly can't reach it; I don't know if there is a despawn timer on dropped loot from your corpse.

Just rebalance the combat and all will be well.

The game is great has lots of potential... however during my play-through of the game my friend and I were playing on a private server and suddenly got griefed by a hacker our entire base destroyed only for them to log off right after ruining our entire playthrough and I am unable to report them in any way I only have there display name which is "Yousy" I suggest something be done about these cheaters ASAP. Another thing to note is that when fighting the NPCs the hit-boxes for the buildings are a bit strange and can make it frustrating to fight them due to their ability to see these invisible hit-boxes and use it against you, I believe the game would be a lot better if these hit-boxes are fixed.

The instability in this game is UNBEARABLE! I couldn't even join the server properly for so many hours after the recent update!. Even now, after a day of cooling off, I tried again, and I'm STILL getting the 'Time out' error. Please OPTIMIZE your 'Join server' function for better performance for all players, especially when it's intended for joining with a friend, because it is REALLY RUINING the experience.

Hello! It's a really nice game indeed! It's a nice idea , with a very good graphics and mechanic. Overall, I would say an 8/10 at this moment. However, at this version(update 1.20) I would have few comments from the point of view of a single player.
1. The NPCs seems to be too aggressive. Started with day 3 they attacked me every day. if I hadn't seen some walktrough before I wouldn't make it. Seems the NPCs don't spend time to gather food and stuff. All they want is me and my little island! Maybe a camouflage of the camp will help. And why they want so much my little island , there are no viable resources here! I know, the game know everything about you and want to kill you!
2. The company changed the food and water gathering geometry. IMHO takes too long to do that and let you too less time to gather resources, even if you don't sleep(need to use those medicine from mushroom and strawberry).
3. I visited few inhabited islands but nowhere found potable water and I didn't find some water purifier(BTW, there are other few methods to obtain potable water, other than purifier!). It's hard to believe they drink only Coke! (why not Pepsi or Schweppes too ?! xD)
4. Even if the NPCs are very good swimmer, I didn't encounter them gather resources underwater. How they lives, what they eat? And most important, why I can't sneak and steal their food and resources? xD
5. Why all factions are hostile? And why they don't fight each other? Aha, they waiting for me to kill me and everybody will be happy!
6. The trader is not part of a faction and I don't know how she survive alone and without defense. And please make her stop to rob me in the trade!
7. I think will be nice to have a friend (like Victoria in Son of the forest) to give some task to do when you are busy. Even some dialogues will be nice too!
8. In this version I have some experience with the paddle boat. It started to shaking and fly away few times but I manage to recover it after press F-drive. BTW, can I change this key please? I'm not a fan of the WSAD sequence, sorry for that.

As I said , overall is a very nice game and can't wait to be better!
Thank you

With that said, this game is rough around the edges. The UI needs a big makeover, everything is a button, I.e "split", "drop". Simply dragging the item out of the inventory UI should drop it. Sunkenland presents an intriguing concept that I wholeheartedly recommend, particularly to those who found joy in playing Stranded Deep. The captivating oceanic environment, filled with sunken and lost cities, never fails to leave me in awe every time I dive into the game. However, it's worth noting that, while enjoyable, Sunkenland can be completed in just a few days, lacking a clear long-term objective beyond looting and combat. Nevertheless, my excitement is fueled by the recently unveiled development roadmap, promising exciting updates on the horizon.

It's essential to keep in mind that Sunkenland remains in its early access phase, which means encountering occasional bugs is par for the course. Despite this, if given the chance, I would unquestionably purchase it again. The potential and promise of Sunkenland's ongoing development make it a worthwhile investment for any fan of immersive exploration and adventure games.

I like the base building, acquiring blueprints, building more powerful weapons, and faster boats. Its fun to hold off a raid. The hit boxes need some work. The AI could also use some work. Overall a really fun game with lots of potential.

[h1]Sunkenland Review: 4/5 Stars - An Engaging Dive into Early Access[/h1]

In the vast sea of survival games, Sunkenland stands out as a promising title that offers players a unique and immersive experience. As a dedicated player of survival games with over 2200 games in my library, I was intrigued by Sunkenland's premise and decided to take the plunge into its post-apocalyptic underwater world.

Gameplay (⭐⭐⭐⭐): A Multifaceted Adventure

The gameplay in Sunkenland is a mix of crafting, exploration, and survival mechanics, creating a multifaceted adventure that keeps players engaged. Gathering resources, crafting tools, and constructing underwater bases are just a few activities that contribute to the game's dynamic gameplay.

One commendable feature is the progression system. Starting with basic tools and advancing through tiers of technology adds a satisfying sense of accomplishment. This progression structure enables players to adapt and overcome the challenges posed by the submerged landscape.

One aspect that distinguishes Sunkenland's gameplay is the presence of AI enemies. From traditional zombies to more complex adversaries like slavers and cultists, these enemies inject a level of danger and excitement into the gameplay. What particularly caught my attention was the fact that these NPCs aren't mere background elements. Instead, they actively raid your base, growing progressively more formidable as you advance through the game. This unique dynamic adds an element of tension and strategy to base-building efforts, pushing players to strategize and reinforce their defenses to fend off relentless invasions.

Enemy AI (⭐⭐⭐⭐): A Dynamic Challenge

In a world ravaged by apocalyptic events, AI enemies are a constant threat in Sunkenland. The game introduces a variety of enemies, each requiring different tactics for successful combat. From close-quarters engagements with zombies to more intricate interactions with slavers and cultists, the diversity of AI adversaries adds depth to the game's narrative and challenges.

One intriguing aspect of enemy AI is their raiding behavior. While currently, NPCs swim to your base for raids, this might not be the developers' long-term intention. It's possible that this mechanic is a temporary solution until more advanced raiding tactics, like NPC boats, are implemented—a future feature that holds the promise of even more engaging gameplay dynamics.

While the current array of enemies might not pose a significant challenge to experienced survival gamers, the developers' plans to introduce new enemy types and combat mechanics are exciting prospects. These additions could potentially elevate the game's combat dynamics and introduce fresh excitement to encounters with hostile factions.

Character Customization (⭐⭐⭐): Crafting Your Avatar

Character customization is a feature that allows players to personalize their avatars, albeit with some limitations. At present, the available options are somewhat constrained, and the character models may appear dated. However, it's important to remember that Sunkenland is still in early access, and character customization is an area that will likely see improvement over time.

The developers have expressed intentions to expand and enhance the customization features in the future. This includes the addition of more outfit options and refinements to visual aspects. As the game progresses, players can anticipate a broader array of choices to create avatars that truly resonate with them.

Server Selection (⭐⭐⭐): A Work in Progress

Sunkenland's current server selection is modest, mainly comprising player-created games with a limited number of slots. However, the developers have indicated plans to enrich the multiplayer experience with increased customization and control options. This suggests that the server selection will become more varied and expansive as the game evolves.

Exploration and Map (⭐⭐⭐⭐): Diving into the Unknown

Sunkenland's map beckons with the promise of exploration, presenting a world with diverse islands to discover. Yet, the standout aspect is the underwater setting—a departure from many other survival games that prioritize above-water activities. This unique approach adds a layer of mystery and excitement, encouraging players to dive into the depths of a post-apocalyptic universe.

However, there's potential to elevate the experience further by expanding the map. With a water-based gameplay focus, introducing a larger map could provide even more opportunities for exploration. The addition of larger boats or ships would enhance immersion, encouraging players to embrace the vastness of the underwater expanse. Future plans to introduce raidable islands and atolls with varying challenges and rewards indicate exciting prospects for exploration.

Performance (⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐): A Smooth Submersion

Performance is a strong point for Sunkenland, particularly considering its early access status. Running the game on a high-end gaming PC with Windows 11 Pro, an Intel Core i9-12900K CPU, 32 GB DDR5-4800 RAM, NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3080 Ti GPU, and stored on an NVMe drive, the game remains smooth on maximum settings. Frame rates remain stable during intense moments, ensuring an immersive and enjoyable gameplay experience.

Sunkenland: A Rising Tide of Potential

In conclusion, Sunkenland is an early access game with immense promise. Its blend of crafting, exploration, and survival mechanics, coupled with its distinctive underwater setting, makes for an engaging and memorable experience. While some aspects like character customization and enemy AI are still evolving, the developers' roadmap and commitment to continuous improvement signal a bright future for the game. With further refinements and additions, Sunkenland has the potential to rise above the waves and become a true standout in the survival genre.

I really do like this game, I think it has a lot of potential.  It’s in early access, so I don’t hold any of the following criticisms against the dev team, these are just some subjective observations.  I’m hoping these observations are improved in the future.  I don’t have a lot of time in this game.  I haven’t played multiplayer, I haven’t taken over enemy islands, so take this with a grain of salt.

Most of the issues I’ve run into are UI/UX issues.  The game looks and plays great but the UI/UX and inventory management feels very tacked on.  There’s a lot of general interface issues that are expected in these types of games that are just not there. A lot of pros to this game, but I’m only listing the cons for visibility as I think these issues being fixed will massively improve the experience of this game.

Even if this list seems “negative”, I’m still giving this a positive review.  As a fellow game dev, I understand these issues are easily remedied and the devs rely on feedback to improve their game.

The aesthetics vs. form/fit/function seem way unbalanced.  There is such a focus on aesthetics/decorations that the other core parts of the game are suffering.

Settings:
- My monitor refresh/v-sync settings are not correct.  I get an obnoxious sync issue with my monitor.  I need all monitor options,(it only gives me the 50Hz options, but I need 59Hz).  The vertical sync is very distracting.
- Mouse speed, even set to max (which I think is 6.0) is still pretty slow for the maximum mouse speed.  This range needs to be increased.

Storage / Item Management
- There’s no incentive to build resource specific storage containers unless you are going for an aesthetic only feature.  They hold magnitudes less resources than just building a basic wooden chest and take up more footprint.  Why build a wood/scrap metal storage when they hold less storage than two full stacks of a basic chest?
- Why can’t I take all from a resource storage (wood/scrap)?  I have to take one unit at a time?  This is very obnoxious as the audio just spams as I click to take one unit at a time.  Please add a “take all” from the resource storage.
- Same goes with building refrigerators, etc.  There’s no item spoil time so why build these except for aesthetics?  They are way more expensive than just building a basic wooden chest.
- Why do I have to drop the item on a button to “split” or drop?  Why is there no split-in-half shortcut (like shift click?  Why can’t I drag an item into “nothing” on the UI to drop it?
- [bug] Adding a water bucket filled with seawater to a storage container and retrieving it doesn’t count as being filled with water even though the “fill bar” is full?  I have to fill it again.  Probably a bug.
- Grabbing loot from a container after your inventory fills up just drops it on the ground.  I’m not watching my inventory slots as I try to take items.  Just stop trying to take items when full?  Why pull it out and drop it on the ground?  Now I have to managed dropped items on the ground.
- If my backpack is full by my belt is not, why not fill up the belt?  Instead I have to move stuff to the belt to save some slots.

Map
- What is the percentage next to locations on a map?  Is this % looted?  I’m assuming so but there’s no information on what this value means.
- The maps are static.  I was a little disappointed by this but this isn’t a game breaking mechanic.  A lot of games do static maps but I was hoping for a procedurally generated world on every world creation.  There are still random elements when looting.

Game Save/Load
- I had to restart 3 times.  My machine crashed when saving when exiting.  This corrupted my save.  Then after replaying the world again, I couldn’t save over it again for apparently the same corruption issue?  Why not just overwrite?  Why not backup the save file before the exit/save in case of corruption as a fallback?
- Loading back into a saved game is janky.  I’ve had logs just laying around for no reason, etc.  I start at the original starting position then the game moves me to the saved character positions and just starts popping stuff in.  This doesn’t look clean.  Early access though, I get it!

There are more notes I would like to add but I think this is a good start.  I hope the devs treat this as a labor of love because there’s so much potential here.  I think this can prove to be a great game if they improve the quality of life/user experience.  Again, it’s early access so it is what it is.  Hopefully I will get to remove this review in praise of the game they are wanting to make.

I have played many games. This is one of the best demo games out of this type in awhile. And having the devs working on fixes and updates at a pretty decent speed, I see this as one of the best games of 2023.

Sunkenland is surprisingly fun and addictive. I made it nine days without dying, then the armed mutants showed up. You have to stay on your toes or you will drown, starve, freeze, or dehydrate. Though the game gives you the ability to learn as you dive for scrap and hopefully some canned food, you have to work for it. Getting established doesn't take too long, yet I do believe the dehydration and starvation rates are a bit too high. I love how the calling of the birds, the lapping of the waves, and the pleasant views  lull you into a false sense of security, and then Bang! You're dead! It's a lot of fun and I hope to see it expand. And did I mention the sharks?

Few minutes in and honestly, I can definitely see the potential this game holds. It's pretty fun to just scavenge for things over an interesting set piece for a world. Lotta things need tweaking though but, it's pretty early in development so that can easily be changed. Some more convenience parts like scrolling making you switch between the hand slots and so. Combat also probs needs more power to it. Like the enemy reacting to a hit or so. 

Hope you guys put your hearts into it and do your best on it. You really got a good concept going.

this game, while still in early access, is quite thoroughly enjoyable. The underwater gameplay is smooth & beautiful, allowing visibility to the player for long distances, & changes with the time of day. Crafting is easy to understand & the stations look like they belong in the world. I'm hoping more building options become available, along with the ability to move objects without destroying them.  Stairs or ramps would be useful since the ladders currently in use seem slow. I personally try to jump onto them to decrease the climb time. farming new plants would be nice since the cook stations tell of more extensive food items. It gives the impression cooking & farming will be fleshed out more & I'm hoping that is so. I also ran into a bug concerning the passive fish traps; I wouldn't get the fish in my inventory after clicking on the trap. Maybe it's fixed in the new update. I'm about to find out. ^.^

The exploration is good, the invasions are good with the npcs becoming gradually more and more difficult. Yes there are some bugs and glitches but for a game that is barely a week old. This is quite fun. I look forward to seeing what Vector3 Studio has yet to introduce to the game

Okay, first review I've ever done for a game.  So here we go.
At first I was drawn right in and really enjoyed the game.  Started building an inventory of wood and scrap metal.  Began building up my base, made a (bugged) fish trap that caught fish, but never gave them to me.  Made a crate to store all of my overflow items.  Things were going great!  I started to unlock more items via the crafting table, made everything you would need (and some) to survive.  Then the NPC raiders came.  I was able to fight them off, would die a few time, but managed to defend my base.  However, I haven't been able to upgrade my weapons as quickly as these guys can.  I'm defending my base with a single shot flint lock and crossbow, while these f***ers come in with automatic weapons and what sounds like a 50cal rifle.  8-10 at a time making short work of my reinforced walls.  Then the domino effect of destruction to my furnaces, weapons craft table, armor craft table, all of my barrels, etc.  16 hours of building up this base, trying to find the appropriate resources to make better weapons and traps, but after a raid I'm busy repairing.  Next thing i know, it's nightfall and there's not much that you can do (gathering-wise) at night, because you get frosty (I'm wearing a long sleeve shirt, pants, gloves, but doesn't matter).  So I go out in the morning and gather.  It's always wood, scrap metal, glass, rubber, circuit board (if I'm lucky, usually not), a few components, and cloth.  I've heard there's leather, but I've only found like 8 in 16 hours of game play.  I'm currently typing up this "review", because I'm not sure if I want to continue playing after my base was annihilated during the last NPC raid on my base.  My current question is, "why should I continue playing?".  So I can spend another 16 hours collecting enough items to maybe make something to defend off 8 guys at a time that ALWAYS know where you're at.  You can't sneak them, they know you're hiding behind that rock, wall, whatever.  They're waiting to one shot you.  Just avoid them?  All of my ammo is with my dead body and have no way of getting it without confronting them.  I would sneak them, but alas I've already stated how that goes.  So yeah, that's where I am with this game.  I will probably go back in and see if I can't re-fortify my demolished base.  The game has been fun up until having everything destroyed.  
Also, I feel like if murder everyone on an enemy occupied base, then that base is mine.  I've built markers on them afterwards, was even able to build a structure on them, but it still showed that it was occupied by an enemy faction.  Seems like it should be mine.  
I've clicked yes for the "Would you recommend this game to other players?" question, because as I said I've really enjoyed the game up until this point.  I probably just suck at the game and others are finding it to be ridiculously easy.  Therefore, you should try it if you're looking for a survival game and form your own opinion.  Okay, I'm done with this "review".

TL:DR is at bottom.

Somewhat Upsetting "bugs": The game at the moment is REALLY rough around the edges, building is kind of a pain because placement snapping is a little goofy and is really picky about where you're standing and where you are looking. You also cannot as of the moment pick up things you built, only demolish, and demolishing an object/structure is sometimes with diminishing returns. An example would be a wall costs 3 wood, sometimes you get 3 wood back, sometimes 2, sometimes 1. Any collectible items/furnishings you find are completely destroyed when "demolished". So better be happy where you place them. So far, all objects HAVE to have a foundation under them to place them unless it's very specific things like defenses and such. Can't have a planter box on the dirt, can't have a pump, smelter, or cooker on the dirt. (Some might argue the game somewhat "implores" you to build on the water itself to make up for most of these issues. More building room, more choices etc. etc. Trees respawn when relogging which is a HUGE mess to clean up if your base was built where trees spawn. They break and fly all over the place. A fun "bug" in my opinion though is the ability to sit on a boat and push it, allowing you to almost hit mach 1, especially if friends are pushing it too, in the same direction of course. (Honestly I hope they keep this as a toggle-able option when starting a game.)

Missing things you'd expect: Stairs, ramps, slopes, half-walls. The roadmap says they are coming but I'm writing this as review of the game of my play so far so it may change.

Balancing: I feel personally the game lacks when it comes to storage/stacking as stacks of wood go only to 20, and scrap metal to 10. You can see the issue here as these two materials are primary crafting ingredients and will fill slots very very quickly. The dedicated wood/scrap storage containers only hold three stacks of their respective items. A barrel can hold a 5x5 grid? I could be a little off but you get the picture, basically you can have 1 barrel in the place of three or more scrap/wood storage racks. And they are considerably cheaper to make too. Personally I'd say to make stacks a much larger quantity, get rid of the dedicated scrap/wood storages or make them hold an far more than any other container in the game to make use of it more often.

Good thoughts: The Co-op is incredibly seamless and built into steam server integration which makes it super easy for friends to get together and play. The crew on the discord page is highly interactive and always looking through bug reports as well as suggestions. Half of my complaints are already written down as well as many more I didn't cover in this review. So they seem to be constantly improving and taking notes from the community which is always a plus in my book, customers who feel heard feel well taken care of. Even more so if these complaints are actually encountered and made right. Buy this game if you want to be part of the early seeds sown and of a growing community.

Bad thoughts: This could just be another grab-n-go where the dev makes a half decent game, seems super involved and just leaves the game in a horrible state and disappears with all the cash. Don't buy this game yet if you are worried about this. Wait a while.

TL:DR - Game has a lot a of bugs, can look really pretty, has base building and resource management and can be a lot of fun with friends. It's basically Rust/Raft/Fallout 4 all mashed up. No dedicated server is required to play with friends. Buy it if you're willing to toss 20 dollars away, don't if you're worried the dev won't continue to take care of it. Wait a while and see if it improves.

I haven't played long, but this game is a lot of fun. Yes, it is early in development and yes, there are bugs, but I think it has a ton of potential :)   If you like Raft, Subnautica and just good survival games in general you'll enjoy this game!
Really enjoying the game play. The AI is a bit clunky but they are fun to fight.

So as of now the game is awesome, the only thing I dislike is not being able to sleep when tired, the character should be able to sleep at night, and not being able to sucks. I know it's an early access game and things will change. I still recommend this game to anyone who like survival/building type games.
Really enjoying this game a lot! Keep making it better. I look forward to seeing how it continues to improve!!

I've been playing sunken-land for a while now and can certainly say for a in development game it doesn't have as many bugs or issues as i first thought. With that being said no in dev game can escape the inevitable, There are currently only 2 bugs i have encountered and a issue with the collision boxes on some item. Firstly the bugs. One has already been patched. A bug where when pausing the game in a sail boat the speed will continue to climb and when coming out of the pause menu the boat would get launched at mach 1 (exaggeration) into the closest island. The second being a random wood spawning bug where in you save and log out then log back in quickly and around 8 full logs and 15 branches randomly appear on my island base. lastly, the collision boxes for things like ladders, cars, trucks, and barricades are enormous and prove to be a fat pain in the ass when fighting.  Other than that the Devs for Sunken-Land have been doing a solid job cracking down on bugs and solving them quickly and efficiently, 8.5/10 Highly recommend

I just started playing today 5 hours with a friend in Co-op . I read some reviews before and was not sure if it makes fun in this state of the game, but I have to say the exploring, looting and defending of our base was really great. The gameplay and connection in Co-op with my friend was so smooth, no problems at all. No big bugs in the game. There is a lot of things to craft, loot and decorate. The building system and placing of objects is so easy and enjoying. The AI of the enemies could be better, but i think they will improve that in development of the game. Finally a nice survival game with Coop again.

Someone placed a comment on one of my reviews about checking out this game, I can't say their name because I can't read the comment any more, shows it exists, but can't read. That game was Sengoku, which isn't really the same as this one. That being said I have played 3 game like it; Subnautica 1 and 2, and Stranded Deep, which this game is similar too. This game however has trading and a lot more humanoid interaction (Pengwings are cute, but don't say much), and crabs that are less cranky. It's a new game so there are some bugs, but they seem to be working hard on it. It seems there is a lot to explore and discover even at this stage of the game, so I believe it is well worth it. Happy diving!

This game is fantastic already as is, and being this early in early access and being this good? Amazing. Setting the standards right where they should be. I dropped 13 hours in current version at the time of this review, unfortunately a PC crash caused my save file to corrupt, but I'm eagerly awaiting to see whatever the next update holds before I start another run, for now I'll take some aggression out on some sharks ;)
gg good game

Good game with great potential. Lots of things to do in the game, even with everything just being baseline stuff for now.
Jogo muito bom para jogar solo ou coop e também muito viciante recomendo. O jogo tras novidades para o público que curte jogos de sobrevivência.

Have to admit, this is addicting.  I have always been a loot...well you know..but the base building, upgrading, loot, mineral, gathering added with the oxygen needs while diving deep makes this a hit.  The DEV's are paying attention and ACTIVELY making changes/fixes as they pop up.  The NPC base raiding is a nice touch, they are relentless.  If you are looking for a time sync with a bit of action, this is for you.
For early access this game is pretty fun and has hours and hours of game play.

This thing is bugged af, enemies can shoot in any direction regardless of where they are looking at, their step don't make any sound so good luck trying to locate them before they start shooting, sometimes they will even walk through solid stuff and don't even get close to a shore since the enemy will keep switching from walking animations to "swimming" underground

Base building is extremely basic, if you try to build anywhere other than in the middle of the ocean you will have problems with building vertically and snapping elements with each other. Storage options are outright stupid, somehow a small box can store more scrap metal than a fucking shelve.

This game doesn't need some cooking it's just raw
Very good game, its like 7days and raft mixed together.
I like it.... I like it a lot.....

This game has tons of potential. The building is a little finicky but not impossible. You CAN rotate foundations but only if you angle the mouse right. After about 2 hours of straight gameplay the game had crashed and i was going to be pretty upset if i lost all my progress but it turned out when i loaded back in i just loaded right where i previously crashed. Unsure if it was a hell of an auto save timer or if it generally saves the game no matter how you exit. A small issue that can be rather annoying is if you have a wall with a chest on one side and maybe another chest or a crafting station on the other, you can practically look into the chest through the wall and it is also finicky getting to the menu you want without seeing the open storage text and not what you're standing in front of. Otherwise besides the obvious early access bugs that will eventually be addressed, it's a pretty fun game and i'm looking forwards to whats to come.

Really great game.Tough getting through the first attacks but very enjoyable. / One negative though. My fishnets are full and when I collect the fish with F key they do not appear in my inventory. All other fish, crabs etc though to appear as expected

Love the game. that's it, that's the review.
Still in the works, and I already love it.  Played a few hours of co-op with my buddy and we are hooked.  I can't wait to see how the game progresses, but I promise I'll be there the whole time!

The game is overall awesome. Of course it has its flaws because of it being in early access. From what i've also seen the devs are very interactive with the community. Along with that they release updates fast and none of them so far have been bad or filler updates. I can pretty much say the game will progress and get better and better. 10/10 game.

For early access I think the game is amazing.  There is so much to do and explore.  I've seen reviews where they finished in 15 or 20 hours and I don't know how.  I'm 50 hours in and still have half the island left to explore.  The graphics are stunning, particularly underwater.  I haven't encountered any bugs yet. There are a few things I would like to see...more stacking, better storage.  Lights for when you are deep underwater.  But I'm sure these will get addressed as time goes by.  Kind of hoping that at some point there will be at least a minimal story...but over all great game!!
This is a great game bunch of stuff to do awesome story-line and progression. :Note: Do expect bugs because it is in early access
great

This is truly a great game!
I am having a blast playing it. 
I wish I could have had this one in my line up a long time ago.
From the start, you can set the difficulty settings. Best part is you can modify them later.
Let's review.

Pro's-
1. It has genuine co-op.
2. Co-op and Worlds couldn't be simpler to join or create.
3. The Graphics and Music are spot on.
4. The concept itself is fantastic. - Dive and loot!
5. So much to do. Never gets boring.
6. Want to build a base or a Mega stricture? Feel free.
7. Want to hunt Marlin or Sharks? It's here.
8. Want build a boat and go exploring? Sure thing.
9. Want to grow your own plants? Yep
10. Want some AI combat? Gear up and go to battle.
11. Want to visit a trader and swap your items for theirs? She is always open.
12. Want to go visit the Nudist colony? Nope- Sorry not in the game.

Cons-
Only 1 that sticks out. Once you place anything, you can't move it or destroy it.

This game is getting a lot of updates.
For an early access, I am super impressed. This game is very polished.
When you first go to log on, there is a list of current content and also a list of future content.
The dev's are on top of the bugs and are actively working on content. A+++
If you are even thinking about a super fun game, this is it. 
Pull the trigger and get it. You won't be sorry.
Truly the best game I have bought in a really long time.
great game i see a future with this one rust lookout. great job

It's a very good game.  Can be frustrating in the late game due to lack of balance due to being in Alpha.  My friend and I replayed four different times with bases in four different locations and the repeatability is definitely there.  No con's really, but only because it's in Alpha.  The expectation is that the devs add more itemization to allow for smoother and more natural transitions through the games phases and that they balance the base attacks.
Rust Raft good

I'm a fan of Survival Open world Crafting game, and Sunkenland is just soooo adictive. Once I started playing it, time pass by like a blink of an eye. The crafting, battle engaging it's just too good. I wish they update the game where we can capture enemy base once you defeat them. Take the chance and buy this game, you wont regret it. Also I have big expectation for future updates on this game. I feel that the developer will hear us and make adjustment.

I am enjoying the game. I LOVE that the developer has given us the options to control how hard it is. I prefer a more relaxed game play and this game will give you that. There are a few things that I do not like or feel it needs but they may be in the making. First, I don't like the look of the scrap metal housing pieces. They just don't look good, even the wood looks better. There needs to be railing, stairs, hatched pieces and half walls added. The scrap roof piece shape is ok but there should be normal roof pieces as well. One of the most important things to me is being able to pick stuff back up and move it. MAJOR drawback that you cannot do that. Even breaking something down takes a bit too much. The batteries and air tanks go down waaaay too fast. Rotating pieces does not work. Another one that is a necessity is snapping pieces for building and being able to stack boxes. I am enjoying the looting and finding the schematics. It really ticks a lot of boxes for me but it does need some improvements.
As someone coming from Rust, this game gets a huge thumbs up from me. It scratches an itch that Rust hasn't lately and I'm very excited to see how this game develops and progresses.
funnnn

In 3 day spent 55 hours playing. Forgot to eat in real life, sleep, etc... sun what sun. Legit this game is fun!!!!!!!!!!! There is a good balance of work to resources gathered till you need steel. Steel is Top notch stuff! There is a legit survival aspect. Need food, water, energy, weapons, armor, and to keep developing your base. If you don't get good fast you die.

The game is very fun. For early access, it offers quite a lot already. Been having so much fun with it. I look forward to what the developers bring. 10/10 would recommend. Best with friends but solo adventures are just as fun.
The dev team seem to really care about their audience and are listening to all the feedback the community is giving them. 10/10 can't wait to see the progress of this lovely, quaint little game.
